la|Livy|Ab Urbe Condita|26|1|quote=Ea tum cura maxime intentos habebat Romanos, non ab ira tantum, quae in nullam unquam ciuitatem iustior fuit, quam quod urbs tam nobilis ac potens, sicut defectione sua '''traxerat''' aliquot populos, ita recepta inclinatura rursus animos uidebatur ad ueteris imperii respectum.|year=27-25 BCE|trans=This concern in particular troubled the mindful Romans at the time, not so much because of anger, which has never been more justified against any other city, rather because a city so noble and powerful, in the same way that it had '''attracted the support of''' a number of communities by its revolt, was thought would again turn attention back towards respect for the previous government once recaptured.

la|Livy|Ab Urbe Condita|26|1|quote=Ea tum cura maxime intentos habebat Romanos, non ab ira tantum, quae in nullam unquam civitatem iustior fuit, quam quod urbs tam nobilis ac potens, sicut defectione sua traxerat aliquot populos, ita '''recepta''' inclinatura rursus animos videbatur ad veteris imperii respectum.|t=This concern in particular troubled the mindful Romans at the time, not so much because of anger, which has never been more justified against any other city, rather because a city so noble and powerful, in the same way that it had attracted the support of a number of communities by its revolt, was thought would again turn attention back towards respect for the previous government once '''recaptured'''.

la|Livy|Ab urbe condita libri|24|31|10|quote=Haec cum recitāta essent, cum tantō clāmōre ad arma discursum est ut praetōrēs inter tumultum pavidī '''abequitāverint''' Syrācūsās.|trans=When these had been read out, they rushed to war with such noise that the scared praetors '''rode away''' to Syracuse.

la|Lucretius|De rerum natura|5|1302|quote=Inde boves Lucas turrito corpore, tetras,<br>'''anguimanūs''', bellī docuērunt volnera Poenī<br>sufferre et magnas Martis turbare catervas.|t=Next the Lucanian oxen with turreted backs, hideous creatures, '''snake-handed''', were taught by the Carthaginians to endure the wounds of war, and to confound the great hosts of Mars.|transauthor=W. H. D. Rouse, revised by Martin F. Smith|transyear=1924

la|Martial|Epigrammata|12|3|4|notes="charta ... anus"|quote=Quod Flacco Varioque fuit summoque Maroni / Maecenas, atavis regibus ortus eques, / gentibus et populis hoc te mihi, Prisce Terenti, / fama fuisse loquax chartaque dicet '''anus'''.|trans=What Maecenas, knight sprung from ancient kings, was to Flaccus and Varius and Maro the Supreme, this, Priscus Terentius, loquacious fame and paper '''grown old''' shall declare to all races and peoples that you were to me.|transauthor=D. R. Shackleton Bailey|transyear=1993

la|Martial|Epigrammata|1|105|4|notes="testa ... anus"|quote=In Nomentanis, Ovidi, quod nascitur agris, / accepit quotiens tempora longa, merum / exuit annosa mores nomenque senecta, / et quidquid voluit, testa vocatur '''anus'''.|trans=Ovidius, when the wine that is born in the fields of Nomentum has taken to itself length of time, it sheds its character and its name with old age full of years, and the '''ancient''' jar is called whatever it desired.|transauthor=D. R. Shackleton Bailey|transyear=1993
la|Martial|Epigrams|1|35|quote=Quid si me iubeas '''talassionem''' verbis dicere non '''talassionis'''?|trans=Would you have me speak the '''wedding chant''' without the words of the '''chant'''?

la|Martial|Epigrams|1|41|9|notes=[[w:Hendecasyllable#Phalaecian_hendecasyllable|Phalacean hendecasyllable]]|quote=quo͞d fūma͞ntĭă quī '''tŏmāclă''' ra͞ucu͞s<br>Ci͞rcu͞mfe͞rt tĕpĭdīs cŏcu͞s pŏpīnīs|t=...hoarse cook who carries around smoking '''''tomacla''''' at tepid eating-houses
la|Martial|Epigrams|4|37|8-10|quote=numerēs oportet aliquid, ut patī possim:<br>cotīdiānam refice nauseam nummīs:<br>audīre '''grātīs''', Āfer, ista nōn possum.

la|Ov.|M.|3|340|quote=Ille per Aonias fama celeberrimus urbes<br>'''inreprehensa''' dabat populo responsa petenti|t=He, the most famous through the cities of Aonia,<br>gave '''blameless''' answers to the people who sought them
la|Ovid|Amores|1|1|30|quote=Mūsa per '''ūndēnōs''' ēmodulanda pedes!|t=Muse, you must be measured through '''eleven''' feet.
la|Ovid|Epistulae ex Ponto|4|10|5|quote='''gutta cavat lapidem''', consumitur anulus usu|t='''the drop bores the rock''', the ring is worn out by use

la|Ovid|Fasti|1|117|thru=118|quote=quicquid ubīque vidēs, caelum, mare, nūbila, terrās,<br/>omnia sunt nostra '''clausa''' patentque manū.|trans=''Whatever thou beholdest around thee, the sky, the sea, the air, the earth , all these '''have been shut up''' and are opened by my hand.''<br/>'''1851'''. ''The Fasti &c of Ovid.'' Translated by {{w|H. T. Riley

la|Ovid|Fasti|1|197|thru=198|quote=plūrīs opēs nunc sunt quam '''prīscī''' temporis annīs,<br/>dum populus pauper, dum nova Rōma fuit, [...]|trans=Now wealth is more valued than it was in years of '''former''' times,<br/>when the nation was poor, when Rome was new, [...]
la|Ovid|Fasti|1|715|quote=sōla gerat mīles, quibus arma '''coerceat''', arma|trans=May the soldier bear arms only to '''restrain''' [the use of] arms.

la|Ovid|Fasti|2|467|thru=468|quote=dum latet, '''īnsonuit''' ventō nemus; illa timōre<br/>pallet et hostīlēs crēdit adesse manūs|trans=While she lay hidden, the grove [of trees] '''resounded''' with the wind;<br/>she pales with fear and believes that bands of enemies are near.
la|Ovid|Fasti|2|574|quote=quā brevis '''occultum''' mūs sibi fēcit iter|trans=where a little mouse made a '''hidden''' passage for itself

la|Ovid|Fasti|3|675|thru=676|quote=nunc mihi cūr cantent superest '''obscēna''' puellae<br/>dīcere; nam coeunt certaque probra canunt|trans=''Now it remains for me to say why the girls sing '''obscene''' songs,<br/>for they get together and recite certain indecencies.''<br/>(The ancient Roman festival of {{w|Anna Perenna

la|Ovid|Fasti|3|733|thru=734|quote=Nōmine ab auctōris dūcunt '''lībāmina''' nōmen<br/>lībaque, quod sānctīs pars datur inde focīs.|trans='''''Libations''' and cakes draw their names from the name of their inventor,<br/>because a portion of them is being offered upon the sacred hearths.''<br/>(Ovid credits the god {{w|Liber

la|Ovid|Fasti|4|147|thru=148|quote=accipit ille locus positō vēlāmine cūnctās<br/>et '''vitium''' nūdī corporis omne videt|trans=''That place receives [you] with all [your] garments set aside,<br/>and exposes every '''blemish''' on the naked body.''<br/>(See {{w|Fortuna Virilis

la|Ovid|Fasti|4|401|thru=402|quote=prīma Cerēs homine ad meliōra '''alimenta''' vocātō<br/>mūtāvit glandēs ūtiliōre cibō.|trans=''Having called man to better '''nourishment''', Ceres first<br/>exchanged acorns with more useful food.''<br/>(See {{w|Ceres (mythology)

la|Ovid|Fasti|4|513|thru=514|quote=‘māter!’ ait virgō (mōta est dea nōmine mātris)<br/>‘quid facis in sōlīs '''incomitāta''' locīs?’|trans=''‘‘Mother!’’ says the maiden (the goddess was moved by the name of mother),<br/>‘‘What are you doing '''unattended''' in lonely places?’’''<br/>(A young shepherdess chances upon the goddess Ceres who, having disguised herself as an old woman, is searching everywhere for her own lost daughter, Persephone.)

la|Ovid|Fasti|5|279-281|quote=‘cētera luxuriae nōndum īnstrūmenta vigēbant,<br/>aut pecus aut lātam dīves habēbat humum;<br/>hinc etiam '''locuplēs''', hinc ipsa pecūnia dicta est.’|trans=''“The other instruments of luxury were not yet thriving: a rich man had either a herd or wide land; hence also [the word for] ‘'''wealthy'''’, [and] for this reason ‘money’ itself is named.”''<br/>(The poetic voice is that of {{w|Flora (mythology)

la|Ovid|Fasti|5|499|thru=504|quote=Ingemuit Chīrōn trāxitque ē corpore ferrum:<br>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;adgemit Alcīdēs Haemoniusque puer.<br>Ipse tamen lēctās Pagasaeīs collibus herbās<br>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;temperat et variā volnera '''mulcet''' ope:<br>vīrus edāx superābat opem, penitusque recepta<br>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;ossibus et tōtō corpore pestis erat.|trans=[[w:Chiron|Chiron]] groaned and drew the iron out of the body:<br>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;[[w:Heracles|Alcides]] and the [[w:Achilles|Haemonian boy]] groans back.<br>He himself herbs gathered from the Pagasaean hills<br>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;gathers and '''helps''' the wounds with diverse aid:<br>the greedy poison was overcoming the help, and received within<br>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;to the bones and the entire body was the pestilence.

la|Ovid|Fasti|5|549|thru=550|quote=fallor, an arma sonant? nōn fallimur, arma sonābant:<br/>Mārs venit et veniēns '''bellica''' signa dedit.|trans=''Am I mistaken, or are weapons sounding? We are not being deceived, arms were clashing: Mars approaches, and as he comes, he has given '''warlike''' signs.''<br/>(Games celebrated in May commemorated the dedication of the {{w|Temple of Mars Ultor

la|Ovid|Fasti|5|551|thru=552|quote=Ultor ad ipse suōs caelō dēscendit honōrēs<br/>templaque in Augustō '''cōnspicienda''' forō.|trans=''The Avenger himself is coming down from heaven to his own honors and his temple, '''worthy of attention''', in the forum of Augustus.''<br/>(See: {{w|Temple of Mars Ultor

la|Ovid|Fasti|5|57|thru=58|quote=‘Magna fuit quondam capitis reverentia '''cānī''',<br/>inque suō pretiō rūga senīlis erat.’|trans=''‘‘At one time, there was great respect '''of a gray''' head,<br/>and the wrinkling of old age was with value in itself.’’''<br/>(The voice is that of the muse {{w|Urania

la|Ovid|Fasti|5|681|thru=682|quote=‘'''ablue''' praeteritī periūria temporis,’ inquit<br/>‘'''ablue''' praeteritae perfida verba diē.’|trans=''“'''Wash away''' the false oaths of time passed,” he says, “'''wash away''' the dishonest words of the day gone by.”''<br/>(A merchant is praying at a spring, fountain, or well dedicated to {{w|Mercury (mythology)

la|Ovid|Fasti|6|205|thru=208|quote=prōspicit ā templō summum brevis ārea Circum,<br/>est ibi nōn '''parvae parva''' columna notae:<br/>hinc solet hastā manū bellī praenūntia mittī,<br/>in rēgem et gentēs cum placet arma cāpī.|trans=''Visible from the temple [is] a short open space, [and] the summit of the Circus [Maximus]. There [stands] a '''small''' column '''of''' no '''small''' renown: From this place the custom is to hurl by hand a spear, foretelling of war against a king and his people, [when] it is proper [that] with arms [they are] to be taken.''<br/>(With a symbolic hurling of a spear – originally into enemy territory, later within Rome itself – a {{w|fetial

la|Ovid|Metamorphoses|11|54|thru=55|quote=iamque mare invectae flumen populare relinquunt<br>et '''Methymnaeae''' potiuntur litore Lesbi:|trans=And now, carried towards the sea, they leave behind their native river<br>and take hold of the shore of '''Methymnaean''' Lesbos:

la|Ovid|Metamorphoses|4|15|quote=Ipse sedens solio '''Tereus''' sublimis avito / vescitur inque suam sua viscera congerit alvum.|trans=He himself, sitting [in] the ancestral chair, lofty '''Tereus''', eats and lavishes his own stomach [with] his own flesh.

la|Ovid|Metamorphoses|7|365|quote=Phoebeamque Rhodon et Ialysios '''Telchinas''', / quorum oculos ipso vitiantes omnia visu / Iuppiter exosus fraternis subdidit undis|t=She passed Rhodes, Phoebus' island, and the '''Telchines''' of Ialsos, whose all-devastating gaze Jupiter hated and buried beneath his brother's waves.<small> ―Dan Curley, ''[https://books.google.com/books?id=4ZmyAAAAQBAJ&pg=PT161 Tragedy in Ovid: Theater, Metatheater, and the Transformation of a Genre]''</small>

la|Ovid|Metamorphoses|7|685|quote=tum vero iuvenis '''Nereius''' omnia quaerit,|trans=Then, indeed, the youth of the Nereid seeks all,|notes=The youth of the Nereid here refers to Phocus, son of Psamathe, a Nereid.

la|Peter Abelard|Sic et non|year=1142|quote=''Hieronymus contra Jovinianum, lib. 1: Et si nupserit virgo, non peccavit'' (I Cor. VII, 28); non [autem] illa virgo, quae se semel Dei cultui dedicavit; harum si '''quaequam''' nupserit, habebit damnationem, quia primum fidem irritam fecit.|trans=''And if a virgin marry, she hath not sinned'' (1 Corinthians 7:28); but not that virgin, who has once devoted herself to the veneration of God; if '''any''' of these marries, she will be damned, because she first broke her promise.

la|Petronius|Satyricon|1|quote=Et ideō ego adulēscentulōs existimō in scholīs stultissimōs fierī, quia nihil ex hīs, quae in ūsū habēmus, aut audiunt aut vident, sed pirātās cum catēnīs in lītore stantēs, sed tyrannōs ēdicta scrībentēs, quibus imperent fīliīs ut patrum suōrum capita '''praecīdant''', sed respōnsa in pestilentiam data, ut virginēs trēs aut plūrēs immolentur, sed mellītōs verbōrum globulōs et omnia dicta factaque quasi papāvere et sēsamō sparsa.|trans=And this is why I consider that teens become most stupid in schools, because they neither hear nor see anything of those that we have in use, but pirates with chains standing on the shore, but tyrants writing edicts, by which they order that sons '''cut off''' the heads of their fathers, but oracles given in plagues, that three or more maidens be immolated, but balls of honeyed words and all that's said and done as if besprinkled with poppy and sesame seeds.

la|Petronius|Satyricon|45|text=Videbis populi rixam inter zelotypos et '''amasiunculos'''. Glyco autem, sestertiarius homo, dispensatorem ad bestias dedit. Hoc est se ipsum traducere. Quid servus peccavit, qui coactus est facere? Magis illa matella digna fuit quam taurus iactaret. Sed qui asinum non potest, stratum caedit.|transauthor={{w|Michael Heseltine (civil servant)|Michael Heseltine

la|Petronius|Satyricon|61|quote=Niceros delectatus '''affabilitate''' amici: "Omne me, inquit, lucrum transeat, nisi iam dudum gaudimonio dissilio, quod te talem video. Itaque hilaria mera sint, etsi timeo istos scolasticos ne me rideant. Viderint: narrabo tamen, quid enim mihi aufert, qui ridet? Satius est rideri quam derideri."|trans=Niceros was delighted by his friend's amiability and said, “May I never turn another penny if I am not ready to burst with joy at seeing you in such a good humour. Well, it shall be pure fun then, though I am afraid your clever friends will laugh at me. Still, let them; I will tell my story; what harm does a man's laugh do me? Being laughed at is more satisfactory than being sneered at.”

la|Pl.|As.|5|2|8|thru=9|quote=At nunc dehinc scītō illum ante omnēs minimī mortālem pretī, / madidum, nihilī, incontinentem atque '''ōsōrem''' uxōris suae.|t=But now henceforth know that he, before all, is a mortal of the least worth, / drunken, of no value, incontinent and a '''hater''' of his wife.

la|Pl.|Ba.|3|3|33|thru=37|text=[Philoxenus] Alii, Lyde, nunc sunt mores.<br>[Lydus] Id equidem ego certo scio.<br>Nam olim populi prius honorem capiebat suffragio,<br>quam magistro desinebat esse dicto oboediens;<br>at nunc, prius quam '''septuennis''' est, si attingas eum manu,<br>extemplo puer paedagogo tabula disrumpit caput.

la|Pl.|Cap.|3|5|12|thru=17|quote=Quia me meamque rem, quod in te uno fuit,<br/>tuis scelestis '''falsidicis''' fallaciis<br/>deartuasti dilaceravisti atque opes<br/>confecisti omnes, res ac rationes meas:<br/>ita mi exemisti Philocratem fallaciis.|trans=Because me and my fortunes, so far as in you singly lay, by your rascally and knavish stratagems you have rent in pieces, and have distracted my affairs and spoiled all my resources and my plans, in that you've thus robbed me of Philocrates by your devices.|transauthor=Henry Thomas Riley

la|Pl.|Cap.|5|4|32|thru=35|quote=Spectātōrēs, ad pudīcōs mōrēs facta haec fābula est,<br/>neque in hāc '''subigitātiōnēs''' sunt neque ūlla amātiō<br/>nec puerī suppositiō nec argentī circumductiō,<br/>neque ubi amāns adulēscēns scortum līberet clam suom patrem.|t=Spectators, this play was made with regard to chaste mores:<br/>neither in it are '''erotic caresses''' nor any lovemaking,<br/>nor the substitution of a child, nor the swindling of money,<br/>nor where a loving youth frees a prostitute secretly from his father.

la|Pl.|Cap.|5|4|32|thru=35|quote=Spectātōrēs, ad pudīcōs mōrēs facta haec fābula est,<br/>neque in hāc subigitātiōnēs sunt neque ūlla '''amātiō'''<br/>nec puerī suppositiō nec argentī circumductiō,<br/>neque ubi amāns adulēscēns scortum līberet clam suom patrem.|t=Spectators, this play was made with regard to chaste mores:<br/>neither in it are lascivious caresses nor any '''lovemaking''',<br/>nor the substitution of a child, nor the swindling of money,<br/>nor where a loving youth frees a prostitute secretly from his father.

la|Pl.|Ep.|5|2|12|thru=13|quote=Quidquid egō malefēcī, auxilia mī et suppetiae sunt domī, '''apolactizō''' inimīcōs omnīs.|trans=Whatever I have done bad, I have aid and assistance at home, I '''scorn''' all the enemies.
la|Pl.|Poen.|3|2|1|thru=2|text=Iam tenes praecepta in corde? — Pulchre. — Vide sis calleas.<br>— Quid opust verbis? Callum '''aprugnum''' callere aeque non sinam.

la|Pl.|Ps.|1|1|28|thru=29|quote=[Calidorus] odiosus mihi es.<br>lege vel tabellas redde. [Pseudolus] immo enim '''pellegam'''.|trans=[Calidorus] I hate you.<br>Read the tablet or give it back. [Pseudolus] Oh no, I will absolutely '''read it thoroughly'''.|notes=using the alternate form [[pellego|pellegō]]
la|Plautus|Amphitryon|2|1|598|quote=Dōnec Sōsia illic '''egomet''' fēcit sibi utī crēderem.|t=Until that Sosia—'''my own self'''—made it so I would believe him.
la|Plautus|Amphitryon|2|1|607|quote=Quis tē verberāvit? —'''Egomet''' [[memet#Latin|mēmet]], quī nunc sum domī.|t=Who has beaten you? —'''I myself''', who am now at home, beat myself.
la|Plautus|Amphitryon|2|1|607|quote=Quis tē verberāvit? —Egomet '''mēmet''', quī nunc sum domī.|t=Who has beaten you? —I myself, who am now at home, beat '''myself'''.

la|Plautus|Curculio|5|3|5|quote=''Argentariis male credi qui aiunt, nugas praedicant: nam et bene et male credi dico; id adeo ego hodie expertus sum. Non male creditur qui numquam reddunt, sed prorsum perit. Vel ille, decem minas dum solvit, omnis mensas transiit. Postquam nil fit, clamore hominem '''posco''': ille in ius me vocat; pessume metui, ne mihi hodie apud praetorem solveret. Verum amici compulerunt: reddit argentum domo. Nunc domum properare certumst.''<ref>[http://www.thelatinlibrary.com/plautus/curculio.shtml Latin]</ref>|trans=People that say bankers are ill trusted talk rubbish. Why, they are well and ill trusted both, I tell you–and what is more, I have proved it myself this very day. Money is not ill trusted to men that never repay you; it is gone for good. That Lyco, for example, in trying to raise forty pounds for me, went to every single bank. Nothing coming of it, I begin '''dunning''' him at the top of my lungs. He summons me before the magistrate I was horribly afraid he would settle with me in court. But his friends coerced him, and he paid me out of his own cash in hand. Now I must hurry home.<ref>[http://artemis.austincollege.edu/acad/cml/rcape/comedy/5-3.html English]</ref>

la|Plautus|Curculio|615|quote=[Curculio] Quod argentum, quas tu mihi tricas narras? Quam tu virginem<br>me reposcis? [Therapontigonus] Quam ab lenone abduxti hodie, scelus viri.<br>[Curculio] '''Nullam''' abduxi.|trans=[Curculio] What money, what nonsense are you telling me about? What girl are you demanding back from me? [Therapontigonus] The one you took away from the pimp today, you criminal. [Curculio] I did'''n’t''' take '''any''' away.|transauthor=Wolfgang de Melo|transyear=2011

la|Plautus|Menaechmi|quote=Ecce, Apollo, '''denuo''', me iubes facere impetum in eum qui stat atque occidere. Sed quis hic est qui me capillo hínc de curru deripit? Imperium tuom demutat atque edictum Apollinis.<ref>[http://artflx.uchicago.edu/perseus-cgi/citequery3.pl?dbname=PerseusLatinTexts&query=Pl.%20Men.%20867&getid=0]</ref>|trans=Lo! '''again''', Apollo, thou dost bid me to make an onset against him who is standing here, and to murder him. But what person is this that is tearing me hence by the hair down from the chariot? He revokes thy commands and the decree of Apollo.<ref>[http://artflx.uchicago.edu/perseus-cgi/citequery3.pl?dbname=PerseusLatinTexts&query=Pl.%20Men.%20863&getid=1]</ref>

la|Plautus|Miles Gloriosus|3|3|66|thru=68|notes=lines 939–941|quote=''Acr.'' Datne ab se mulier operam? <br> ''Per.'' Lepidissume et compsissume. <br> ''Acr.'' Confido '''confuturum'''.<br>ubi facta erit conlatio nostrarum malitiarum,<br>haud vereor ne nos subdola perfidia pervincamur.|transauthor=Paul Nixon|trans=Is the girl herself helping us? <br>Oh, delightfully, toutafaitly!<br>I trust '''things will turn out well'''. <br>When we've lumped together our talents for mischief, <br>I have no fear of our being beaten at artful wiles.
la|Plautus|Mostellaria|2|1|quote=In tuam '''custodelam''' meque et meas spes trado, Tranio.|trans=To your charge I commit myself, Tranio, and my hopes.|transauthor=Henry Thomas Riley

la|Plautus|Poenulus|5|5|38|thru=39|quote=Quīn '''adhibuistī''', dum istaec loquēre, tympanum?<br>nam tē cinaedum esse arbitror magis quam virum.|trans=Why didn't you '''hold out''' a tambourine while saying this?<br>'cause I think you're more of a catamite than a man.

la|Plautus|Pseudolus|4|4|9-10|quote=Occasionem '''repperisti''', [[verbero]],<br/>ubi [[perconteris]] me, insidiis hostilibus|trans='''You have found''' an opportunity, scoundrel, when you question me amid hostile ambush

la|Plin.|Naturalis Historia|16|18|40|quote=haec plurimam fundit interveniente candida gemma, tam simili turis, ut mixta visu discerni non queat; unde fraus '''Seplasiae'''.|trans=It gives out considerable quantities of resin, which is intermingled with white granulations like pearls, and so similar in appearance to frankincense, that when mixed, it is impossible to distinguish them; hence the adulterations we find practised in the '''Seplasia'''.

la|Plin.|Naturalis Historia|37|140|quote=etiam pateras, '''staticula''', equorum ornamenta inde medicisque coticulas faciunt|trans=and from them also are made dishes, '''statuettes''', horse-trappings and small mortars for the use of pharmacists

la|Plin.|Naturalis Historia|37|140|quote=etiam pateras, staticula, equorum ornamenta inde medicisque '''coticulas''' faciunt|trans=and from them also are made dishes, statuettes, horse-trappings and '''small mortars''' for the use of pharmacists

la|Plin.||28|45|159|quote=De '''equiferis''' non scripserunt Graeci, quoniam terrae illae non gignebant, verum tamen fortiora omnia eadem quam in equis intellegi debent.|trans=About '''wild horses''' the Greeks have not written, because Greek lands did not breed them, but it must be inferred that all remedies from them are more potent than from the tame animal.|transauthor=W. H. S. Jones

la|Plin.||31|44|97|quote=vitium huius est allex atque inperfecta nec colata faex. coepit tamen et privatim ex inutili pisciculo minimoque confici. apuam nostri, '''aphyen''' Graeci vocant, quoniam is pisciculus e pluvia nascatur.|transauthor=W. H. S. Jones|trans=Allex is sediment of garum, the dregs, neither whole nor strained. It has, however, also begun to be made separately from a tiny fish, otherwise of no use. The Romans call it ''apua'', the Greeks '''''aphye''''', because this tiny fish is bred out of rain.
la|Pliny the Elder|Natural History|18|13|quote=apud populum etiam de culturis agendi morem fuisse '''qualiterque''' defendi soliti sint illi viri
la|Pliny the Elder|Natural History|8|38|quote=persequitur interfectorem unumque eum in '''quantolibet''' populi agmine notitia quadam infestat

la|Pliny the Elder|Naturalis Historia|10|109|2|quote=Ob id cum his habenda est avis quae '''tinnungulus''' vocatur; defendit enim illas terretque accipitres naturali potentia in tantum ut visum vocemque eius fugiant. Hac de causa praecipuus columbis amor eorum, feruntque, si in quattuor angulis defodiantur in ollis novis oblitis, non mutare sedem columbas|trans=For that reason the bird called '''kestrel''' must be classed with these; for it defends the pigeons, and scares the hawks by its natural powerfulness so much that they fly from sight and sound of it. For this reason wood-pigeons have a special love for kestrels, and they say that if kestrels put in new jars with their mouths sealed up are hidden in the four corners of the dovecot the pigeons do not change their abode |transauthor=H. Rackham|transyear=1940

la|Pliny the Elder|Naturalis Historia|16|92|quote=Iam densa aut rara semperque lata rariora. disposita myrto, concava buxo, inordinata pomis, plura eodem pediculo exeuntia malis pirisque, ramulosa ulmo et cytiso. quibus adicit Cato decidua populea quernaque, animalibus iubens dari non perarida, bubus quidem et ficulnea ilignaque et '''hederacea'''. dantur et ex harundine ac lauru. decidunt sorbo universa, ceteris paulatim. et de foliis hactenus.

la|Pliny the Elder|Naturalis Historia|1|quote='''Zoranisceos''' in Indo ilumine nascitur : Magorum gemma esse narratur : ñeque aliud amplius de ea.|trans='''Zoranisceos''' is found in the river Indus. It is a gem said to be used by the magicians, and beyond this I know nothing more of it.

la|Pliny the Elder|Naturalis Historia|22|50|107|quote=Prīma propolis alvōrum, dē quā dīximus, acūleōs et omnia īnfīxa corporī extrahit, tūbera discutit, dūra concoquit, dolōrēs nervōrum '''mulcet''' ulceraque iam dēspērantia cicatrīcem clūdit.|trans=First, propolis of the hives, of which we've talked about, extracts bee stings and anything embedded in the body, reduces swellings, softens calluses, '''alleviates''' pains of the nerves and closes ulcers already hopeless with a scar.
la|Pliny the Elder|Naturalis Historia|35|104|quote="[...] cum pingeret '''poppyzonta''' retinentem eum."

la|Pliny the Elder||VIII|12|text=Antiocho vadum fluminis experienti renuit Aiax, alioqui dux agminis semper. Tum pronuntiatum eius fore principatum qui transisset, ausumque Patroclum ob id phaleris argenteis, quo maxime gaudent, et reliquo omni primatu donavit. Ille, qui notabatur, inedia mortem ignominiae praetulit. Mirus namque pudor est, victusque vocem fugit victoris, terram ac verbenas porrigit. Pudore numquam nisi in abdito coeunt, mas '''quinquennis''', femina decennis.

la|Propertius|Elegiae|2|25|22|quote=tū quoque, quī plēnō fastūs assūmis amōre,<br>crēdule, '''nūlla''' diū fēmina pondus habet.|trans=You, too, credulous one, who put on airs because your love is at the full, '''no''' woman can be relied on for long.|transauthor=G. P. Goold|transyear=1990

la|Propertius|Elegiae|2|26b|6|quote=nam mea cum recitat, dīcit sē ōdisse beātōs:<br>carmina tam sānctē '''nūlla''' puella colit.|trans=For when she recites my poems, she says she hates the rich: '''no other''' girl so devoutly worships poetry.|transauthor=G. P. Goold|transyear=1990

la|Prudentius|Psychomachia|518–19|quote=[ingenia] docta, indocta simul, bruta et sapientia, '''nec non'''<br>casta, incesta meae patuerunt pectora dextrae|t=The learned and the unlearned alike, the stupid and the wise, '''and also'''<br>the pure and the impure, have given themselves up to my hand
la|Publilius Syrus|Sententiae|quote=Bonīs '''nocet''' quisquis pepercit malīs.|trans=He '''does harm''' to the good, whoever has been lenient to the bad

la|Publius Terentius Afer|Andria|228|thru=232|quote=MȲSIS: Audīvī, Archylis! Jamdūdum: Lesbiam addūcī jubēs. / Sānē pol illa tēmulentast mulier et temerāria / nec satis digna cui committās prīmō partū mulierem. / Tamen eam addūcam? Importūnitātem spectāte aniculae — / quia '''compōtrīx''' ejus est!|trans=MYSIS: I heard you, Archylis! For a long time now: you’re ordering Lesbia [the midwife] to be brought. (To the audience) Truly, by god, that woman [Lesbia] is drunk and reckless, and not worthy enough for you to entrust a woman in her first childbirth. Shall I bring her anyway? Look at the impropriety of the old woman — just because she’s a '''drinking companion''' of [Archylis]!<br/>(tēmulentast = [[temulenta]] + est)

la|Publius Terentius Afer|Andria|246|thru=247|quote=PAMPHILUS: Prō deum atque hominum fidem! / Nūllōn ego Chremētis pactō '''affīnitātem''' effugere poterō?|trans=PAMPHILUS: By the faith of gods and men! / Is there no way for me to escape the '''kinship''' of Chremes?<br/>(In other words, Pamphilus desperately wants to avoid having an arranged marriage to the daughter of Chremes.)

la|Publius Terentius Afer|Andria|310|quote=Tū sī hīc sīs aliter '''sentiās'''.|trans=If you were in my place, '''you would think''' differently.<br/>(Present subjunctive used for a condition contrary to fact.)

la|Publius Terentius Afer|Andria|37|thru=40|quote=SĪMŌ: [...] Fēcī ex servō ut essēs '''lībertus''' mihi, / proptereā quod servībās līberāliter: / quod habuī summum pretium persolvī tibi.|trans=SIMO: I made you, who were a slave, into a '''freedman''' for me, because you served me like a free man: what I had [in my power] — the greatest reward — I gave to you.

la|Publius Terentius Afer|Andria|380|thru=381|quote=[...] PAMPHILUS: Quidvīs patiar. DĀVUS: ''Pater'' est, Pamphile: / '''difficile''' est. [...].|trans=PAMPHILUS: I’ll endure anything you wish. DAVUS: He’s your ''father'', Pamphilus: it’s '''difficult'''.<br/>(In context: The ''problem'' is “difficult” to resolve in part because Pamphilus’ ''father'' is “difficult” or obstinate.)

la|Publius Terentius Afer|Andria|443|thru=445|quote=DĀVUS: Dum '''licitum est''' eī dumque aetās tulit, / amāvit; tum id clam: cāvit nē umquam īnfāmiae / ea rēs sibi esset, ut virum fortem decet.|trans=DAVUS: While '''it was allowed''' for him and while his [young] age moved him, he had an affair; and then did it privately: being careful that the matter would never bring dishonor upon himself, as a good man should.

la|Publius Terentius Afer|Andria|679|thru=680|quote=DĀVUS: Parum succēdit quod agō, at faciō sēdulō. / Vel, melius tūtē '''reperī'''; mē missum face!|trans=(Translating idiomatically) DAVUS: [There is] little progress to what ''I’m'' doing, but at least I’m doing it diligently. Or, '''why don’t ''you'' come up with''' [a plan that’s] better [and] less dangerous; [then] send me away!

la|Publius Terentius Afer|Andria|825|quote=CHREMĒS: Vidē quam '''inīquō’''' sīs prae studiō!|trans=CHREMES: Look how '''unfair''' you are because of your eagerness!<br/>(The apostrophe indicates [[elision]] with the following word, ''sīs''.)

la|Publius Terentius Afer|Andria|IV|794|thru=795|quote=DĀVUS: Paullum interesse cēnsēs ex animō omnia,<br>ut fert nātūra, faciās an '''dē industriā'''?|trans=DAVUS: Do you think it really matters much whether everything [arises] from instinct — whatever feels right — or from careful premeditation?

la|Quint.||6|3|107|refn=<sup>[https://babel.hathitrust.org/cgi/pt?id=uc1.c003402087&seq=299]</sup>|quote=nam meo quidem iudicio illa est urbanitas, in qua nihil absonum, nihil agreste, nihil inconditum, nihil peregrinum neque sensu neque verbis neque ore gestuve possit deprehendi, ut non tam sit in singulis dictis quam in toto colore dicendi, qualis apud Graecos {{lang|grc|'''{{italic|ἀττικισμός

la|Quintilian|Institutio Oratoria|9|2|4|quote=Quae cum adesse dēbent, tum disponenda atque varianda sunt, ut audītōrem, quod in fidibus fierī vidēmus, omnī sonō '''mulceant'''.|trans=Which, while they need to be present, also are to be arranged and varied, so as to '''delight''' the hearer with all the musicality, as we see with the lyre.

la|Quintilian|Instituto Oratoria|1|3.13|quote=‘habendumque in animo semper illud Vergilianum: adeo in teneris consuescere multum est.’|trans=''‘‘and we must never forget the words of Virgil, "So strong is custom formed in early years."’’''

la|Rupert of Deutz|Commentaria in Apocalypsim|year=c. 1129|book 10, chapter 17|quote=Nam, ut de caeteris taceam, quis '''utiquam''' Romanae civitati populoque et senatui proprio imperatore suo Nerone crudelior aut nequior hostis exstitit?|t=For, to say nothing of others,  who '''in any way''' was a crueler or worse enemy to the Roman city, people and senate than their own emperor Nero?

la|Sallust|Bellum Iugurthinum|73|3|1|quote=Marium fatigantem de profectione, simul et invitum et offensum sibi parum idoneum ratus, domum dimittit. Et Romae '''plebes''' litteris, qua de Metello ac Mario missae erant, cognitis volenti animo de ambobus acceperant.|t=He sent Marius home since the fellow kept pressing for his departure and since at the same time Metellus considered him unsuitable for service because of his discontent and their bad relations. At Rome, too, '''the commons''', upon learning of the letters which had been sent concerning Metellus and Marius, had readily accepted the reports about both men.|transauthor=J. C. Rolfe|transyear=2013

la|Seneca the Elder|Controversiae|10|3|quote=Aiebat tortoribus: “sic intendite, sic caedite, sic istum quem fecit '''cummaxime''' vultum servate, ne sitis ipsi exemplar.”|t=He said to the torturers: “Stretch him like that, flog him like that, keep his present expression '''just so'''—or I’ll make a model of ''you''.”

la|Seneca the Elder|Controversiae|1|21|quote=et statim ipse dicebat sententias quae interponi argumentis '''cummaxime''' declamantis Marulli possent.|t=And he proceeded himself to point out the epigrams which could have been interspersed in the arguments of Marullus, '''at that time''' mid-declamation.

la|Seneca the Younger|Epistulae Morales ad Lucilium|1|1|1|quote=Turpissima tamen est iactūra quae per '''neglegentiam''' fit.|trans=The worst [use of time], however, is [what gets] thrown away, which happens through '''neglect'''.<br/>(Neuter plurals “turpissima,” “iactura,” and “quae” relate to the implied third declension neuter plural “tempora”: passages of time or moments in time.)

la|Seneca the Younger|Epistulae Morales ad Lucilium|1|1|2|quote=Quem mihi dabis quī aliquod '''pretium''' temporī pōnat, quī diem aestimet, quī intellegat sē cotīdiē morī?|trans=What man can you show me who places any '''value''' on [his] time, who can reckon the worth of a day, who understands himself to be dying every day?

la|Seneca the Younger|Epistulae Morales ad Lucilium|1|1|4|quote=Nōn possum dīcere nihil perdere, sed quid perdam et quārē et quemadmodum dīcam; causās '''paupertātis''' meae reddam.|trans=I cannot claim to waste nothing, but I can say what I waste and how; I can explain the causes '''of''' my '''poverty'''.<br/>(The financially wealthy Seneca writes with playful irony about a perceived lack of ''time'' and admits that it is something he doesn’t always spend wisely.)

la|Seneca the Younger|Epistulae Morales ad Lucilium|1|1|5|quote=Nam ut vīsum est maiōribus nostrīs, ‘sērā parsimōniā in fundō est’; nōn enim tantum minimum in īmō sed pessimum '''remanet'''.|trans=For, as it was understood by our ancestors, “thrift comes too late at the bottom [of the wine container]”; for not only the least but the worst [part is what] '''remains''' near the end.<br/>(Seneca here echoes the Greek poet Hesiod, ''Works and Days'', 368-369, offering wine as a metaphor for life: whatever the portion, consume it wisely, and the sooner the better.)

la|Seneca the Younger|Epistulae Morales ad Lucilium|1|1|5|quote=Tū tamen malō servēs tua, et bonō tempore '''incipiēs'''.|trans=[As for] you, however, I would rather you safeguard [your time], and [now is] the optimal moment '''for you to begin'''.<br/>(In other words, it is never too late to appreciate the value of a lifetime.)

la|Seneca the Younger|Epistulae Morales ad Lucilium|1|2|2|quote=Certīs ingeniīs immorārī et innūtrīrī oportet, sī velīs aliquid '''trahere''' quod in animō fidēliter sedeat.|trans=You must linger among certain distinguished writers, and nourish yourself [upon their books], if you wish '''to derive''' anything that will be held reliably in your mind.<br/>(Note the possible dual meaning: initially ''to extract'' words or meaning from a text, and also ''to ponder'' something memorable.)

la|Seneca the Younger|Epistulae Morales ad Lucilium|1|2|4|quote=Aliquid cotīdiē adversus paupertātem, aliquid adversus mortem auxilī comparā, nec minus adversus cēterās pestēs; et cum multa percurreris, ūnum excerpe quod illō diē '''concoquās'''.|trans=Provide yourself daily with something [written that is] helpful against poverty, something against death, and no less against other plagues; and when you have run through many [good examples], select one '''for you to reflect upon and thoroughly digest''' that same day.<br/>(A few lines prior Seneca compares reading to proper digestion, so here he means thinking more deeply about an excerpt from a book, and no mere passing notice.)

la|Seneca the Younger|Epistulae Morales ad Lucilium|47|12|quote=“At ego,” inquis, “nūllum habeō dominum.” Bona aetās est: forsitan habēbis. Nescīs quā aetāte Hecubā servīre '''coeperit''', quā Croesus, quā Dārēī māter, quā Platōn, quā Diogenēs?|trans=“But I have no master,” you say. Your age is appropriate: perhaps you will have one. Do you not know at what age [[Hecuba]] '''began''' to be enslaved; or [[Croesus]]; or ([[Sisygambis]]), the mother of [[Darius]]; or [[Plato]]; or [[Diogenes]]?<br/>(Third-person singular perfect active subjunctive of ''coepī'' used here in an indirect question following ''nescīs''.)

la|Seneca the Younger|Epistulae Morales ad Lucilium|47|17|quote=“Servus est.” Sed fortasse līber animō. “Servus est.” Hoc illī '''nocēbit'''?|trans=“He is a slave.” But perhaps he’s free in spirit. “He is a slave.” [Why] '''will''' this '''bring harm''' to that [man]?<br/>(Third-person singular future indicative verb ''nocēbit'' forms a question that takes the dative case for its object: ''illī''.)

la|Seneca the Younger|Epistulae morales ad Lucilium|87|9|quote=M. Cato Censorius, quem tam rei publicae fuit nasci quam Scipionem (alter enim cum hostibus nostris bellum, alter cum moribus gessit), cantherio vehebatur et '''hippoperis''' quidem impositis, ut secum utilia portaret.|t=Cato the Elder, him being born indeed healsome for the society like Scipio (for the one fought war with our foes, the other without our mores), rode along with a gelding and merely two '''saddlebags''' on it to stow his belongings.

la|Seneca the Younger|Medea|1|13|quote=nunc, nunc adeste, sceleris '''ultrices''' deae, crinem solutis squalidae serpentibus, atram cruentis manibus amplexae facem|trans=Now, now be present, you goddesses, you '''avengeresses''' of crime; come with your hair adorned with loose, squalid serpents, come embracing the black torch with your blood-stained hands.

la|Seneca the Younger|Naturales quaestiones|II|56,1|text=Tonitrua nos '''pluraliter''' dicimus; antiqui autem tonitruum dixerunt aut tonum.|t=We use the word thunder '''in the plural''', but our forefathers used it in the singular or called it ''tonum''.

la|Servius|In Vergilii Aeneidem commentarii|1|651|quote=hinc etiam apud Romanos '''Thalassio''' invocatur. cum enim in raptu Sabinarum plebeius quidam raptam pulcherrimam duceret, ne ei auferretur ab aliis, Thalassionis eam ducis nobilis esse simulavit, cuius nomine fuit puellae tuta virginitas.|trans=Because of this, "'''Thalassio'''" is also invoked amongst the Romans. When, during the rape of the Sabines, the plebeians were leading a certain captured beauty, they pretended she was of a noble leader, by whose name her virginity was safeguarded, so that others would not take her from Thalassius.

la|Sextus Julius Frontinus|Strategemata|1|10|4|1|year=c. 84-96 AD|quote='''Scorylo''', dux Dacorum, cum sciret dissociatum armis civilibus populum Romanum neque tamen sibi temptandum arbitraretur, quia externo bello posset concordia inter cives coalescere, duos canes in conspectu popularium commisit iisque acerrime inter ipsos pugnantibus lupum ostendit,quem protinus canes omissa inter se ira aggressi sunt: quo exemplo prohibuit barbaros ab impetu Romanis profuturo.

la|Sextus Pompeius Festus|De Verborum Significatione|quote=Poenitam offam Naevius appellpat '''absegmen''' carnis cum coda: antiqui autem offam vocabant abscisum globi forma, ut manu glomeratam pultem
la|Sextus Pompeius Festus|De verborum significatione|344.34|quote="...<Spa>tiātōrem, '''errātōrem''' Catō in M."

la|Sidonius Apollinaris|Epistolae|year=c. 489|quote=Ipse hic Parthicus Arsaces precatur, aulae Susidis ut tenere culmen possit foedere sub stipendiali. Nam quod partibus arma Bosphoranis grandi hinc surgere sentit apparatu, maestam Persida iam sonum ad duelli ripa '''Euphratide''' vix putat tuendam; qui cognata licet sibi astra fingens Phoebea tumeat propinquitate, mortalem hic tamen implet obsecrando.|t=Here even the Parthian Arsaces prays that he may be enabled to keep the towering palace of Susa under covenant of tribute; for perceiving that an armament with a vast muster of warlike might is surging up from here to take the side of Constantinople, he thinks that Persia, depressed at the very sound of war, can scarcely be defended by '''the Euphrates’''' bank; and although he feigns himself related to the stars, and vaunts his kinship with Phoebus the Sun, here in Bordeaux he plays a mortal’s part by making supplication.|transauthor=W. B. Anderson|transyear=1965

la|Sidonius Apollinaris|Letters|7|7|4|quote=parum in commūne cōnsulitis; et, cum in concilium convenītis, nōn tam cūrae est pūblicīs medērī perīculīs quam prīvātīs studēre fortūnīs; quod utique saepe diūque facientēs iam nōn prīmī '''comprōvinciālium''' coepistis esse, sed ultimī.|t=You consider the common good too little; and, when you come together into a council, there is not so much concern to remedy public dangers than to pursue private fortunes. At any rate, because of you doing this often and for a long time, you have already begun to be not the first of the '''comprovincial''', but the last.
la|Statius|Achilleid|1|917|quote=Nec tamen '''abnuerit''' generō sē iungere tālī.|t=Nor will he '''refuse''' to join with such a son in law.

la|Statius|Silvae|5|2|136|quote=an iuga Pannoniae mutatoresque domorum / Sauromatas quaties? an te '''septenus''' habebit / Hister et umbroso circumflua coniuge Peuce?|t=Or shall you shake Pannonia’s ridges and nomad Sarmatians? Or shall '''sevenfold''' Hister have you, and Peuce, surrounded by her spouse’s shady stream?|transauthor=D. R. Shackleton Bailey|transyear=2015

la|Statius|Thebais|1|561|quote=Nōn īnscia suāsit / rēligiō, magnīs exercita clādibus ōlim / '''plēbs''' Argīva lita(n)t; animōs advertite, pandam.|notes=Manuscripts vary in this line between plural "litant", which would be a case of notional agreement, and singular "litat". The final syllable of the verb scans as heavy: this would be anomalous if the word is "litat", since the following word starts with a vowel. Lengthening of final syllables in this context is an attested poetic license, but one rarely used by Statius.

la|Statius|Thebais|7|271|quote=Ecce autem clamore ruunt Neptunia '''plebes''' / Onchesti, quos pinigeris Mycalesos in agris|notes=Some manuscripts instead read "Neptunia proles" (a phrase used several times in the Aeneid), which is preferred by Hill.<ref>{{cite-book|page=135|pageurl=https://books.google.com/books?id=Nf_0DwAAQBAJ&newbks=1&pg=PA135|year=1994|last=Smolenaars|first=J.J.L.|title=Statius Thebaid VII: A Commentary

la|Suetonius|De Vita Caesarum|87|2|quote=Ponit assidue et pro stulto "baceolum" et pro pullo "pulleiaceum" et pro cerrito "vacerrosum" et "vapide" se habere pro male et "'''betizare'''" pro languere, quod vulgo "lachanizare" dicitur|t=He also habitually used "''baceolus''" (dolt) for "''stultus''" (fool), "''pulleiaceus''" (darkish) for "''pullus''" (dark), "''vacerrosus''" (blockhead) for "''cerritus''" (mad); also "''vapide se habere''" (to feel flat) for "''male se habere''" (to feel bad) and '''"betizare"''' (to be like a beet) for "''languere''" (to be weak) which is "''lanchanizare''" in vulgar terms

la|Suetonius|De vita Caesarum|2|10|quote=Omnium bellōrum initium et causam hinc sūmpsit: nihil convenientius dūcēns quam necem avunculī vindicāre tuērīque ācta, '''cōnfestim''' ut Apollōniā rediit, Brūtum Cassiumque et vī necopīnantīs et, quia prōvīsum perīcu­lum subterfūgerant, lēgibus adgredī reōsque caedis absentīs dēferre statuit.|trans=The source and cause of all the wars he took from this: holding nothing more fitting than to avenge his uncle and maintain the validity of his enactments, '''immediately''' on returning from Apollonia he resolved to take the unexpecting Brutus and Cassius by force as well as to resort to laws and prosecute them for murder in their absence, as they had fled the foreseen danger.

la|Suetonius|De vita Caesarum|4|37|quote=Nepōtātus sūmptibus omnium prōdigōrum ingenia superāvit, commentus novum balneārum ūsum, portentōsissima genera cibōrum atque cēnārum, ut calidīs frīgidīsque unguentīs lavārētur, prētiōsissima margarīta acētō liquefacta sorbēret, convīvīs ex aurō pānēs et '''obsōnia''' appōneret, aut frūgī hominem esse oportere dictitāns aut Caesarem.|trans=In the devices of his profuse expenditure, he surpassed all the prodigals that ever lived; inventing a new kind of bath, with strange dishes and suppers, washing in precious unguents, both warm and cold, drinking pearls of immense value dissolved in vinegar, and serving up for his guests loaves and other '''victuals''' modelled in gold; often saying, " that a man ought either to be a good economist or an emperor."|transyear=1889|transauthor=Alexander Thomson

la|Suetonius|De vita Caesarum|5|41|quote=Historiam in adulēscentia hortante T. Līviō, Sulpiciō vērō Flāvō etiam adiuvante, scrībere adgressus est. Et cum prīmum frequentī auditōriō commīsisset, aegrē perlēgit refrīgerātus saepe ā sēmet ipsō. Nam cum initiō recitātiōnis dēfrāctīs complūribus subsellīs obēsitāte cuiusdam rīsus exortus esset, nē sēdātō quidem tumultū temperāre potuit, quīn ex intervāllō subinde factī reminīscerētur '''cachinnōs'''que revocāret.|trans=In his youth he undertook to write a history, urged by [[w:Livy|Livy]] and helped by Sulpicius Flavus. And when he first called together a numerous auditory, he read it poorly and often interrupted by no one but himself. For when, at the beginning of the recitation, laughter was roused by more benches broken by somebody's fatness, not even with the tumult sedated could he calm down, but from time to time remembered the event and brought '''laughter''' back.

la|Suetonius|De vita Caesarum|Galbae|VII.|quote=Ordinavitque magna severitatis ac iustitiae cura, etiam in parvulis rebus. Militi, qui per expeditionem artissima annona residuum cibariorum tritici modium centum denariis vendidisse arguebatur, vetuit, simul atque indigere cibo coepisset, a quoquam opem ferri; et is fame extabuit. At in iure dicendo cum de '''proprietate''' iumenti quaereretur, levibus utrimque argumentis et testibus ideoque difficili coniectura veritatis, ita decrevit ut ad lacum, ubi adaquari solebat, duceretur capite involuto atque ibidem revelato, eius esset, ad quem sponte se a potu recepisset.|t=His administration was distinguished by great strictness and equity, even in matters of small importance. A soldier upon some expedition being charged with selling, in a great scarcity of corn, a bushel of wheat, which was all he had left, for a hundred denarii, he forbad him to be relieved by anybody, when he came to be in want himself: and accordingly he died of famine. When sitting in judgment, a cause being brought before him about some beast of burden, the '''attribution''' of which was claimed by two persons; the evidence being slight on both sides, and it being difficult to come at the truth, he ordered the beast to be led to the pond at which he had used to be watered, with his head muffled up, and the covering being there removed, that he should be the property of the person whom he followed of his own accord, after drinking.

la|Tac.|Germania|34|2|1|quote=[[ipsum]] [[quīn]] [[etiam]] [[Ōceanum]] [[illā]] [[temptāvimus]]; [[et]] [[superesse]] [[adhūc]] '''Herculis Columnās''' [[fāma]] [[vulgāvit]], [[sīve]] [[adiit]] [[Herculēs]], [[seu]] [[quicquid]] [[ubīque]] [[magnificum]] [[est]], [[in]] [[clāritātem]] [[ejus]] [[referre]] [[cōnsēnsimus]].|trans=Indeed, we even attempted the Ocean itself with that, and the rumour spread that the '''Pillars of Hercules''' still exist, whether Hercules reached them or we agreed to attribute whatever is magnificent anywhere in the world to his glory.

la|Tacitus|Annales|11|2|quote=Ipsa ad perniciem Poppaeae festinat subditis qui terrore carceris ad '''voluntariam mortem''' propellerent.|trans=She (Messalina) is accelerating Poppaea's destruction by suborned agents that they might drive her with a great fear of prison to (commit) '''suicide'''.
la|Tacitus|Annales|1|4|quote=hunc et prima ab infantia eductum in domo '''regnatrice'''|t=From the earliest infancy he had been raised in an '''imperial''' house.

la|Tacitus|Annales|3|61|quote=Prīmī omnium Ephesiī adiēre, memorantēs nōn, ut vulgus crēderet, Diānam atque Apollinem Dēlō genitōs: esse apud sē Cenchrium amnem, lūcum Ortygiam, ubi Lātōnam partū gravidam et oleae, quae tum etiam maneat, '''adnīsam''' ēdidisse ea nūmina, deōrumque monitū sacrātum nemus, atque ipsum illīc Apollinem post interfectōs Cyclōpās lovis īram vītāvisse.|trans=First went the Ephesians, reminding that Diana and Apollo weren't born, as people believe, on Delos: that in their region there was the river Cenchrius and the grove Ortygia, where Latona, pregnant with her issue and '''leant''' on an olive tree which survives even these days, gave birth to those gods; and the grove was sacred by the gods' injunction, and that Apollo himself had avoided the anger of Jupiter after killing the Cyclops.

la|Tacitus|Annals|13|14|quote=Nōn '''abnuere''' se, quīn cūncta īnfēlīcīs domūs mala patefīerent, suae in prīmīs nūptiae, suum venēficium.|t=She didn't '''reject''' that all the evils of the unhappy house be made known, her marriage first of all, and her poisoning.

la|Tacitus|Histories|4|44|quote=Octāvius Pontiam Postumīnam, stuprō cognitam et nūptiās suās '''abnuentem''', impotēns amōris interfēcerat, Sosiānus prāvitāte mōrum multīs exitiōsus.|t=Octavius, in impotent jealousy, murdered Pontia Postumina, whom he'd had an affair with and who '''refused''' to marry him, while Sosianus in his depravity proved ruinous to many.
la|Ter.|Heaut.|271|thru=273|text=ego te autem novi quăm ĕsse soleas inpotens;<br>inversa verba, eversas cervices tuas,<br>gemitus '''screatus''' tussis risus abstine.

la|Terence|Andria|2|364|quote=Maneo. Interea intro ire neminem<br>video, exire neminem; matronam '''nullam''' in aedibus,<br>nil ornati, nil tumulti: accessi; intro aspexi.|t=I waited. During this time I saw nobody go inside, nobody come out; '''not a''' married woman in the house, no preparations, no bustle. I went up and looked inside.|transauthor=John Barsby|transyear=2001

la|Terence|Heauton Timorumenos|357|quote=Hīc sīquid nōbīs forte advorsī ēvēnerit,<br>tibi erunt parāta verba, huic hominī verbera:<br>quāpropter haec rēs '''ne‿ŭtĭquam''' neglēctust mihi.|notes=Iambic senarius|t=If by chance anything here goes wrong for us,<br>There will be words for you, lashes for myself here:<br>Therefore this matter is '''by no means''' something for me to disregard.

la|Tertullian|Ad nationes libri duo|1|8|quote=Age nunc, perseuerauerit Philomelae medicamentis ⟨ . . . .⟩ quam et ipsam prudentiores non linguae caede, sed ⟨ra⟩p⟨ti pu⟩doris rubore mutam interpretantur. Si ergo vixit, ⟨potuit⟩ effutire aliquid : obtusum et exarticulatum sonum tinnitumque sine modulatu labellorum, expanso ore, lingua stupente de solis faucibus cogi licet. Id fors tunc infantes, quia unicum, facilius commentati paulo modulatius, utpote '''linguatul⟨i⟩''' ⟨in⟩ inventum alicuius interpretationis impegeri<n>t.|t=Come, even suppose that by the remedies of a Philomela she retained her life, in the way supposed by wisest persons, who account for the dumbness not by cutting out the tongue, but from the blush of shame; if on such a supposition she lived, she would still be able to blurt out some dull sound. And a shrill inarticulate noise from opening the mouth only, without any modulation of the lips, might be forced from the mere throat, though there were no tongue to help. This, it is probable, the infants readily imitated, and the more so because it was the only sound; only they did it a little more neatly, as they '''had tongues'''; and then they attached to it a definite signification. |transauthor=Peter Holmes|transyear=1869

la|Tertullian|Apologeticus|11|8|quote=Ceterum si propterea Liber deus, quod vitem demonstravit, male cum Lucullo actum est, qui primus '''cerasia''' ex Ponto Italiae promulgavit, quod non est propterea consecratus ut frugis novae auctor, qui ostensor.|trans=But if Bacchus is made a god because he discovered the grapevine, Lucullus, who first introduced '''cherries''' from Pontus to Italy, has not been fairly dealt with; for as the discoverer of a new fruit, he has not, as though he were its creator, been awarded divine honours.

la|Tertullian|De Pallio|1|3|quote=Equidem haud mīror prae documentō superiōre. Nam et ariētem (nōn quem Laberius reciprocicornem ait, lānicutem et '''testitrahum''', sed trabēs māchina est quae mūrōs frangere mīlitat) nēminī unquam adhūc lībrātum illa dicitur Carthago, 'studiīs asperrima bellī', prīma omnium armāsse in oscillum pendulī impetūs, commentāta vim tormentī dēbile pecoris caput vindicantis.|trans=I'm not surprised at all on account of a previous example. For the ram too (not the one whom [[w:Decimus Laberius|Laberius]] calls reciprocally-horned, wooly-skinned and '''testicle-dragging''', but the siege weapon that smashes walls), not swung into anyone yet, Carthage, 'the toughest in the arts of war', is said to have first mobilised in the oscillation of violence, having realised the power of the engine by analogy of the anger of the beast that avenges itself with its head.

la|Tertullian|De spectaculis|27|quote=Nemo venenum temperat felle et elleboro, sed conditis pulmentis et bene saporatis, et plurimum dulcibus id mali inicit. Ita et diabolus letale quod conficit rebus dei gratissimis et acceptissimis imbuit. Omnia illic seu fortia seu honesta seu sonora seu canora seu subtilia [perinde/proinde] habe ac [si] stillicidia mellis de '''libacunculo''' venenato nec tanti gulam facias voluptatis quanti periculum per suavitatem.|t=No one mixes poison with gall and hellebore; no, it is into delicacies well made, well flavoured, and, for the most part, sweet things, that he drops the venom. So does the devil; the deadly draught he brews, he flavours with the most agreeable, the most welcome gifts of God. So count all you find there—brave and honest, resounding, musical, exquisite—as so much honey dripping from a poisoned '''bit of pastry'''; and do not count your appetite for the pleasure worth the risk in the sweetness.|transauthor=T.R. Glover<ref>[https://archive.org/details/apologydespectac00tertuoft/page/292/ Tertullian. Apology. de Spectaculis. with an English Translation by T.R. Glover.]</ref>|transyear=1931

la|Titus Livius|Ab Urbe Condita|3|38|quote=Circumspectare omnibus fori partibus senatorem raroque usquam noscitare; curiam inde ac solitudinem circa decemviros intueri, cum et ipsi consensu invisum imperium et plebs, quia privatis ius non esset vocandi senatum, non convenire patres interpretarentur: iam caput fieri libertatem repetentium, si se plebs comitem senatui det, et quem ad modum patres vocati non coeant in senatum, sic plebs abnuat dilectum. Haec fremunt '''plebes'''.|t=Men looked about in every corner of the Forum to discover a senator, and seldom recognized one anywhere; then their glances rested on the Curia and the decemvirs sitting there alone. Meantime the decemvirs themselves explained the Fathers’ failure to assemble as owing to the universal detestation of their rule; the commons as due to their having no authority, being private citizens, to convoke the senate: a beginning, it seemed, was already being made towards the recovery of freedom, if the plebs would join with the senate; and if, even as the Fathers were refusing, when summoned, to attend the session, so they, for their part, would reject the levy. Such were the murmurs of the '''plebs'''.|transauthor=B. O. Foster|transyear=1922|notes=categorized by Pinkster 2015:1289 as singular with notional agreement.<ref>{{cite-book|page=1289|last=Pinkster|first=Harm|year=2015|title=The Oxford Latin Syntax: Volume 1: The Simple Clause|publisher=Oxford University Press

la|Varro|De Lingua Latina|5|110|quote='''Insicia''' ab eo quod insecta caro, ut in Carmine Saliorum <prosicium> est, quod in extis dicitur nunc prosectum.|t=''Insicia'' ‘minced meat’ from this, that the meat is ''insecta'' ‘cut up,’ just as in the ''Song of the Salii'' the word ''prosicium'' ‘slice’ is used, for which, in the offering of the vitals, the word ''prosectum'' is now used.|transauthor=Roland G. Kent|transyear=1938

la|Varro|Res Rusticae|1|49|2|quote=Dicam, inquit, de fructibus maturis capiendis. Primum de pratis summissis herba, cum crescere desiit et aestu arescit, subsecari falcibus debet et, quaad perarescat, furcillis versari; cum perarvit, de his manipulos fieri ac vehi ad villam; tum de pratis stipulam rastellis eradi atque addere faenisiciae cumulum. Quo facto '''sicilienda''' prata, id est falcibus consectanda quae faenisices praeterierunt ac quasi herba tuberosum reliquerunt campum. A qua sectione arbitror dictum '''''sicilire''''' pratum.|trans=he continued: “I shall discuss next the subject of harvesting the ripe crops. First the grass on the hay-meadows should be cut close with the sickle when it ceases to grow and begins to dry from the heat, and turned with the fork while it is drying out; when it is quite dry it should be made into bundles and hauled to the barn. Then the loose hay from the meadows should be raked up and added to the hay-pile. After doing this you should ‘'''sickle'''’ the meadows—that is, cut with the sickle what the mowers have passed over, leaving the field humped, as it were, with tufts of grass. I suppose the verb '''''sicilire''''', used with meadow as object, is derived from this cutting (''sectio'').|transauthor=W. D. Hooper, Harrison Boyd Ash.|transyear=1934
la|Verg.|A.|4|615|thru=618|text=bellō audācis populī uexātus et armīs,<br>fīnibus '''extorris''', complexū āuulsus Iūlī<br>auxilium implōret uideatque indigna suōrum<br>fūnera;{{...

la|Vergil|Aeneid|7|568|thru=571|quote=Hīc '''specus''' horrendum et saevī spīracula Dītis<br>mōnstrantur, ruptōque ingēns Acherōnte vorāgō<br>pestiferās aperit faucēs, quīs condita Erīnȳs,<br>invīsum nūmen, terrās caelumque levābat.|trans=Here the horrible '''cave''' and the breathing hole of the cruel Dis<br>is shown, and a giant whirlpool, with the Acheron burst forth,<br>opens its pestilential jaws, in which Erinys,<br>hated god, relieved the Earth and the heavens by hiding.

la|Vergil|Georgics|2|346|thru=353|text=Quod superest, quaecumque premes virgulta per agros,<br>Sparge fimo '''pingui''' et multa memor occule terra,<br>Aut lapidem bibulum aut squalentis infode conchas;<br>Inter enim labentur aquae tenuisque subibit<br>Halitus atque animos tollent sata; iamque reperti,<br>Qui saxo super atque ingentis pondere testae<br>Urgerent; hoc effusos munimen ad imbris,<br>Hoc, ubi hiulca siti findit canis aestifer arva.|t=For the rest, whate'er<br>The sets thou plantest in thy fields, thereon<br>Strew refuse '''rich''', and with abundant earth<br>Take heed to hide them, and dig in withal<br>Rough shells or porous stone, for therebetween<br>Will water trickle and fine vapour creep,<br>And so the plants their drooping spirits raise.<br>Aye, and there have been, who with weight of stone<br>Or heavy potsherd press them from above;<br>This serves for shield in pelting showers, and this<br>When the hot dog-star chaps the fields with drought.|transauthor={{w|James B. Greenough

la|Virgil|Aeneid|1|527|thru=528|quote=“Nōn nōs aut ferrō Libycōs populāre Penātīs<br/>vēnimus, aut raptās ad lītora vertere '''praedās'''.”|trans=''“We come neither to pillage by sword the household gods of Libya, nor to drive captured '''plunder''' to the shores.”''<br/>(The plunder “driven” or “turned” implies taking herds of animals; it might also mean taking humans into slavery.)

la|Virgil|Aeneid|1|569|thru=571|quote=“Seu vōs Hesperiam magnam Sāturniaque arva,<br/>sīve Erycīs fīnīs rēgemque optātis Acestēn,<br/>auxiliō tūtōs '''dīmittam''', opibusque iuvābō.”|trans=“Whatever your choices – great Hesperia and the fields of Saturn, or the land of Eryx and King Acestes – '''I shall send''' [you] '''forth''' with protective escorts, and help with supplies.” – Queen Dido

la|Virgil|Aeneid|1|67|thru=68|quote=“Gēns '''inimīca''' mihī Tyrrhēnum nāvigat aequor,<br/>Īlium in Ītaliam portāns vīctōsque Penātēs.”|trans=''“A race '''inimical''' to me is sailing the calm Tyrrhenian Sea, bringing Ilium to Italy, along with [their] conquered household-gods.”''<br/>(Juno is describing the Trojan war survivors led by Aeneas. See: {{w|Tyrrhenian Sea

la|Virgil|Aeneid|1|88|thru=89|quote='''Ēripiunt''' subitō nūbēs caelumque diemque<br/>Teucrōrum ex oculīs; pontō nox incubat ātra.|trans=''Stormclouds suddenly '''take away''' both sky and day[light] from the eyes of the Trojans; black night broods upon the sea.''<br/>(“They take away, suddenly, stormclouds…”: The poet exploits Latin’s flexible word-order and begins line 88 with the energetic verb “ēripiunt.” Note: The Trojans were “Teucrians” or descendants of {{w|King Teucer

la|Virgil|Aeneid|2|279|thru=280|quote=“[...] Ultrō flēns ipse vidēbar<br/>compellāre virum et maestās '''exprōmere''' vōcēs: [...].”|trans=“[In my dream,] spontaneously weeping myself, I seemed to address [Hector] and '''to utter''' sorrowful words: [...].”

la|Virgil|Aeneid|2|285|thru=286|quote=“‘[...] Quae causa indigna '''serēnōs''' / foedāvit voltūs? [...].’”|trans=''“‘What shameful cause disfigured your '''serene''' face?’”''<br/>(Aeneas dreams he is speaking to the dead and disfigured Hector. The Latin plural “serenos voltus,” here translated as English singular, implies a heroic character which projects steadfast calm despite changing circumstances.)

la|Virgil|Aeneid|2|289|quote=“‘Heu fuge, nāte deā, tēque hīs, ait, '''ēripe''' flammīs.’”|trans=[Aeneas recalls Hector’s dire warning:] “‘Alas! Flee, goddess-born,’ [Hector] says, ‘and '''deliver''' yourself from these flames!’”

la|Virgil|Aeneid|2|48|thru=49|quote=“Equō nē crēdite, Teucrī.<br/>Quicquid id est, timeō Danaōs, et dōna '''ferentīs'''.”|trans=“Trojans, do not trust the horse! Whatever it is, I fear the Greeks, even [when they are] '''bearing''' gifts.” – Laocoön

la|Virgil|Aeneid|2|49|quote=[[w:en:Timeo Danaos et dona ferentes|Equo ne credite, Teucri! '''Quidquid''' id est, timeo Danaos et dona ferentes]].|trans=Do not trust the horse, Trojans! '''Whatever''' it is, I fear the Greeks even if they are bearing gifts.

la|Virgil|Aeneid|2|581|thru=582|quote=“‘Occiderit ferrō Priamus? Troiā ārserit ignī?<br/>Dardanium '''totiēns''' sūdārit sanguine lītus?’”|trans=“‘[After] Priam has fallen by the sword? With Troy consumed by fire? The Dardan shore having sweated blood '''so many times'''?’”<br/>(An expression of surprise or indignation posed as questions using three future perfect verbs: ''occiderit, ārserit, sūdārit.'' Here, “totiēns” refers to the bloodshed throughout the Trojan War.)

la|Virgil|Aeneid|2|606|thru=607|quote=“‘[...] Tū nē qua parentis / '''iussa''' timē, neu praeceptīs pārēre recūsā.’”|trans=''“‘You, [my son] – That which [your divine] parent '''has ordered''', fear not, nor refuse to obey [what she] has instructed.’”''<br/>(Aeneas recalls the words of his mother, Venus.)

la|Virgil|Aeneid|3|192|thru=193|quote=Postquam altum tenuēre ratēs, nec iam amplius ūllae<br/>adpārent terrae, caelum '''undique''' et '''undique''' pontus|trans=“After [our] ships held the deep, now neither [was there] any more sight of land: the sky [was] '''all around''' [us], and '''everywhere''' the sea.”<br/>(An example of [[hyperbole]] or exaggeration in a figure of speech.)

la|Virgil|Aeneid|4|129-130|quote=Ōceanum intereā surgēns Aurōra relīquit.<br/>It portīs '''iubare''' exortō dēlēcta iuventūs [...].|trans=Meanwhile Aurora, rising, departs from Oceanus. [Then,] '''with Dawn’s radiance''' having shone forth, chosen youth go out the [city] gates [...].

la|Virgil|Aeneid|4|141-142|quote=[...] Ipse ante aliōs pulcherrimus omnis<br/>īnfert sē socium Aenēās atque agmina '''iungit'''.|trans=[The Trojan leader] himself, before all others, most handsome — Aeneas comes forward as [Dido’s] companion, and also '''unites''' [their combined] ranks.<br/>(Symbolic of personal, civic and military alliances as Dido and Aeneas, Carthaginians and Trojans, join in regal formation for the hunt.)

la|Virgil|Aeneid|4|213|thru=214|quote=“[...] cōnūbia '''nostra''' / reppulit, ac dominum Aenēān in rēgna recēpit.”|trans=''“[The woman …] has rejected '''our''' marriage-offer, and accepted Aeneas as lord in her realm.”''<br/>(King Iarbas, whom Queen Dido has rejected, refers to himself using the “royal we.”'')

la|Virgil|Aeneid|4|271|quote=“Quid '''struis'''? Aut quā spē Libycīs teris ōtia terrīs?”|trans=''“What '''do you think you are doing'''? Or with what [false] hope are you wasting idle hours in the lands of Libya?”''<br/>(Aeneas is overseeing building projects in Carthage just as Mercury arrives to confront him; Mercury’s criticism, however, is less about the physical construction than it is about self-deception. Other translations: West, 1990: “What do you have in mind?”; Fagles, 2006: “What are you plotting now?”; Bartsch, 2020: “What’s your plan?”)

la|Virgil|Aeneid|4|301|thru=303|quote=[...] quālīs commōtīs excitā sacrīs<br/>'''Thyias''', ubi audītō stimulant trietērica Bacchō<br/>orgia, nocturnusque vocat clāmōre Cithaerōn.|trans=[...] like a '''Maenad''', thrilled by the shaken emblems of the god, when the biennial festival rouses her, and, hearing the Bacchic cry, Mount Cithaeron summons her by night with its noise.|transauthor=A. S. Kline|transyear=2002

la|Virgil|Aeneid|4|356|thru=358|quote=“Nunc etiam '''interpres''' dīvom, Iove missus ab ipsō —<br/>testor utrumque caput — celerīs mandāta per aurās<br/>dētulit [...].|trans=''“And now even the '''messenger''' of the gods, sent from Jove himself – I swear by your life and mine – has delivered commands [to me] through the swift winds.”''<br/>(The messenger was [[Mercury]]. Syncopation: “divom” for “divorum”.)

la|Virgil|Aeneid|4|358|thru=359|quote=“[...] ipse deum '''manifēstō in lūmine''' vīdī<br/>intrantem mūrōs, vōcemque hīs auribus hausī.”|trans=“I myself saw – '''with clear [vision], in daylight''' – the god [Mercury] entering the [city] walls, and with these ears I heard his message.”

la|Virgil|Aeneid|4|399|thru=400|quote=Frondentīsque ferunt rēmōs et rōbora silvīs<br/>'''īnfabricāta''', fugae studiō.|trans=And [the Trojans] carry from the woods still-leafy oars and sturdy, '''unhewn''' timbers, [all] in their haste to flee [Carthage].<br/>(The incomplete hexameter of line 4.400 includes Virgil’s only use of “infabricata.”)

la|Virgil|Aeneid|4|460|thru=461|quote=Hinc exaudīrī vōcēs et verba '''vocantīs'''<br/>vīsa virī, nox cum terrās obscūra tenēret.|trans=[Dido’s shrine honoring Sychaeus:] From here, it seemed, she was hearing voices, and words from her [dead] husband '''calling [her name]''', whenever dark night held the lands.

la|Virgil|Aeneid|4|466|thru=468|quote=[...] semperque relinquī / sōla sibī, semper longam '''incomitāta''' vidētur / īre viam, et Tyriōs dēsertā quaerere terrā.|trans=[Dido’s anguished dreams:] and always to be left to herself all alone, forever she seems to go a long way, '''unattended''', and looking for her Tyrian [companions] in a solitary land.

la|Virgil|Aeneid|4|659|thru=660|quote=“'''Moriēmur''' inultae / sed '''moriāmur'''”|trans=''“'''We will die''' unavenged, but '''let us die'''.”''<br/>(Dido here speaks of herself using the royal we or majestic we, which some translations honor, and others alter to first-person singular: “I shall die…”.)

la|Virgil|Aeneid|4|685|quote=[...] Sīc '''fāta''' gradūs ēvāserat altōs [...].|trans=''As she '''had spoken''' these words [Anna] had been climbing the high steps [up to Dido’s pyre…].''<br/>(T.E. Page [1967], pg. 393, notes that “‘fata’ is really a present” tense in this context, i.e.: ''While saying'' these words….)

la|Virgil|Aeneid|4|690-691|quote=Ter sēsē attollēns '''cubitō'''que adnīxa levāvit,<br/>ter revolūta torō est [...].|trans=''Lifting herself three times, [Dido] had tried to raise '''upon''' her '''elbow''', and thrice she had rolled back upon the bed [...].''<br/>(Fratantuono and Smith [2022], pg. 916: “The only elbow in Virgil: another graphic detail as the poet continues his emphasis on the physical.”)

la|Virgil|Aeneid|4|8-9|quote=cum sīc '''ūnanimam''' adloquitur male sāna sorōrem:<br/>“Anna soror, quae mē suspēnsam īnsomnia terrent!”|trans=''When, badly distraught, [Dido] speaks in this way with her '''like-minded''' sister: “Anna, [dear] sister, [I am] restless — what dreams frighten me!”''<br/>(Dido’s closest confidant, her sister Anna, first appears here in the epic. Translations vary – Mackail, 1885: “opens her confidence to her sister”; Knight, 1956: “the sister whose heart was one with hers”; Fagles, 2006: “confides now to the sister of her soul”; Ahl, 2007: “what was her soul’s other self, in a manner, her sister”; Ruden, 2021: “her loving sister”.)

la|Virgil|Aeneid|4|88-89|quote=[...] '''pendent''' opera interrupta, minaeque<br/>mūrōrum ingentēs aequātaque māchina caelō.|trans=[...] Works are interrupted — [pieces] '''hang''' [in mid-air] — [for] the massive battlements of walls and machines level with the sky.<br/>(Cranes, hoists, and scaffolds sit idle — construction of Carthage halts — because the queen has become so distracted: The work is both literally and figuratively “suspended.”)
