room next to the altar or alcove in the altar used for the storage of ecclesiastical objects, usually in the care of the deacon
roughly the same term, but used in folklore context
royal & religious symbol in South & East Asia
rude, also "leader" in the criminal slang

ru|Иван Тургенев|Отцы и дети|1862|quote=Четверть часа спустя оба экипажа остановились перед '''крыльцом''' нового деревянного дома, выкрашенного серою краской и покрытого железною красною крышей.|trans=A quarter of an hour later both carriages drew up in front of the '''porch''' of a new wooden house, painted grey, with a red iron roof.
sad because of a recent disappointment
said of someone else, never of oneself
said of textiles, either from the fibers breaking down, or from the starch used for stiffening wearing off
said when someone uses a vulgar word
same meaning, used at the end of sentences
sauce used for dressing a dish

sa|Daṇḍin|Kāvyādarśa|1|43|quote=श्लिष्टम् अस्पृष्टशैथिल्यम् '''अल्पप्राणा'''क्षरोत्तरम् ।<br>शिथिलं मालतीमाला लोलालिकलिला यथा ॥|t=Cohesion means being untouched by the lax sounds, which largely consist of '''unaspirated''' syllables;<br>Laxity: for example, as in "mālatīmālā lolālikalilā" (a garland of jasmines in the throng of tossing bees).

sa||AV|11|8|22|quote='''निन्दाश्''' च वा अनिन्दाश् च यच् च हन्तेति नेति च ।<br>शरीरं श्रद्धा दक्षिणाश्रद्धा चानु प्राविशन् ॥|trans='''Reproaches''', freedom from reproach, all blamable, all blameless deeds,<br>Bounty, belief, and unbelief entered the body as a home.

sa||AV|11|9|22|quote=ये च॒ धीरा॒ ये चाधी॑राः॒ परा॑ञ्चो बधि॒राश्च॒ ये<br>'''त॑म॒सा''' ये च॑ तूप॒रा अथो॑ बस्ताभिवा॒सिनः॑।<br>सर्वां॒स्ताँ अ॑र्बुदे॒ त्वम॒मित्रे॑भ्यो दृ॒शे कु॑रूदा॒रांश्च॒ प्र द॑र्शय ॥|trans=The clever and the foolish ones, those who are twisted round, the deaf,<br>The '''dusky-hued''', the hornless goats and those whose voice is like the buck's,<br>All these, O Arbudi, do thou make visible to our enemies: cause them to look on mists and fog.

sa||AV|12|4|3|quote=कूटयास्य सं शीर्यन्ते श्लोणया काटमर्दति ।<br>बण्डया दह्यन्ते गृहाः '''काणया''' दीयते स्वम् ॥|t=They perish through a hornless cow, a lame cow sinks them in a pit.<br>Through a maimed cow his house is burnt: a '''one-eyed''' cow destroys his wealth.

sa||AV|15|17|quote=योऽस्य प्रथमो व्यानः सेयं भूमिः ॥<br>योऽस्य द्वितीयो व्यानस्तदन्तरिक्षम् ॥<br>योऽस्य तृतीयो व्यानः सा द्यौः ॥<br>योऽस्य चतुर्थो व्यानस्तानि नक्षत्राणि ॥<br>योऽस्य पञ्चमो व्यानस्त ऋतवः ॥<br>योऽस्य षष्ठो व्यानस्त आर्तवाः ॥<br>योऽस्य '''सप्तमो''' व्यानः स संवत्सरः ॥|trans=His first diffused breath is this Earth.<br>His second diffused breath is that Firmament.<br>His third diffused breath is that Heaven.<br>His fourth diffused breath are those Constellations.<br>His fifth diffused breath are the Seasons.<br>His sixth diffused breath are the Season-groups.<br>His '''seventh''' diffused breath is the year.

sa||AV|4|7|6|quote='''पवस्तैस्''' त्वा पर्य् अक्रीणन् दूर्शेभिर् अजिनैर् उत ।<br>प्रक्रीर् असि त्वम् ओषधे ऽभ्रिखाते न रूरुपः ॥|trans=[People] have traded you for '''garments''', woven cloths, and deer-skins.<br>O Plant, dug up with a pickaxe, you are a thing of sale; do not cause us harm!

sa||AV|4|7|6|quote=पवस्तैस् त्वा पर्य् अक्रीणन् '''दूर्शेभिर्''' अजिनैर् उत ।<br>प्रक्रीर् असि त्वम् ओषधे ऽभ्रिखाते न रूरुपः ॥|trans=[People] have traded you for garments, '''woven cloths''', and deer-skins.<br>O Plant, dug up with a pickaxe, you are a thing of sale; do not cause us harm!

sa||AV|6|119|3|quote=वैश्वानरः '''पविता''' मा पुनातु यत् संगरम् अभिधावाम्य् आशाम् ।<br>अनाजानन् मनसा याचमानो यत् तत्रैनो अप तत् सुवामि ॥|trans=May Vaiśvānara '''the Purifier''' purify me when I oppose their (my debtors') hope and break my promise,<br>Unknowing in my heart. With supplication, whatever guilt there is in that, I banish.

sa||AV|9|6|53|quote=यद्वा '''अतिथिपतिर्'''अतिथीन् परिविष्य गृहानुपोदैत्यवभृथमेव तदुपावैति ॥|t=Or if the '''host''', having offered food to his guest, goes up to the house, he virtually enters the bath of purification.

sa||AV|9|8|1|quote='''हरिमाणं''' ते अङ्गेभ्योऽप्वामन्तरोदरात्।<br>यक्ष्मोधामन्तरात्मनो बहिर्निर्मन्त्रयामहे ॥|trans='''The yellow Jaundice''' from thy limbs, and Colic from the parts within,<br>And Phthisis from thine inward soul we charm away with this our spell.

sa||BhP|3|14|47|quote=स वै महाभागवतो महात्मा महानुभावो महतां '''महिष्ठः''' ।<br>प्रवृद्धभक्त्या ह्यनुभाविताशये निवेश्य वैकुण्ठमिमं विहास्यति ॥|t=Verily, he would be the greatest devotee of unlimited vision and of great prowess and '''the greatest''' of the great. For, by his deep devotion, he will establish Lord Viṣṇu in his heart, purified by devotion, and give up the ego about his body.

sa||BhP|3|19|23|quote=तदा दितेः समभवत्सहसा हृदि वेपथुः। स्मरन्त्या भर्तुरादेशं स्तनाच्च्'''आसृक्''' प्रसुस्रुवे॥|t=At that very moment, a shudder suddenly ran through the heart of Diti, the mother of Hiraṇyākṣa. She recalled the words of her husband, Kaśyapa, and '''blood''' flowed from her breasts.

sa||BhP|4|24|38|quote=नम ऊर्जे इषे त्रय्याः पतये यज्ञरेतसे। '''तृप्तिदाय''' च जीवानां नमः सर्वरसात्मने॥|t=My Lord, you are the provider of the Pitṛlokas as well as all the demigods. You are the predominating deity of the moon and the master of all three Vedas. I offer my respectful obeisances unto you because you are the '''source of satisfaction''' for all living entities.

sa||BhP|7|12|25|quote=खे खानि वायौ निश्वासांस्तेजःसूष्माणमात्मवान्। अप्स्व्'''असृक्'''श्लेष्मपूयानि क्षितौ शेषं यथोद्भ‍वम्॥|t=A sober, self-realized person who has full knowledge should merge the various parts of the body in their original sources. The holes in the body are caused by the sky, the process of breathing is caused by the air, the heat of the body is caused by fire, and semen, '''blood''' and mucus are caused by water. The hard substances, like skin, muscle and bone, are caused by earth. In this way all the constituents of the body are caused by various elements, and they should be merged again into those elements.

sa||BhP|7|2|8|quote=मच्छूलभिन्नग्रीवस्य भूरिणा रुधिरेण वै। '''असृक्'''प्रियं तर्पयिष्ये भ्रातरं मे गतव्यथः॥|t=I shall therefore sever Lord Viṣṇu’s head from his trunk by my trident, and with the profuse rudhira [blood] from his body I shall please my brother Hiraṇyākṣa, who was so fond of sucking asṛk ['''blood''']. Thus shall I too be peaceful.

sa||Bhag|11|44|quote=प्रणम्य प्रणिधाय कायं प्रसादये त्वामहमीशमीड्यम्|trans=''praṇamya praṇidhāya kāyaṁ prasādaye tvām-aham-īśam-'''īḍyam''''' <br /> saluting, having bent my body, seeking favour of yours I am [O!] lord '''praiseworthy'''

sa||Bhag|3|8|quote=नियतं कुरु कर्म त्वं कर्म '''ज्यायो''' ह्यकर्मणः। शरीरयात्रापि च ते न प्रसिद्धयेदकर्मणः॥|t=Do your duties with discipline, for doing something is '''better''' than being without work. One's body cannot even be maintained without doing work.

sa||Bh|11|7|62|quote=एकदा जग्मतुस्तासामन्नार्थं तौ कुटुम्बिनौ । '''परितः''' कानने तस्मिन्नर्थिनौ चेरतुश्चिरम् ॥|t=Once the two householders went to find food for them [their children]. '''All around''' the forest, the two seekers wandered for a long time.

sa||Bh|1|7|23|quote=त्वमाद्यः पुरुषः साक्षादीश्वरः प्रकृतेः परः ।<br/> मायां व्युदस्य '''चिच्छक्त्या''' कैवल्ये स्थित आत्मनि ॥|t=You are the original man who expands himself all over the creations and is transcendental to material energy. You have cast away the effects of the illusion by '''mental capacity'''. You are always situated in eternal bliss and transcendental knowledge.

sa||Bh|4|14|11|quote=निरूपितः प्रजापालः स '''जिघांसति''' वै प्रजाः। तथापि सान्‍त्वयेमामुं नास्मांस्तत्पातकं स्पृशेत्॥|t=We appointed this king of the state in order to give protection to the citizens, but he '''desires to harm''' them. Despite all these discrepancies, we should at once try to pacify him. By doing so, we may not be touched by the sinful results caused by him.

sa||Bhāratamañjarī|1|636|quote=स गत्वा '''मृण्मयं''' द्रोणं श्रद्धावान् पूजयन् सदा ।<br/>अस्त्राभ्यासं स्वयं चक्रे येनाभूद् धन्विनां वरः ॥|t=He [Ekalavya] went to the '''clay-made''' [statue of] Droṇa, always with reverence and faith;<br/> He trained with his weapons by himself, by which he became the best of the archers.

sa||Bhāratamañjarī|8|155|quote=श्रुत्वैतत् खड्गम् आकृष्य '''हन्तुम्''' आत्मानम् उद्यतम् ।<br/>प्रतिज्ञाभङ्गनिर्भिन्नं पार्थं कृष्णो ऽब्रवीत् पुनः ॥|t=On hearing this, Kṛṣṇa spoke to Arjuna who, having his vow broken was ready '''to kill''' himself having drawn his sword.

sa||BṛĀrUp|2|1.20|quote=स य'''थोर्णवाभिस्'''  तन्तुनोच्चरेत्।<br>यथाग्नेः क्षुद्रा विष्फुलिङ्गा व्युच्चरन्त्य् एवम् एवास्माद् आत्मनः सर्वे प्राणाः सर्वे लोकाः सर्वे देवाः सर्वाणि भूतानि सर्व एत आत्मानो व्युच्चरन्ति तस्योपनिषत् सत्यस्य सत्यम् इति प्राणा वै सत्यं तेषाम् एष सत्यम्|trans=As a '''spider''' sends forth itself by its thread, and as tiny sparks spring forth from a fire, so indeed do all the vital functions, all the worlds, all the gods, and all beings spring from this Self. Its hidden name (upaniṣad) is 'The truth behind the truth', for the truth consists of the vital functions, and the self is the truth behind the vital functions.

sa||BṛĀrUp|6|4|13|quote=अथ यस्य जायाम् आर्तवं विन्देत् त्र्यहं कंसे न पिबेत् ।<br/>अहतवासाः ।<br/>नैनां वृषलो न '''वृषल्य्''' उपहन्यात् ।<br/> त्रिरात्रान्त आप्लुत्य व्रीहीन् अवघातयेत् ॥|t=If anybody’s wife is menstruating, she should not drink for three days in a metal cup<br/>And wear a new dress<br/>No Śūdra man or'''Śūdra woman''' should touch her<br/>After three nights she should be put to thresh rice

sa||BṛĀrUp|6|4|18|quote=अथ य इच्छेत् पुत्रो मे पण्डितो विगीतः समितिंगमः शुश्रूषितां वाचं भाषिता जायेत सर्वान् वेदान् अनुब्रुवीत सर्वम् आयुर् इयाद् इति '''मांसौदनं''' पाचयित्वा सर्पिष्मन्तम् अश्नीयाताम् ईश्वरौ जनयितवा औक्षेण वार्षभेण वा ॥|trans=If a man wishes that a son should be born to him who will be a famous scholar, frequenting assemblies and speaking delightful words, a student of all the Vedas and an enjoyer of the full term of life, he should have '''rice cooked with the meat''' of an ox or a bull and he and his wife should eat it with clarified butter. Then they should be able to beget such a son.
sa||CS|4|1|47|2|quote=कर्ता '''भोक्ता''' न स पुमानिति केचिद्व्यवस्थिताः ॥|t=They do not believe in a Self who is the doer and the '''enjoyer'''.

sa||CS|4|3|13|3-4|quote=स्मार्तं हि ज्ञानमात्मनस्तस्यैव मनसोऽनुबन्धादनुवर्तते यस्यानुवृत्तिं पुरस्कृत्य पुरुषो जातिस्मर इत्युच्यते ।<br/> यानि खल्वस्य गर्भस्य सत्त्वजानि यान्यस्य सत्त्वतः सम्भवतः सम्भवन्ति तान्यनुव्याख्यास्यामः तद्यथा भक्तिः शीलं शौचं द्वेषः स्मृतिर्मोहस्त्यागो मात्सर्यं शौर्यं भयं क्रोधस्तन्द्रोत्साहस्तैक्ष्ण्यं '''मार्दवं''' गाम्भीर्यमनवस्थितत्वमित्येवमादयश्चान्ये ते सत्त्वविकारा यानुत्तरकालं सत्त्वभेदमधिकृत्योपदेक्ष्यामः ॥|t=We shall now enumerate the mind-born parts of the embryo, i. e those that pass from the mind, to the embryo during its formation. These are - inclination, character, purity, hate, recollection, infatuation, liberality, envy, valour, fear, anger, torpor, enthusiasm, keenness, '''softness''', profundity, fickleness, and such others; as also the conditions of the mind, which we shall later describe in connection with the analysis of mind. The mind is indeed of diverse dispositions; all these obtain in the same man but not at the same time. When a man is said to be of a particular disposition, he is said to be so by reason of its preponderance.
sa||Hit|4|16|7|quote=तम् अवलोक्य मूषिकस् तस्य मुनेः '''क्रोडे''' प्रविवेश ।|t=Seeing the cat, the mouse jumped into the sage's '''lap'''.

sa||MBh|18|5|38|quote=धर्मे चार्थे च कामे च मोक्षे च भरतर्षभ ।<br>यदिहास्ति तद्'''अन्यत्र''' यन्नेहास्ति न तत्क्वचित् ॥|t=Bull among Bharatas, whatever is here, on Law, on Profit, on Pleasure, and on Salvation, that is found '''elsewhere'''. But what is not here is nowhere else.

sa||MBh|8|39|31|quote=नैव नाम तव प्रीतिर् नैव नाम कृतज्ञता ।<br/> '''यतस्''' त्वं पुरुषव्याघ्र माम् एवाद्य जिघांससि ॥|t=You certainly do not have any kindness or gratefulness,<br/>'''because of which''' you, O tiger among men, wish to kill me today.

sa||MaitrUp|1|6|9|quote=कालकाञ्जा वा असुरा इष्टका अचिन्वत दिवमारोक्ष्यामा इति तानिन्द्रो ब्राह्मणो ब्रुवाण उपैत् स एतामिष्टकामप्युपाधत्त प्रथमा इव दिवमाक्रमन्त अथ स ताम् आबृहत् तेऽसुराः पापीयांसो भवन्तोऽपाभ्रंशन्त या उत्तमा आस्तां तौ यमश्वा अभवताम् येऽधरे त '''ऊर्णावाभयः'''|trans=The Asuras called Kālakāñja attempted to stack an altar up to the sky. Indra, passing himself off as a Brahmin, inserted one of his bricks into the altar. As soon as the Kālakāñja ascended, Indra removed the brick and they fell: the two who were at the top became Yama's dogs, the others who remained further down, they became '''spiders'''.

sa||Naiṣadhacarita|quote=पदे पदे सन्ति भटा र'''णोद्भटा''' न तेषु हिंसारस एष पूर्यते ।<br/>धिग् ईदृशं ते नृपते कुविक्रमं कृपाश्रये यः कृपणे पतत्त्रिणि ॥|t=There are warriors '''eminent''' in combat at every step; yet your passion for violence is not fulfilled by them.<br/> O King, fie upon your malicious valor which you spend on a poor and pitiful bird.

sa||RVKh||quote=आ॒र्द्रां पु॒ष्करि॑णीं पु॒ष्टिं सु॒वर्णां॑ '''हेम॒मालि॑नीम्''' ।<br>सू॒र्यां हि॒रण्म॑यीं ल॒क्ष्मीं जात॑वेदो म॒ आव॑ह ॥|trans=O Jātavedas, invoke her for me, who is like water, adorned with lotuses, the nourishing one; invoke her who is golden hued, and '''garlanded with gold'''.<br>Invoke her for me who is [brilliant] like the Sun, golden hued, invoke Lakṣmī for me.
sa||RV|10|110|10|1|quote=उपावसृज त्मन्या समञ्जन्देवानां '''पाथ''' ऋतुथा हवींषि ।|t=Send to our '''offering''' which thyself thou balmest the Companies of Devas in ordered season.

sa||RV|10|112|3|quote=हरि॑त्वता॒ '''वर्च॑सा॒''' सूर्य॑स्य॒ श्रेष्ठै॑ रू॒पैस् त॒न्वं॑ स्पर्शयस्व ।<br>अ॒स्माभि॑र् इन्द्र॒ सखि॑भिर् हुवा॒नः स॑ध्रीची॒नो मा॑दयस्वा नि॒षद्य॑ ॥|trans=Deck out thy body with the fairest colours, with golden '''splendour''' of the Sun adorn it.<br>O Indra, turn thee hitherward invited by us thy friends; be seated and be joyful.
sa||RV|10|125|6|quote=अ॒हं रु॒द्राय॒ धनु॒रा त॑नोमि ब्रह्म॒द्विषे॒ '''शर॑वे॒''' हन्त॒वा उ॑ ।|trans=I bend the bow for Rudra that his '''arrow''' may strike and slay the hater of devotion.

sa||RV|10|164|3|quote=यद् आशसा निःशसाभिशसोपारिम जाग्रतो यत् स्वपन्तः ।<br>अग्निर् विश्वान्य् अप '''दुष्कृतान्य्''' अजुष्टान्य् आरे अस्मद् दधातु ॥|trans=If by address, by blame, by imprecation we have committed sin, while awake or asleep,<br>All hateful acts of ours, all '''evil doings''' may Agni banish away to distant places.
sa||RV|10|46|3|quote=स शेवृधो जात आ '''हर्म्येषु''' नाभिर्युवा भवति रोचनस्य ॥|trans=[Agni], born in our '''houses''', Youthful, joy-bestower, he now becomes the central point of brightness.

sa||RV|10|68|7|quote=बृहस्पतिरमत हि त्यदासां नाम स्वरीणां सदने गुहा यत् ।<br>'''आण्डे'''व भित्त्वा शकुनस्य गर्भमुदुस्रियाः पर्वतस्य त्मनाजत् ॥|trans=That secret name borne by the lowing cattle within the cave Bṛhaspati discovered,<br>And drove, himself, the bright kine from the mountain, like a bird's young after the '''egg''''s breaking.

sa||RV|10|82|7|quote=न तं वि॑दाथ॒ य इ॒मा ज॒जाना॒न्यद् यु॒ष्माक॒म् अन्त॑रं बभूव ।<br/>'''नी॒हा॒रेण॒''' प्रावृ॑ता॒ जल्प्या॑ चासु॒तृप॑ उक्थ॒शास॑श् चरन्ति ॥|t=You do not know Him who created these beings, something else has arisen among you.<br/>Covered in '''mist''' and stammering speech, the hymn-chanters wander, unsatisfied.

sa||RV|1|102|5|quote=नाना॒ हि त्वा॒ हव॑माना॒ जना॑ इ॒मे धना॑नां धर्त॒र् अव॑सा विप॒न्यवः॑ ।<br>अ॒स्माकं॑ स्मा॒ रथ॒म् आ ति॑ष्ठ सा॒तये॒ जैत्रं॒ ही॑न्द्र॒ '''निभृ॑तं॒''' मन॒स् तव॑ ॥|trans=For, from various quarters these people here call to you, O holder of stakes, admiring you because of the help (that you give them).<br>Ride our chariot so that it may win: because, your '''firm''' soul, O Indra, (is) made for victory.

sa||RV|1|113|20|quote=यच् चि॒त्रम् '''अप्न॑''' उ॒षसो॒ वह॑न्तीजा॒नाय॑ शशमा॒नाय॑ भ॒द्रं ।<br>तन् नो॑ मि॒त्रो वरु॑णो मामहन्ता॒म् अदि॑तिः॒ सिन्धुः॑ पृथि॒वी उ॒त द्यौः ॥|trans=Whatever splendid '''wealth''' the Dawns bring with them to bless the man who offers praise and worship,<br>That may Mitra, Varuṇa grant us, and Aditi and Sindhu, Earth and Heaven.

sa||RV|1|116|18|quote=यदया॑तं॒ दिवो॑दासाय व॒र्तिर्भ॒रद्वा॑जायाश्विना॒ हय॑न्ता ।<br>रे॒वदु॑वाह सच॒नो रथो॑ वां वृष॒भश्च॑ '''शिंशु॒मार॑'''श्च यु॒क्ता ॥|trans=When to his house ye came, to Divodâsa, hasting to Bharadvâja, O ye Aṣvins, The car that came with you brought splendid riches: a '''porpoise''' and a bull were yoked together.|transauthor=Ralph T. H. Griffith|transyear=1890

sa||RV|1|116|1|quote=नास॑त्याभ्यां ब॒र्हिरि॑व॒ प्र वृ॑ञ्जे॒ '''स्तोमाँ॑ इयर्म्य्'''अ॒भ्रिये॑व॒ वातः॑ ।<br>यावर्भ॑गाय विम॒दाय॑ जा॒यां से॑ना॒जुवा॑ न्यू॒हतू॒ रथे॑न ॥|t=I trim like grass my song for the Nāsatyas and '''send their lauds forth''' as the wind drives rain-clouds,<br>Who, in a chariot rapid as an arrow, brought to the youthful Vimada a consort.<ref>[https://sacred-texts.com/hin/rigveda/rv01116.htm], Rig Veda, tr. by Ralph T.H. Griffith, [1896], at sacred-texts.com</ref>

sa||RV|1|144|7|quote=अग्ने॑ जु॒षस्व॒ प्रति॑ हर्य॒ तद् वचो॒ मन्द्र॒ स्वधा॑व॒ ऋत॑जात॒ सुक्र॑तो ।<br>यो वि॒श्वतः॑ '''प्र॒त्यङ्ङ्''' असि॑ दर्श॒तो र॒ण्वः संदृ॑ष्टौ पितु॒माँ इ॑व॒ क्षयः॑ ॥|t=Agni, accept with joy, be glad in this our prayer, joy-giver, self-sustained, strong, born of Holy Law!<br>For fair to see art thou '''turned towards''' every side, pleasant to look on as a dwelling filled with food.

sa||RV|1|145|4|quote=उ॒प॒स्थायं॑ चरति॒ यत्स॒मार॑त स॒द्यो जा॒तस्त॑त्सार॒ युज्ये॑भिः ।<br/> अ॒भि '''श्वा॒न्तं''' मृ॑शते ना॒न्द्ये॑ मु॒दे यदीं॒ गच्छ॑न्त्युश॒तीर॑पिष्ठि॒तम् ॥|tr=upasthā́yaṃ carati yátsamā́rata sadyó jātástatsāra yújyebhiḥ .<br/> abhí '''śvāntáṃ''' mṛśate nāndyè mudé yádīṃ gáchantyuśatī́rapiṣṭhitám .|t=Whatever he meets he grasps and then runs farther on, and straightway, newly born, creeps forward with his kin.<br/> He stirs the '''tranquil''' man to pleasure and great joy what time the longing gifts approach him as he comes.

sa||RV|1|15|12|quote=गार्ह॑पत्येन सन्त्य ऋ॒तुना॑ यज्ञ॒नीर् अ॑सि ।<br>दे॒वान् दे॑वय॒ते '''य॑ज''' ॥|trans=With Ṛtu, through the house-fire, you, kind Giver, guide the worship-ritual:<br>'''Worship''' the Gods for the sake of the pious one.

sa||RV|1|32|13|quote=नास्मै॑ वि॒द्युन् न '''त॑न्य॒तुः''' सि॑षेध॒ न यां मिह॒म् अकि॑रद् ध्रा॒दुनिं॑ च ।<br>इन्द्र॑श् च॒ यद् यु॑यु॒धाते॒ अहि॑श् चो॒ताप॒रीभ्यो॑ म॒घवा॒ वि जि॑ग्ये ॥|t=The lightning and '''thunder''' failed to help him [against Indra]; the mist and hail that he spread around were similarly of no use to him.<br>When Indra and the Dragon fought, the Generous One [Indra] attained a victory for all times to come.

sa||RV|1|36|5|quote=म॒न्द्रो होता॑ गृ॒हप॑ति॒रग्ने॑ दू॒तो वि॒शाम॑सि।<br>त्वे विश्वा॒ संग॑तानि व्र॒ता ध्रु॒वा यानि॑ दे॒वा '''अकृ॑ण्वत'''॥|trans=Thou, Agni, art a cheering priest, lord of the house, men’s messenger.<br>All constant high decrees '''established''' by the gods, gathered together, meet in thee.

sa||RV|1|79|6|quote='''क्षपो''' राजन्नुत त्मनाग्ने वस्तोरुतोषसः।<br>स तिग्मजम्भ रक्षसो दह प्रति॥|trans=O Agni, shining of thyself by '''night''' and when the morning breaks,<br>Burn, thou whose teeth are sharp, against the Rākṣasas.

sa||RV|1|91|21|quote=अषा॑ळ्हं '''यु॒त्सु''' पृत॑नासु॒ पप्रिं॑ स्व॒र्षाम॒प्सां वृ॒जन॑स्य गो॒पाम् ।<br> भ॒रे॒षु॒जां सु॑क्षि॒तिं सु॒श्रव॑सं॒ जय॑न्तं॒ त्वामनु॑ मदेम सोम ॥|trans=Invincible '''in fight''', saver in battles, guard of our camp, winner of light and water, <br> Born amid hymns, well-housed, exceeding famous, victor, in thee will we rejoice, O Soma.

sa||RV|1|94|6|quote=त्वम् अध्व॒र्युर् उ॒त होता॑सि पू॒र्व्यः '''प्र॑शा॒स्ता''' पोता॑ ज॒नुषा॑ पु॒रोहि॑तः ।<br>विश्वा॑ वि॒द्वाँ आर्त्वि॑ज्या धीर पुष्य॒स्य् अग्ने॑ स॒ख्ये मा रि॑षामा व॒यं तव॑ ॥|trans=Thou art Presenter and the chief Invoker, thou '''Director''', Purifier, great High Priest by birth.<br>Knowing all priestly work thou perfectest it, O Sage. Let us not in thy friendship, Agni, suffer harm.

sa||RV|1|94|6|quote=त्वम् अध्व॒र्युर् उ॒त होता॑सि पू॒र्व्यः प्र॑शा॒स्ता '''पोता॑''' ज॒नुषा॑ पु॒रोहि॑तः ।<br>विश्वा॑ वि॒द्वाँ आर्त्वि॑ज्या धीर पुष्य॒स्य् अग्ने॑ स॒ख्ये मा रि॑षामा व॒यं तव॑ ॥|trans=You are the Presenter and the chief Invoker, you are the Director, '''Purifier''', great High Priest by birth.<br>Knowing all priestly work you perfect it, O Sage. Let us not in your friendship, Agni, suffer harm.

sa||RV|1|94|7|quote=यो विश्वतः सुप्रतीकः '''सदृङ्ङ्''' असि दूरे चित् सन् तळिद् इवाति रोचसे ।<br>रात्र्याश् चिद् अन्धो अति देव पश्यस्य् अग्ने सख्ये मा रिषामा वयं तव ॥|trans=Lovely of form art thou, '''alike''' on every side; though far, thou shinest brightly as if close at hand.<br>O God, thou seest through even the dark of night. Let us not in thy friendship, Agni, suffer harm.

sa||RV|1|94|9|quote=व॒धैर्दुः॒शंसाँ॒ अप॑ '''दू॒ढ्यो॑''' जहि दू॒रे वा॒ ये अन्ति॑ वा॒ के चि॑द॒त्रिणः॑ ।<br>अथा॑ य॒ज्ञाय॑ गृण॒ते सु॒गं कृ॒ध्यग्ने॑ स॒ख्ये मा रि॑षामा व॒यं तव॑ ॥|trans=Smite with thy weapons those of evil speech and '''those with evil thoughts''', devouring demons, whether near or far away.<br>Then to the singer of your praises, give free way for worship. Let us not, in thy friendship, Agni, suffer harm.

sa||RV|2|23|12|quote=अदे॑वेन॒ मन॑सा॒ यो रि॑ष॒ण्यति॑ शा॒सामु॒ग्रो मन्य॑मानो॒ '''जिघां॑सति'''। बृह॑स्पते॒ मा प्रण॒क्तस्य॑ नो व॒धो नि क॑र्म म॒न्युं दु॒रेव॑स्य॒ शर्ध॑तः॥|tr=ádevena mánasā yó riṣaṇyáti śāsā́mugró mányamāno '''jíghāṃsati'''. bṛ́haspate mā́ práṇaktásya no vadhó ní karma manyúm durévasya śárdhataḥ.|t=Whosoever with ungodly mind harms us, who, considering himself powerful in commands '''seeks to do us harm'''<br>Let not his deadly blow reach us, O Bṛhaspati; may we humiliate the strong ill-doer's wrath.

sa||RV|2|27|14|quote=अदिते मित्र वरुणोत मृळ यद् वो वयं चकृमा कच् चिद् आगः ।<br>उर्व् अश्याम् अभयं ज्योतिर् इन्द्र मा नो दीर्घा अभि नशन् '''तमिस्राः''' ॥|trans=Aditi, Mitra, Varuṇa, forgive us however we have erred and sinned against you.<br>May I obtain the broad light free from peril: O Indra, let not the long, '''dark nights''' harm us.

sa||RV|2|43|2|quote='''उ॒द्गा॒ते'''व॑ शकुने॒ साम॑ गायसि ब्रह्मपु॒त्र इ॑व॒ सव॑नेषु शंससि।<br> वृषे॑व वा॒जी शिशु॑मतीर॒पीत्या॑ स॒र्वतो॑ नः शकुने भ॒द्रमा व॑द वि॒श्वतो॑ नः शकुने॒ पुण्य॒मा व॑द॥|t=Thou like the '''chanter-priest''' chantest the holy song, O Bird; thou singest at libations like a Brahman's son.<br>Even as a vigorous horse when he comes near the mare, announce to us good fortune, Bird, on every side, proclaim in all directions happy luck, O Bird.

sa||RV|2|43|2|quote=उ॒द्गा॒तेव॑ शकुने॒ साम॑ '''गायसि''' ब्रह्मपु॒त्र इ॑व॒ सव॑नेषु शंससि।<br> वृषे॑व वा॒जी शिशु॑मतीर॒पीत्या॑ स॒र्वतो॑ नः शकुने भ॒द्रमा व॑द वि॒श्वतो॑ नः शकुने॒ पुण्य॒मा व॑द॥|t=Thou like the chanter-priest '''chantest''' the holy song, O Bird; thou singest at libations like a Brahman's son.<br>Even as a vigorous horse when he comes near the mare, announce to us good fortune, Bird, on every side, proclaim in all directions happy luck, O Bird.

sa||RV|4|30|quote=अपो॒षा अन॑सः सर॒त् संपि॑ष्टा॒द् अह॑ बि॒भ्युषी॑ ।<br>नि यत्सीं॑ शि॒श्नथ॒द् वृषा॑ ॥<br>ए॒तद् अ॑स्या॒ अनः॑ शये॒ सुसं॑पिष्टं॒ '''विपा॒श्य्''' आ ।<br>स॒सार॑ सीं परा॒वतः॑ ॥|trans=Then from her chariot Uṣas fled, affrighted, from her ruined car.<br>When the strong God had shattered it.<br>So there this car of Uṣas lay, broken to pieces, '''in [the river] Vipāś''',<br>And she herself fled far away.

sa||RV|5|54|7|quote=न स जीयते मरुतो न हन्यते न '''स्रेधति''' न व्यथते न रिष्यति।<br>नास्य राय उप दस्यन्ति नोतय ऋषिं वा यं राजानं वा सुषूदथ॥|trans=Never is he, O Maruts, slain or overcome, never doth he '''decay''' ne' er is distressed or harmed;<br>His treasures, his resources, never waste away, whom. whether he be prince or Rsi, ye direct.

sa||RV|5|58|7|quote=प्रथिष्ट यामन्पृथिवी चिदेषां '''भर्तेव''' गर्भं स्वमिच्छवो धुः ।<br>वातान्ह्यश्वान्धुर्यायुयुज्रे वर्षं स्वेदं चक्रिरे रुद्रियासः ॥|trans=Even Earth hath spread herself wide at their coming, and they as '''husbands''' have with power impregned her.<br>They to the pole have yoked the winds for coursers: their sweat have they made rain, these Sons of Rudra.

sa||RV|6|17|3|quote=यो नो॑ अग्ने दु॒रेव॒ आ मर्तो॑ व॒धाय॒ दाश॑ति ।<br>तस्मा॑न् नः '''पा॒ह्य्''' अंह॑सः ॥|trans=Whatever sinner, Agni, brings oblations to procure our death,<br>'''Save''' us from woe that he would work.

sa||RV|6|24|10|quote=सच॑स्व ना॒यम् अव॑से अ॒भीक॑ इ॒तो वा॒ तम् इ॑न्द्र पाहि रि॒षः ।<br>अ॒मा चै॑न॒म् '''अर॑ण्ये''' पाहि रि॒षो मदे॑म श॒तहि॑माः सु॒वीराः॑ ॥|trans=Hasting to help, come hither and protect him, keep him from harm when he is here, O Indra.<br>At home, '''abroad''', from injury preserve him. May brave sons gladden us through a hundred winters.

sa||RV|6|47|21|quote=दिवे दिवे '''सदृशीर्''' अन्यम् अर्धं कृष्णा असेधद् अप सद्मनो जाः ।<br/>अहन् दासा वृषभो वस्नयन्तोद-व्रजे वर्चिनं शम्बरं च ॥|trans=Day after day he drove them far from their seat, from place to place, those darksome creatures who were all '''alike'''.<br/>The Hero slew the meanly-huckstering Dāsas, Varcin and Śambara, where the waters gather.
sa||RV|6|64|1|quote='''कृ॒णोति॒''' विश्वा॑ सु॒पथा॑ सु॒गान्यभू॑दु॒ वस्वी॒ दक्षि॑णा म॒घोनी॑ ॥|trans=She '''makes''' all paths easy and fair to travel, and truly has shown herself benign and friendly.

sa||RV|6|68|05|quote=स इत् सु॒दानुः॒ स्ववाँ॑ ऋ॒तावेन्द्रा॒ यो वां॑ वरुण॒ दाश॑ति॒ त्मन् ।<br>इ॒षा स द्वि॒षस् त॑रे॒द् दास्वा॒न् वंस॑द्र॒यिं '''र॑यि॒वत॑श्''' च॒ जना॑न् ॥|trans=Only he is truly rich in gifts and favor, truly righteous by law, O Indra and Varuna, who is willing to revere you two.<br>The generous one, through food, should surpass his foes; he should conquer wealth and '''wealthy people''' for himself.

sa||RV|6|75|17|quote=यत्र बाणाः सम्पतन्ति कुमारा '''विशिखा''' इव ।<br/> तत्रा नो ब्रह्मणस् पतिर् अदितिः शर्म यच्छतु विश्वाहा शर्म यच्छतु ॥|t=Where the arrows are falling scatteredly, like children '''without shikha''' [i.e. before having undergone religious tonsure];<br/>May Aditi and Bṛhaspati always provide protection there.

sa||RV|8|41|5|quote=यो '''ध॒र्ता''' भुव॑नानां॒ य उ॒स्राणा॑मपी॒च्या॒३॒॑ वेद॒ नामा॑नि॒ गुह्या॑।<br> स क॒विः काव्या॑ पु॒रु रू॒पं द्यौरि॑व पुष्यति॒ नभ॑न्तामन्य॒के स॑मे॥|t=He who is the '''sustainer''' of the worlds, who knows the hidden and secret names of the (solar) rays, he is the sage who cherishes the acts of sages, as the heaven cherishes numerous forms; may all our adversaries perish.

sa||RV|9|81|1|quote=प्र सोमस्य पवमानस्योर्मय इन्द्रस्य यन्ति जठरं सुपेशसः ।<br>'''दध्ना''' यदीमुन्नीता यशसा गवां दानाय शूरमुदमन्दिषुः सुताः ॥|trans=The beauteously adorned waves of Soma move onward to Indra's throat, as he purifies himself,<br>When they, brought forward with the lovely '''curd''' of kine, effused, have cheered the Hero to bestow his gifts.

sa||R|1|2|11|quote=तं शोणितपरीताङ्गं '''वेष्टमानं''' महीतले ।<br/> भार्या तु निहतं दृष्ट्वा रुराव करुणां गिरम् ॥|t=Seeing him struck and having a blood-covered body, '''clinging''' to the ground, the wife cried in a miserable voice.

sa||R|1|48|quote=तस्यान्तरं विदित्वा च सहस्राक्षः शचीपतिः।<br>मुनिवेषधरो भूत्वा अहल्यामिदमब्रवीत्॥<br>ऋतुकालं प्रतीक्षन्ते नार्थिनः सुसमाहिते।<br>संगमं त्वहमिच्छामि त्वया सह सुमध्यमे॥<br>मुनिवेषं सहस्राक्षं विज्ञाय रघुनन्दन।<br>मतिं चकार दुर्मेधा देवराजकुतूहलात्॥<br>अथाब्रवीत् सुरश्रेष्ठं कृतार्थेनान्तरात्मना।<br>कृतार्थास्मि सुरश्रेष्ठ गच्छ शीघ्रमितः प्रभो॥<br>आत्मानं मां च '''देवेश''' सर्वथा रक्ष गौतमात्।<br>इन्द्रस्तु प्रहसन् वाक्यमहल्यामिदमब्रवीत्॥<br>सुश्रोणि परितुष्टोऽस्मि गमिष्यामि यथागतम्।<br>एवं संगम्य तु तदा निश्चक्रामोटजात् ततः॥|t=[O Rama, one day, when the sage Gautama had gone to a distant place] Indra, finding the opportunity, assumed the sage's disguise, and said to Ahalya: "O Attractive One, those who are amorous do not wait for the right time. I desire union with thee, O slender waisted one!" O Rama, although Ahalya recognized Indra disguised as her husband, she out of curiosity about the king of gods, made a foolish decision [and yielded to his desire]. Afterwards, having been satisfied, Ahalya addressed Indra saying : "O best among the gods, I am highly satisfied, now depart quickly from here, Lord. O '''Chief of the gods''', save thyself and me from Gautama." Indra laughed and answered : "O Thou of beautiful waist, I am [also] very satisfied;, I will now depart the same way I entered!" Saying this, he sought to leave the hut of Gautama.

sa||R|1|55|quote=स गत्वा हिमवत्पार्श्वे किंनरोरगसेवितम्। महादेवप्रसादार्थं तपस्तेपे महातपाः॥ केनचित् त्वथ कालेन '''देवेशो''' वृषभध्वजः। दर्शयामास वरदो विश्वामित्रं महामुनिम्॥ किमर्थं तप्यसे राजन् ब्रूहि यत् ते विवक्षितम्। वरदोऽस्मि वरो यस्ते कांक्षितः सोऽभिधीयताम्॥ एवमुक्तस्तु देवेन विश्वामित्रो महातपाः। प्रणिपत्य महादेवं विश्वामित्रोऽब्रवीदिदम्॥ यदि तुष्टो महादेव धनुर्वेदो ममानघ। सांगोपांगोपनिषदः सरहस्यः प्रदीयताम्॥ यानि देवेषु चास्त्राणि दानवेषु महर्षिषु। गन्धर्वयक्षरक्षःसु प्रतिभान्तु ममानघ॥ तव प्रसादाद् भवतु देवदेव ममेप्सितम्। एवमस्त्विति '''देवेशो''' वाक्यमुक्त्वा गतस्तदा॥|t=[Vishwamitra] retired to the forest to practise ascetic worship of Mahādeva (Shiva). After some time, Shiva, the '''Lord of Gods''', with the bull on his flag, appeared before Vishwamitra and said to him : "O King, why art thou undergoing penance ? What is thy desire ? I will grant thee whatsoever thou askest". Vishwamitra, making obeisance to Shri Mahādeva said to him : "O Great God, if I have found favour with thee, then instruct me in the Upanishads and other branches of learning, teach me also the mysteries and the science of archery. Whatever weapons are known to the danavas, yakshas, asuras, gandharvas and other beings, let them be revealed to me by thy grace." On hearing the request of the king, the '''Lord of Gods''' answered, "Be it so" and returned to his abode.

sa||R|3|8|7|quote=अभ्यनुज्ञातुम् इच्छामः सहैभिर् मुनिपुङ्गवैः ।<br/> धर्मनित्यैस् तपोदान्तैर् '''विशिखैर्''' इव पावकैः ॥|t=We wish to be authorized by these great sages,<br/>who are continually pious and self-restrained by penance, like fires '''without flame'''.

sa||R|5|10|49|quote=आतोद्यानि विचित्राणि परिष्वज्य वरस्त्रियः ।<br/>निपीड्य च '''कुचैः''' सुप्ताः कामिन्यः कामुकान् इव ॥|t=Exquisite women were sleeping with various musical instruments<br/> pressed upon their '''bosoms''' like passionate ones embracing their lovers.

sa||Saundarananda|2|55|quote='''तुतुषुस्''' तुषिताश् चैव शुद्धावासाश् च देवताः ।<br>सद्धर्मबहुमाणेण सत्त्वानां चानुकम्पया ॥|t=The deities of Tuṣita and Śuddhāvāsa '''became calm'''<br>Through the great esteem toward the dharma and the compassion toward sentient beings.

sa||Suśruta Saṃhitā|46|292|quote=वेणोः '''करीराः''' कफला मधुरा रसपाकतः ।<br/> विदाहिनो वातकराः सकषाया विरूक्षणाः ॥|t=Bamboo '''shoots''' are phlegmatic, sweet both in taste and digestion, causing heartburn and flatulence, astringent and dryness-causing.

sa||Suśruta Saṃhitā|46|292|quote=वेणोः करीराः '''कफला''' मधुरा रसपाकतः ।<br/> विदाहिनो वातकराः सकषाया विरूक्षणाः ॥|t=Bamboo shoots are '''phlegmatic''', sweet both in taste and digestion, causing heartburn and flatulence, astringent and dryness-causing.

sa||TS|IV|5.11|2|quote=नमो रुद्रेभ्यो ये पृथिव्यां ये ऽन्तरिक्षे ये दिवि येषाम् अन्नं वातो वर्षम् इषवस् तेभ्यो दश प्राचीर् दश दक्षिणा दश '''प्रतीचीर्''' दशोदीचीर् दशोर्ध्वास् तेभ्यो नमस् ते नो मृडयन्तु ते यं द्विष्मो यश् च नो द्वेष्टि तं वो जम्भे दधामि ॥|trans=Homage to the Rudras on the earth, in the atmosphere, in the sky, whose arrows are food, wind, and rain, to them ten eastwards, ten to the south, ten to '''the west''', ten to the north, ten upwards; to them homage, be they merciful to us, him whom we hate and him who hateth us, I place him within your jaws.

sa||TS|VII|5.18|quote=आऽस्मिन् राष्ट्रे राजन्य इषव्यः शूरो महारथो जायताम् । दोग्ध्री धेनुः । वोढाऽनड्वान् आशुः सप्तिः पुरंधिर्योषा जिष्णू रथेष्ठाः सभेयो युवा । आऽस्य यजमानस्य वीरो जायताम् । निकामेनिकामे नः पर्जन्यो वर्षतु फलिन्यो न ओषधयः पच्यन्ताम् । '''योगक्षेमो''' नः कल्पताम् ॥|trans=In this kingdom may a prince [who is bent on ruling] be born, an archer [who is able to shoot arrows], a hero [who is bent on excelling in battle], and a great chariot-fighter [who is bent on fighting]; a milk cow who will yield milk; a draught ox [who is bent on plowing]; a swift racer [who is bent on running]; a young woman who is fertile; a victorious warrior [who is bent on winning]; a youth fit for the assembly [who is bent on speaking well]. To this worshipper be a hero born. May Parjanya rain for us whensoever we desire. May our plants ripen with fruit. May '''peace and prosperity''' be ours.|tr=ā́smín rāṣṭré rājanyà iṣavyàḥ śū́ro mahārathó jāyatām. dógdhrī dhenúḥ. vóḍhānaḍvā́n. ā́śuḥ sáptiḥ. púraṃdhiryóṣā. jiṣṇū́ ratheṣṭhā́ḥ. sabhéyo yúvā. ā́syá yájamānasya vīró jāyatām. nikāménikāme naḥ parjányo varṣatu phalínyo na óṣadhayaḥ pacyantām. '''yogakṣemó''' naḥ kalpatām.

sa||VS|11|15|quote=प्रतूर्वन्न् एह्य् अवक्रामन्न् अशस्ती रुद्रस्य '''गाणपत्यम्''' मयोभूर् एहि ।<br/>उर्व् अन्तरिक्षं वीहि ।<br/>स्वस्तिगव्यूतिर् अभयानि कृण्वन् पूष्णा सयुजा सह ॥|t=Come speeding on and trampling imprecations; come gladdening to the '''chieftainship''' of Rudra.<br/>Speed through the wide air, whose paths are pleasant,<br/>Come, providing safety, with Pūṣan as your companion.
sa||ŚBr|10|4|2|13|quote=पञ्चदशात्मनो ऽकुरुत '''अष्टाचत्वारिंशद्''' इष्टकान्त् स नैव व्याप्नोत्|trans=He made himself fifteen bodies of '''forty-eight''' bricks each: he did not succeed.

sa||ŚBr|10|4|2|14|quote=षोडशात्मनो ऽकुरुत '''पञ्चचत्वारिंशद्''' इष्टकान्त् स नैव व्याप्नोन् न सप्तदशधा व्यभवत्|trans=He made himself sixteen bodies of '''forty-five''' bricks each: he did not succeed. He did not develop seventeenfold.

sa||ŚBr|2|4|1.1|quote=अथ '''हुते'''ऽग्निहोत्र उपतिष्ठते । भूर्भुवः स्वरिति तत्सत्येनैवैतद्वाचं समर्धयति यदाह भूर्भुवः स्वरिति तया समृद्धयाशिषमाशास्ते सुपोषः पोषैरिति तत्पुष्टिमाशास्ते|trans=Now he approaches the fires where the Agnihotra '''has been libated''' and utters: "Earth! ether! sky!" In saying "Earth! ether! sky!", he renders his speech auspicious by means of the truth, and with that (speech) thus rendered propitious he invokes a blessing:--"May I be well supplied with offspring!" whereby he prays for offspring; "--well supplied with men!" whereby he prays for men (heroes); "--well supplied with viands!' whereby he prays for prosperity.

sa||ŚBr|6|3|3.26|quote=समंबिला योनिर्वा इयं रेत इदं यद्वै रेतसो योनिमतिरिच्यतेऽमुया तद्भवत्यथ यन्न्यूनं '''व्यृद्धं''' तदेतद्वै रेतसः समृद्धं यत्समम्बिलं चतुःस्रक्तिरेष कूपो भवति चतस्रो वै दिशः सर्वाभ्य एवैनमेतद्दिग्भ्यः खनति|trans=It (the lump of clay) should be as large as the hole: thus this earth (or clay) becomes his (Agni's) self. And as to its (being) as large as the hole, -- this earth is the womb, and this clay is seed; and whatever part of the seed exceeds the womb, becomes useless; and what is deficient, is '''unsuccessful'''; but that part of the seed which is within the hole is successful. Four-cornered is this hole, for there are four quarters: from all the four quarters he thus digs him out.

sa||ŚBr|8|6|2|18|quote=सोऽस्यैष सुकृत आत्मा । तद्यस्य हैतमेवं सुकृतमात्मानं कुर्वन्त्येतं ह स सुकृतमात्मानमभिसम्भवत्यथ यस्य हैतमतोऽन्यथा कुर्वन्ति '''दुष्कृतं''' ह तस्यात्मानं कुर्वन्ति स ह स '''दुष्कृतम्''' एवात्मानमभिसम्भवति |trans=That body of his (Agni) is well-made; --and, indeed, for whomsoever they thus make that body of his so as to be well-made, he becomes possessed of that body of his as a well-made one; but for whomsoever they make it otherwise than that, for him they make that body of his so as to be '''ill-made''', and he becomes possessed of an '''ill-made''' body.

xag||[[Bible]]|[[1 Timothy]]|3,14-15|quote=𐕠𐔰𐕌𐕄𐔰𐔵 𐕛𐔽𐔰𐕀𐕒𐔾 𐕢̅𐔾𐔴𐕔𐔰𐔰𐕎𐔰𐕄𐔴𐔵𐕒𐕡 𐔼𐔽𐔰𐔳𐕒𐕡𐕐 𐕆𐔴𐕘𐔴𐕚𐔰 𐕛𐔰𐕀 : 𐕆𐔰𐕜𐔴𐕎𐕄𐔴 𐔱𐕞𐕡𐔼𐔱𐔰𐔰𐔴𐔿𐔴-𐔵𐕒𐕡 𐔰𐔰𐕎𐔰𐔰𐕆𐔰𐔾𐔰𐕎𐕄𐔴𐕛𐔰 : 𐕆𐔰𐕖𐔼𐕎𐔱𐔴𐕘𐔰𐕄𐔴 𐕛𐔰𐕚 𐕄𐕒𐕁𐔰 𐔱̅𐔶 𐕆𐕒𐕙𐕒𐔼𐕘𐔴𐕚𐔰 : 𐔱𐕒𐕡𐕆̅𐕄𐔴 𐔴𐕄𐔾𐔴𐕚𐔼 𐔱̅𐔶 𐕘𐕒𐕡𐔺𐕒𐔺𐔰 : 𐕒𐔾 𐕒𐕡𐕎 '''𐕚𐔴𐕙𐕕𐔴𐕀𐔰𐔺𐕒𐕡𐕎'''𐕒𐕡𐕎 𐕜𐔽𐔴𐔲𐔴𐕎̅𐕎 :|trans=This I write unto you because I expect to come to you shortly; so that, if I tarry, you will know how you must behave in the house of God, which is the church of the living God, the pillar and '''the foundation''' of truth.

xag||[[Bible]]|[[Hebrews]]|3,3|quote=𐔼𐕀𐕒𐔺 𐔲𐕈𐕇𐕒𐕡𐕎𐔰 𐔱𐕈𐕇𐔿𐔼𐕆𐔶𐔰𐕎𐔰𐕄𐔴𐕛𐔰 𐕌𐕒𐕡𐕚𐔶𐕚𐔰𐕇𐕒𐕠 𐔼𐕀𐕒𐔺 𐕒𐕜𐔰𐕎𐔱𐔼𐕜𐔶𐕒𐕡𐕎 𐔴𐕔𐔰𐕆𐔰𐕌𐔰𐕜𐕒𐕡𐕎𐕄𐔴 𐔴 𐕄𐕒𐕁𐔰𐕇𐕒𐕠 𐔼𐕀𐕒𐔺 𐕒 '''𐕄𐕒𐕁𐔱𐔰𐔰𐔾'''𐕎𐔴𐕎:|trans=For he was worthy of more glory than Moses, to the (same) extent as '''the builder of a house''' has more honour than the house.

xag||[[Bible]]|[[Romans]]|8,23|quote=𐔸𐔴 𐕆𐕒𐕡𐕜𐕒𐕡𐕎 𐕚𐕒𐕡𐕎 𐕚𐔰 𐔷𐔰𐕎𐔰𐔾 𐔴 𐕙𐕒𐕡𐕘 𐕆𐔴𐔾𐔼𐕎 𐔴𐕔𐔰𐕆𐔰𐕎𐔰𐔺𐕈͞𐕎𐕄𐔴 𐔱𐕒𐕡𐔾𐕌𐕒𐕇 𐔱𐔴𐕐𐔼 𐔱𐔼𐔼𐕎 𐕒𐕡𐕆𐕒𐕡𐕒𐔽𐕒𐕌 𐕆𐔴𐔾𐔽𐔰𐕀𐔰𐔷𐔰𐕎 '''𐕘𐔰𐕙𐕠𐔰𐕌𐕢𐔴𐕚𐕒𐕡𐕎'''𐔰𐕇 𐕢𐕒𐕡𐔾𐔴𐕔𐔶 𐕣𐔰𐕙𐕀𐔴𐕚𐔱𐔼𐔺𐔴𐕚𐕒𐕡𐕎𐔰 𐕌𐔰𐕙𐕌𐔼𐔿𐕒𐕡𐕎 𐔱𐔴𐕐𐔼|trans=(And) not only up to this, but we, too, who have the fruit of the Spirit, (we) ourselves groan likewise in ourselves, expecting '''the adoption''', the salvation of our body.

xcl|Bible|Acts|28|3|quote=Եւ ի ժողովելն պաւղոսի '''խռիւ''' ինչ բազում եւ դնել ի վերայ խարուկին, իժ մի ի ջերմութենէն ելեալ կալաւ զձեռանէ նորա։|trans=And when Paul had gathered a bundle of '''sticks''', and laid them on the fire, there came a viper out of the heat, and fastened on his hand.|refn=<ref>{{R:xcl:Acts|page=83

xcl|Bible|Job|41|15|quote=Անդամք մարմնոյ նորա մածեալք․ եթէ զեղցի ի վերայ նորա՝ ոչ '''խլրտասցէ։'''|trans=The limbs of its body, cleaved together; if it will flow upon it, it will not '''be shaken'''.|transauthor=Claude E. Cox|refn=<ref name=Cox>{{R:xcl:Cox:2006|page=264

xcl||Բարոյախոս|Earliest recension (''TR'')|10|2–3|quote=Է թռչուն ինչ ի '''հնդիկս''', որ կոչի փիւնիքս։ Ըստ հինգհարիւր ամին գայ ի ծառսն Լիբանանու եւ լնու զերկոսին թեւսն իւր խնկաւք. եւ երթայ ազդ առնէ քրմին Արեգ քաղաքի ի յամսեան պայեմոդի կամ ի փարմոդի, այսինքն արեգ կամ ի կանխոց։|trans=There is a bird in '''India''' called phoenix. Every five hundred years it comes to the trees of Lebanon and fills both its wings with incense, and goes to inform the priest of Heliopolis, in the month Phamenoth or Pharmuthi, that is Areg or the preceding months [i.e. Meheki].|transauthor=Gohar Muradyan|refn=<ref>{{R:xcl:Physiologus|pages=103, 147

xcl||Բարոյախոս|Earliest recension (''TR'')|5|2–3|quote=Յորժամ տեսանէ զնաւս առագաստեալս, նմանի նոցա․ ամբառնայ զթեւս ի նմանութիւն առագաստաց եւ հակառակի ընդ նաւսն․ եւ երթա '''վտաւանս''' երեսուն կամ քառասուն․ իբրեւ վաստակի, խոնարհեցուցանէ զթեւսն եւ յինքն ամբփոփէ յաշխատութենէ։|trans=When it [the "saw-fish"] sees ships driven by sails, it imitates them: it raises its wings like sails and competes with the ships. After racing 30 or 40 '''stadia''', growing tired, it brings the wings down and folds them to itself because of fatigue.|transauthor=Gohar Muradyan|refn=<ref>{{R:xcl:Physiologus|pages=93—94, 144

xcl||Բարոյախոս|Earliest recension (''TR'')|5|2–3|quote=Յորժամ տեսանէ զնաւս առագաստեալս, նմանի նոցա․ ամբառնայ զթեւս ի նմանութիւն առագաստաց եւ հակառակի ընդ նաւսն․ եւ երթա վտաւանս երեսուն կամ քառասուն․ իբրեւ վաստակի, խոնարհեցուցանէ զթեւսն եւ յինքն '''ամբփոփէ''' յաշխատութենէ։|trans=When it [the "saw-fish"] sees ships driven by sails, it imitates them: it raises its wings like sails and competes with the ships. After racing 30 or 40 stadia, growing tired, it brings the wings down and '''folds''' them to itself because of fatigue.|transauthor=Gohar Muradyan|refn=<ref>{{R:xcl:Physiologus|pages=93—94, 144

xcl||Բարոյախոս|Earliest recension (''TR'')|5|8|quote=Խոկալով ի գործս բարութեան, չկարացին հանել ի գլուխ վասն արծաթսիրութեան կամ ամբարհաւաճութեան կամ '''շնութեան''', պոռնկութեան եւ կամ վասն զաւշաքաղութեան կամ վասն այլ իրիք|trans=Thinking of good deeds, they did not persevere to the end because of love of money or arrogance, or '''adultery''', fornication or because of avarice or some other thing|transauthor=Gohar Muradyan|refn=<ref>{{R:xcl:Physiologus|pages=94, 144

xcl||Բարոյախոս|Earliest recension (TR)|21|3|quote=Քանզի զաւտարին ձուս գողանայ եւ յիւր բունն տանի․ եւ մինչ չկարէ հանդարտել թխոյն վասն բազում ձագուցն, երթայ կուտէ '''խռիւ''' ինչ եւ թոյլ տայ, որ ցամաքի․ եւ այնպէս '''խռուովն''' հանդերձ թխէ։|trans=For it steals the eggs of the others and takes them to its nest; and until it cannot rest sitting on eggs because of many nestlings, it goes, heaps some '''brushwood''' and lets it dry up, and thus sits on eggs with the '''brushwood'''.|transauthor=Gohar Muradyan|refn=<ref>{{R:xcl:Physiologus|pages=123, 154

xcl|Ագաթանգեղոս||645|quote=Սոյնպէս եւ գունակ գունակ եւ երփն երփն ծաղկանցն․ որպէս մանրագորն եւ վարդն եւ շուշանն եւ ասպազանն եւ յասմիկն եւ անիարն եւ սմնակն եւ ներգիսն եւ '''շամպղիտակն''' եւ մեղրուկն, հօրօտն եւ մօրօտն եւ մանիշակն․ եւ այլն ամենայն համասպրամ ծաղկանցն եւ ծառոցն բոյսք բողբոջոցն գարնանւոյն երեւեսցին յետ ձմերանւոյն։|trans=Likewise the various kinds and colors of flowers, like the mandrake and rose, and lily and soldanel, and jasmin and lotus, and sumach and narcissus, and '''arum''' and lungwort, and hyacinth and poppy and violet. And of all the other fragrant flowers and trees, the budding shoots will appear in spring after the winter.|transauthor=Robert W. Thomson|refn=<ref>{{R:xcl:Agatangeghos|pages=330–331

xcl|Բուզանդ||III|7|quote=Յայնմ ժամանակի թագաւոր Մազքթաց Սանէսան անհնարին նիւթեաց զսրտմտութիւն ոխութեան ընդ իւրում ազգակցին Խոսրովու արքային Հայոց, և գումարեաց ժողովեաց զամենայն զօրս Հոնաց եւ Փոխաց, Թաւասպարաց, Հեճմատակաց, Իժմախաց, Գաթաց և Գղուարաց, Գուգարաց, Շչբաց և Ճղբաց և '''Բաղասճաց''' և Եգերսուանացն, և այլոց խառնաղանճ բազմութեամբք, անթիւ բանակն վաչկատուն զօրութեանց, որում միանգամ ինքն իշխէր զօրացն բազմաց:|trans=At that time, Sanēsan, king of the Mazkʿutʿkʿ, nourished an implacable hatred and rancor against his kinsman Xosrov, king of Armenia. And so, he gathered and assembled all the forces of the Honkʿ and the Poxkʿ, of the Tʿawasparkʿ, the Hečmatakkʿ, the Ižmaxkʿ, the Gatʿkʿ, and Głuarkʿ, the Gugarkʿ, the Šičbkʿ, and the Čiłbkʿ and the '''Bałasčikʿ''', and the Egersuankʿ, and masses of other rabble. [It was] an innumrable nomadic host, whose entire large force he led himself.|transauthor=Nina G. Garsoïan|refn=<ref>{{R:xcl:Buzand|page=14

xcl|Բուզանդ||V|37|quote=Բայց Մանուէլ որդի '''Արտաշինայ''' ի Մամիկոնեան ի տոհմէն, հանդերձ եղբարբն իւրով Կոմսիւ, բազում քաջութիւնս կատարեալ ի նմին ճակատուն, սակայն հետիոտս ապրէին:|trans=But Manuēl son of '''Artašēn''' from the Mamikonean house, together with his brother Koms, performed many deeds of valor in this battle, though they survived [only] on foot.|transauthor=Nina G. Garsoïan|refn=<ref>{{R:xcl:Buzand|pages=201–202

xcl|Եղիշե||chapter 4|quote=Այլ և դրօշից անգամ իւրաքանչիւրոց տեղեկանայր ի նմանէ․ և թէ քանի՛ գունդ զզօրսն բաժանիցեն, և ո՛ր ոք ի նոցանէ '''սաղարք''' լինիցին, և ո՛ր զօրագլուխ յորմէ կողմանէ յռազմ մտանիցէ, և զինչ անուանք իւրաքանչիւր համհարզացն իցեն, և քանի՛ փողահարք ի մէջ գնդին ձայնիցեն։|notes=1957 edition, page 96|trans=He also inquired from him about each of the standards: into how many companies they divided the army, which of them were '''generals''', which commander would attack from which side, what were the names of each one's adjutants, how many trumpeters would sound in the company.|transauthor=Robert W. Thomson|refn=<ref>{{R:xcl:Thomson:1982|page=148

xcl|Եւս.|քր.|I|65–66|quote='''գումարեաց''' եդ ի ձեռին որդւոյն իւրում Նաբուկոդրոսորայ, որ այնուհետեւ ի չափ իսկ հասակի հասեալ էր, մասն ինչ ի զօրացն|trans=he put part of the troops he '''had assembled''' under the control of his son, Nebuchadnezzar, who had reached maturity|transauthor=Robert Bedrosian|refn=<ref>{{R:xcl:EusebiusOfCaesarea:1818|vol=I|page=65

xcl|Եւս.|քր.|quote=Քիղոն յեօթանց իմաստնոցն '''պարէտ''' ղակեդմոնացւոց եղեւ։|trans=Chilon from the Seven Sages became '''ephor''' the Lacedaemonians.|refn=<ref>{{R:xcl:EusebiusOfCaesarea:1818|vol=II|page=198

xcl|Թրակ.|quote=Փաղանուն է որ ի զանազան անուանս զնոյն ցուցանէ․ որգոն խադ, '''դալապր''', մարտացու, վաղակաւոր, սուսեր, նրան։|trans=A synonym is a noun which, by several designations, signifies the same thing, as ''{{xlit|xcl|խադ, '''դալապր''', մարտացու, վաղակաւոր, սուսեր, նրան

xcl|Ինճիճեան||part 2, volume 4, page 320|year=1805|quote=Զէնք հետևակ զօրաց են սաղաւարտ, վահան, երկու թուր, մի սուին և '''ատրճան''', այն է՝ թիւֆէնկ։ Իսկ հեծել՟ք յոտից մինչև ՚ի գլուխ զրահաւոր են, և ունին ատրճանակ․ այն է՝ փիշտով, նետ, նիզակ և թուր։|trans=The munitions of the infantry are the helmet, shield, two swords, one {{m|xcl|սուին

xcl|Շիրակացի|Աշխարհացույց|quote=Եւ '''զռնգնեղջիւր''' գազանէն ասեն թէ յՈվկիանոսէ անցանեն ընդ Ենտոս-Լիբիա մինչեւ ցՆեղոս, եւ նման են գետաձիոյ եւ ամենեքեան որձ են․|trans=They tell of '''rhinoceroses''' which roam from the Ocean to Inner Libya as far as the Nile; they resemble the hippopotamus and are all males.|transauthor=Robert H. Hewsen|transyear=1992

xcl|ՍԳր.|Amos|5|23|quote=Ի բաց արա յինէն զձայն երգոց քոց, եւ '''զնուագս''' սրնգաց քոց ես ոչ լուայց։|trans=Remove from me the sound of thy songs, and I will not hear the '''music''' of thine instruments.|transauthor=Brenton Septuagint Translation

xcl|ՍԳր.|Jeremiah|50|26|quote=Եկին հասին նմա ժամանակք իւր, բացէք զշտեմարանս նորա, '''որոնեցէք''' զնա իբրեւ զայրս, եւ սատակեցէք զնա․ մի՛ մնասցեն նոցա մնացորդք։|trans=For her times are come: open ye her storehouses: '''search''' her as a cave, and utterly destroy her: let there be no remnant of her.|transauthor=Brenton Septuagint Translation

xcl|ՍԳր.|Philippians|3|13|quote=Եղբարք, ես ոչ համարիմ զանձն իմ թէ հասեալ իցեմ. բայց մի ինչ է` զի զառ ի յետոյսն մոռացեալ է, եւ ի յառաջադէմսն '''նկրտեալ''' եմ:|trans=Brethren, I count not myself to have apprehended: but [this] one thing [I do], forgetting those things which are behind, and '''reaching forth''' unto those things which are before.|transauthor=King James Version

xcl|Փիլ.|ել.|2|5|quote=Ընդէ՞ր ասէ, Զաստուածս ո՛չ '''հայհոյեսցես'''։ Եւ արդ ևս մեղադրե՞ն զա՟ծային օրէնս, իբրու թէ զայլոց սովորութիւնս քակեն․ քանզի ահա՛ ոչ միայն հաստատութիւն մատուցանեն այլափառացն, յընդունելութիւն և ի պատիւ այնոցիկ՝ զորս ի սկզբանէն կարծեցին թէ են ա՟ծք․ այլ և զիւրեանց աշակերտեալսն ըմբերանեն և սանձեն, ոչ տուեալ թոյլ արձակ լեզուով բամբասել զնոսա, լաւ զբարեհամբաւ գովութիւն համարեալք։|trans=Why does (Scripture) say, "gods thou shalt not '''revile'''"? Do they then still accuse the divine Law of breaking down the customs of others? For, behold, not only does it offer support to those of different opinion by accepting and honouring those whom they have from the beginning believed to be gods, but it also muzzles and restrains its own disciples, not permitting them to revile these with a loose tongue, for it believes that well-spoken praise is better.|transauthor=Ralph Marcus|refn=<ref>{{R:xcl:Philo|vol=II|page=471

xcl|Փիլ.|ել.|2|5|quote=Ընդէ՞ր ասէ, Զաստուածս ո՛չ հայհոյեսցես։ Եւ արդ ևս մեղադրե՞ն զա՟ծային օրէնս, իբրու թէ զայլոց սովորութիւնս քակեն․ քանզի ահա՛ ոչ միայն '''հաստատութիւն''' մատուցանեն այլափառացն, յընդունելութիւն և ի պատիւ այնոցիկ՝ զորս ի սկզբանէն կարծեցին թէ են ա՟ծք․ այլ և զիւրեանց աշակերտեալսն ըմբերանեն և սանձեն, ոչ տուեալ թոյլ արձակ լեզուով բամբասել զնոսա, լաւ զբարեհամբաւ գովութիւն համարեալք։|trans=Why does (Scripture) say, "gods thou shalt not revile"? Do they then still accuse the divine Law of breaking down the customs of others? For, behold, not only does it offer '''support''' to those of different opinion by accepting and honouring those whom they have from the beginning believed to be gods, but it also muzzles and restrains its own disciples, not permitting them to revile these with a loose tongue, for it believes that well-spoken praise is better.|transauthor=Ralph Marcus|refn=<ref>{{R:xcl:Philo|vol=II|page=471

xcl|Փիլ.|լին.|2.62|quote=Ամենաբարւոք եւ առանց ստութեան այս հրաման պատասխանոյ յա՟յ ելեալ է․ քանզի մահկանացու ոչինչ կերպարանիլ ի '''նմանութիւն''' առ վերնագոյնն եւ առ հայրն ամենեցուն կարէր, այլ առ երկրորդն ա՟ծ՝ որ է նորա բան։ Քանզի պարտ է բանականին մարդկան ոգւոյ՝ տիպ ա՟ծային բանին ձեւանալ․ վասն զի առաջին բանին՝ ա՟ծ վեհագոյն է, ամենաբանական բնութիւնն․ իսկ այն որ ի վեր քան զբանն է, ի լաւագունին եւ յառանձինն իմն անցեալ կայ ի տեսակի, զի՞նչ պարտ էր եղելոյ նման նորա բերել։ Բայց սակայն կամի եւ զայն ազդել, զի իրաւագոյն ա՟ծ վրէժ խնդրէ, զաստեացն եւ զճահաւորաց, վասն կրելոյ իմն այսմ առ նորա բանն զընտանութիւն․ որոյ է եւ մարդկային միտքն նմանութիւն եւ կերպարան։|trans=Most excellently and veraciously this oracle was given by God. For nothing mortal can be made in the '''likeness''' of the most high One and Father of the universe but (only) in that of the second God, who is His Logos. For it was right that the rational (part) of the human soul should be formed as an impression by the divine Logos, since the pre-Logos God is superior to every rational nature. But He who is above the Logos (and) exists in the best and in a special form—what thing that comes into being can rightfully bear His likeness? Moreover, Scripture wishes also to show that God most justly avenges the virtuous and decent men because they have a certain kinship with His Logos, of which the human mind is a likeness and image.|transauthor=Ralph Marcus|refn=<ref>{{R:xcl:Philo|vol=II|pages=146–147

xcl|Փիլ.|լիւս.|quote=Ասեն, թէ՝ եւ '''կրայք''' յանյագութենէ որկորստութեանն առ լցեալք յիժից՝ ուտել զուիրակ ի վերայ երկիւղիւ մահու․ քանզի միայն ա՛յսպէս ի թունաբերացն՝ որ վնասս լինի՝ ճողոպրել կարեն:|trans=It is said that when '''tortoises''' devour asps because of gluttony, they eat marjoram for fear of dying; for only by this means can they be relieved of the harmful venom.|transauthor=Abraham Terian|refn=<ref>{{R:xcl:Philo|vol=I|page=144

xcl|Փիլ.|լիւս.|quote=Արդ զսոսա վասն զի քակել անհնա՛ր էր, որ ասին '''թոնձք''', (լս. պեղականք) դիւրահնարաբար կլանեն յառաջագոյն, զի կոկորդին ջերմութեամբ հալեսցի, որ զպատեանսն պինդ պահէ սինձն, եւ սակաւ թուլացեալ արձակեսցին աղխքն|trans=It is impossible to pry open what are called '''shellfish''' [in the margin glossed with "pelicans"]. Whatever is snared is absorbed easily, since it dissolves by the warmth of the gullet. What keeps the shells tight is an elastic, which when relaxed, releases the clasp, so that they open wide to engulf food.|transauthor=Abraham Terian|refn=<ref>{{R:xcl:Philo|vol=I|page=140

xcl|Փիլ.|լիւս.|quote=Քանզի կեռնեխք՝ եւ ագռաւք եւ '''պապկայք''', եւ որ միանգամ հոմանմանք, զի թէպէտ եւ զանազանագոյն բարբառեսցին, յօդաւոր ո՛չ երբէք եւ ո՛չ իւիք ձայն կարասցեն հանել։|trans=Although blackbirds, crows, '''parrots''', and all the like can produce different kinds of utterances, they cannot produce an articulated voice in any manner whatever.|transauthor=Abraham Terian|refn=<ref>{{R:xcl:Philo|vol=I|page=171

en|John Skorupski|, Routledge Encyclopedia of Philosophy|, Mill, John Stuart (1806–73)|year=1998|quote=Thus Mill’s case for the claim that happiness is the sole human end, put more carefully, is this: ‘Whatever is desired otherwise than as a means to some end beyond itself, and ultimately to happiness, is desired as itself a part of happiness, and is not desired for itself until has become so’ (1861a: 237). Nothing here assumed Hume’s view that every action must ultimately flow from an underived desire. That is a quite separate issue, and Mill’s view of it is closer to that of Kant or Reid than to that of Hume. He insists ‘positively and emphatically’ that ''the '''will''' is a different thing from desire''; that a person of confirmed virtue, or any other person whose ''purposes are fixed'', carries out his purposes without any thought of the pleasure he has in contemplating them, or expects to derive from their fulfilment. (1861a: 238) ''This distinction between purpose and desire is central to Mill’s conception of the '''will'''. When we develop purposes we can will against mere likings or aversions'': ‘In the case of an habitual purpose, instead of willing the thing because we desire it, we often desire it only because we will it’ (1861a: 238). Every action is caused by a motive, but not every motive is a liking or aversion: When the will is said to be determined by motives, a motive does not mean always, or solely, the anticipation of a pleasure or of a pain…. ''A habit of willing is commonly called a purpose''; and among the causes of our volitions, and of the actions which flow from them, must be reckoned not only likings and aversions, but also purposes. (1843: 842) ''The formation of purposes from desires is the evolution of '''will'''; it is also the development of character''. Mill quotes Novalis: ‘a character is a completely fashioned will’ (1843: 843).

en|Joseph Tropper, Rebecca Hasselbach-Andee|Classical Ethiopic: A Grammar of Gəˁəz|§ 6|5|5|year=2021|quote=When the temporal clause precedes the main clause, the main clause can be connected  '''asyndetically''' or by [[ወ-]] wa-.

en|Kane, Kathryn|The Regency Redingote Blog|The Cut: The Ultimate & Final Social Weapon|year=27 September 2013|quote=The Monthly Magazine, Or, British Register for 1798 included an explanation by a reader of how the cut was carried out in his college days in a lengthy letter to the editor, signed by the pseudonym "Ansonius." In his rambling letter, Ansonius noted that when he was at college, ''" … if a man passed an old acquaintance wittingly, without recognizing him, he was said— ‘'''To cut''' him.’"'' Ansonius then went on to explain the performance of the cut and noted that for a time the term "to spear" was used instead of to cut. However, that term did not remain long in use, and this act was generally known as "the cut" ever after.

en|Kane, Kathryn|The Regency Redingote Blog|The Cut: The Ultimate & Final Social Weapon|year=27 September 2013|quote=The Monthly Magazine, Or, British Register for 1798 included an explanation by a reader of how the cut was carried out in his college days in a lengthy letter to the editor, signed by the pseudonym "Ansonius." In his rambling letter, Ansonius noted that when he was at college, " … if a man passed an old acquaintance wittingly, without recognizing him, he was said— ‘To cut him.’" Ansonius then went on to explain the performance of the cut and noted that for a time the term "'''to spear'''" was used instead of to cut. However, that term did not remain long in use, and this act was generally known as "the cut" ever after.

en|Laurence, Stephen and Margolis, Eric|Abstraction and the Origin of General Ideas,| Philosophers' Imprint volume 12, no. 19, December 2012|year=2012|quote=Given their opposition to innate ideas, philosophers in the empiricist tradition have sought to explain how the rich and multifarious ''representational'' capacities that human beings possess derive from experience. A key explanatory strategy in this tradition, tracing back at least as far as John Locke’s An Essay Concerning Human Understanding, is to maintain that the acquisition of many of these capacities can be accounted for by a process of '''''abstraction'''''. In fact, Locke himself claims in the Essay that '''''abstraction''' is the source of all general ideas'' (1690/1975, II, xii, §1). Although Berkeley and Hume were highly critical of Locke, '''''abstraction''' as a source of generality has been a lasting theme in empiricist thought''.

en|Samuel Barber|The Way of All Flesh|chapter 73|year=1903|quote=At first it had been very painful to him to meet any of his old friends, [...] but this soon passed; either they '''cut''' him, or he '''cut''' them; it was not nice being '''cut''' for the first time or two, but after that, it became rather pleasant than not [...] The ordeal is a painful one, but if a man's moral and intellectual constitution are naturally sound, there is nothing which will give him so much strength of character as having been well '''cut'''.

hy|Աճառյան|գաղթ.|175|quote=Բացի Կալիցիայէն, որ Լեհաստանի գաղթականութեան մասը կա կազմէ, Աւստրիոյ կայսրութեան միւս հայաբնակ երկիրներն են՝ '''Պուքովինա''', Թրանսիլվանիա, Հունգարիա և բուն Աւստրիա։|trans=Apart from Galicia, which is part of Poland's diaspora, the other Armenian-populated lands of the Austrian Empire are '''Bukovina''', Transylvania, Hungary and Austria itself.

hy|Աճառյան|գաղթ.|175|quote=Բացի Կալիցիայէն, որ Լեհաստանի գաղթականութեան մասը կա կազմէ, Աւստրիոյ կայսրութեան միւս հայաբնակ երկիրներն են՝ Պուքովինա, '''Թրանսիլվանիա''', Հունգարիա և բուն Աւստրիա։|trans=Apart from Galicia, which is part of Poland's diaspora, the other Armenian-populated lands of the Austrian Empire are Bukovina, '''Transylvania''', Hungary and Austria itself.

hy|Աճառյան|գաղթ.|page 115|quote=Լեհաստան գաղթող հայերը առաջին անգամ 1120 տուն բնակեցան Կալիցիայի '''Իլվով''' կամ Լէմպէրկ մայրաքաղաքին քով՝ առանձին արուարձանի մը մէջ, որպէսզի օտարներու հետ չխառնուին։|trans=The Armenians immigrating to Poland first lived in 1120 households near '''Lviv''' or Lemberg, the capital of Galicia, in a separate suburb to avoid intermixing with foreigners.

hy|Հովնաթան Նաղաշ|quote='''Շամամներիդ''' համար դառն եմ,<br>Թո՛ղ, որ ձեռս մէջն խառնեմ,<br>Ինձ ծախեմ՝ էդ բախչէդ առնեմ։<br>Զալում, թո՛ղ՝ ես<br>Եմիշ քաղեմ,<br>Մէկ ծիծաղեմ:|trans=I'm desperate for your '''melons'''.<br>Let my hand them go among them,<br>Let me sell myself and buy the orchard of yours.<br>O unjust one, Let me<br>pick some fruit<br>and have a giggle.|transauthor=S. Peter Cowe|refn=<ref>{{R:hy:Naghash|pages=48–49

hy|Հովնաթան Նաղաշ|quote=Շամամներիդ համար դառն եմ,<br>Թո՛ղ, որ ձեռս մէջն խառնեմ,<br>Ինձ '''ծախեմ'''՝ էդ բախչէդ առնեմ։<br>Զալում, թո՛ղ՝ ես<br>Եմիշ քաղեմ,<br>Մէկ ծիծաղեմ:|trans=I'm desperate for your melons.<br>Let my hand them go among them,<br>Let me '''sell''' myself and buy the orchard of yours.<br>O unjust one, Let me<br>pick some fruit<br>and have a giggle.|transauthor=S. Peter Cowe|refn=<ref>{{R:hy:Naghash|pages=48–49

hy|Հովնաթան Նաղաշ|quote=Շամամներիդ համար դառն եմ,<br>Թո՛ղ, որ ձեռս մէջն խառնեմ,<br>Ինձ ծախեմ՝ էդ '''բախչէդ''' առնեմ։<br>Զալում, թո՛ղ՝ ես<br>Եմիշ քաղեմ,<br>Մէկ ծիծաղեմ:|trans=I'm desperate for your melons.<br>Let my hand them go among them,<br>Let me sell myself and buy the '''orchard''' of yours.<br>O unjust one, Let me<br>pick some fruit<br>and have a giggle.|transauthor=S. Peter Cowe|refn=<ref>{{R:hy:Naghash|pages=48–49

hy|Հովնաթան Նաղաշ|quote=Շամամներիդ համար դառն եմ,<br>Թո՛ղ, որ ձեռս մէջն խառնեմ,<br>Ինձ ծախեմ՝ էդ բախչէդ առնեմ։<br>'''Զալում''', թո՛ղ՝ ես<br>Եմիշ քաղեմ,<br>Մէկ ծիծաղեմ:|trans=I'm desperate for your melons.<br>Let my hand them go among them,<br>Let me sell myself and buy the orchard of yours.<br>'''O unjust one''', Let me<br>pick some fruit<br>and have a giggle.|transauthor=S. hy|Մենևիշյան|Zoology|quote='''Սրնչակը'''՝ թէպէտ նրբաքիթ “մուկ”, ալ կ՚անուանուի, բայց մկանց կարգին տակ չ՚երթար:|trans='''The shrew''', although also called narrow-nosed “mouse”, does not belong to the genus of mice.|refn=<ref>{{R:hy:Menevishyan|vol=I|page=47
hy|Նար-Դոս|quote=Դեռ կան մարդին, որոնք կրոնական գաղափարները '''մեկնաբանում''' են իբրև իրականություն։|t=There are still people who '''interpret''' religious ideas as reality.

hy|Վահե Ավետյան|Անկախության բանակ|quote=Նախ խիստ նվազում էր անձնական բյուջեն, իսկ դա ջինս էր, կիթառ, Ծաղկաձոր-Շորժա-կոմպոզիտորների տուն, դահուկ, օղի, ծխախոտ, պլան երբեմն, ու '''պցեր''' ու սիրելի աղջիկներ՝ նրանցից, որ ամուսնանում էին հետո որպես հարգարժան կույսեր։|trans=Firstly, the personal budget was greatly diminished, and that was jeans, guitar, Tsaghkadzor–Shorzha–House of Composers, skis, vodka, tobacco, sometimes weed, and '''hos''' and lovely girls—the kind that would later get married as respectable virgins.

inc-apa|Vir|जंबू|8|11|14|quote=माणिणि-माण-उवसावण-कंखिरु<br>महुरम्मण-उल्लावण-'''झंकिरु''' ।|t=In order to pacify the pride of the ladies,<br>he sweetly utters his own words and '''takes a long sigh'''.

inc-apa|Vir|जंबू|9|15|4-5|quote=करमि '''अकम्मु''' सिट्ठ-जण-दूसिउ मंदिरु तं न जं न मइँ मूसिउ ।<br/>तेरउ एक्क नवर न निहेलणु चोरमि अज्जु तं पि पेरिउ मणु ।|t=I commit '''misdeeds''' that are condemned by civilised people. There is no house that I have not looted from.<br/>In fact, your house is the only one that I have not looted yet, so I am tempted to rob it today.

inc-apa|Vir|जंबू|9|15|4-5|quote=करमि अकम्मु सिट्ठ-जण-दूसिउ मंदिरु तं न जं न मइँ मूसिउ ।<br/>तेरउ एक्क नवर न निहेलणु चोरमि '''अज्जु''' तं पि पेरिउ मणु ।|t=I commit misdeeds that are condemned by civilised people. There is no house that I have not looted from.<br/>In fact, your house is the only one that I have not looted yet, so I am tempted to rob it '''today'''.

inc-ash|Asoka|Major Pillar Edict 4|Delhi-Topra|19-20|quote=𑀚𑀦𑀲 𑀘 '''𑀯𑀠𑀢𑀺''' 𑀯𑀺𑀯𑀺𑀥𑁂 𑀥𑀁𑀫𑀘𑀮𑀦𑁂 𑀲𑀁𑀬𑀫𑁂 𑀤𑀸𑀦𑀲𑀯𑀺𑀪𑀸𑀕𑁂 𑀢𑀺|t=And various moral practices, self-control and the distribution of gifts are (thus) '''promoted''' among the people.|transauthor=Eugen Hultzsch<ref>{{R:inc-ash:Hultzsch
inc-ash|Aśoka|Major Rock Edict 6|line 9|year=c. 268 BCE – 232 BCE|quote='''𑀓𑀝𑀯𑀺𑀬'''𑀫𑀢𑁂 𑀳𑀺 𑀫𑁂 𑀲𑀯𑀮𑁄𑀓𑀳𑀺𑀢𑁂|t="Because I consider it my '''duty''' to work for the salvation of the whole world"

inc-ash|Aśoka|Rock Edict 6|Girnar|year=c. 256 BCE|url=https://www2.hf.uio.no/polyglotta/index.php?page=record&view=record&vid=365&mid=635002|quote=𑀬 𑀘 𑀓𑀺𑀁𑀘𑀺 𑀫𑀼𑀔𑀢 𑀆𑀜𑀧𑀬𑀸𑀫𑀺 𑀲𑁆𑀯𑀬𑀁 𑀤𑀸𑀧𑀓𑀁 𑀯𑀸 𑀲𑁆𑀭𑀸𑀯𑀸𑀧𑀓𑀁 𑀯𑀸 𑀬 𑀯𑀸 𑀧𑀼𑀦 𑀫𑀳𑀸𑀫𑀸𑀢𑁆𑀭𑁂𑀲𑀼 𑀆𑀘𑀸𑀬𑀺𑀓𑁂 𑀅𑀭𑁄𑀧𑀺𑀢𑀫 '''𑀪𑀯𑀢𑀺''' 𑀢𑀸𑀬 𑀅𑀣𑀸𑀬 𑀯𑀺𑀯𑀸𑀤𑁄 𑀦𑀺𑀛𑀢𑀻 𑀯 𑀲𑀁𑀢𑁄 𑀧𑀭𑀺𑀲𑀸𑀬𑀁 𑀆𑀦𑀁𑀢𑀭𑀁 𑀧𑀝𑀺𑀯𑁂𑀤𑁂𑀢𑀯𑁆𑀬𑀁 𑀫𑁂 𑀲𑀭𑁆𑀯𑀢𑁆𑀭 𑀲𑀭𑁆𑀯𑁂 𑀓𑀸𑀮𑁂|t=And if in the council a dispute arises, or an amendment '''is''' moved, in connexion with any donation or proclamation which I myself am ordering verbally, or (in connexion with) an emergent matter which has been delegated to the Mahāmātras, it must be reported to me immediately, anywhere, at any time.|transauthor=Eugen Hultzsch|transyear=1925

inc-oas|Madhav Kandali|Saptakanda Ramayana|4th canto|year=14th century|quote=হাওৰে বানৰা, মিত্ৰক বিঞ্চিলি,<br>অজ্ঞান '''গাধৱ''' পশু ।<br>ভৃত্য হুয়া তেল, কূঢ বোলৱস,<br>গৃহস্থৰ গাৱে খসু ॥২৯|t=Oh you monkey, you deceived (your) friend, you're a stupid '''donkey'''. Being a servant you smear oil, and pustule on the householder's body.

inc-oas|Madhav Kandali|Saptakanda Ramayana|Ayodhyakanda|year=14th century|quote=ভয় '''সন্তে''' নৃপতিৰ শিহৰিল গাৱ ।<br>মৃতক স্বভাৱ ভৈলা কম্পে হাত পাৱ ॥|t='''From''' fear, (the hairs of the) body of the king stood on ends,<br>he became like a dead, shivering his hands and legs.

inc-oas|Madhav Kandali|Saptakanda Ramayana|Lanka Kanda|year=14th century|quote=ছয় সহস্ৰ বেওঁ উগ্ৰত কলেৱৰ ।<br>সহস্ৰ ধনুৰ মান পথালি '''ডাঙ্গৰ''' ॥|t=His body was six thousand arms long,<br>It was as wide as (lit, as '''big''' in width as) a thousand bows.

inc-oas|Madhav Kandali|Saptakanda Ramayana|Lanka Kanda|year=14th century|quote=বানৰৰ মুণ্ড '''গাণ্ডি''' ফালিয়া পেলাৱে । হাত পাৱ ছিণ্ডে সবে খড়গৰ ঘাৱে ॥|t=They slit the head and '''body''' of the monkey,<br>the hands and legs all tear by the horn.

inc-oas|Madhav Kandali|Saptakanda Ramayana|Sundara Kanda|year=14th century|quote=[[কেহো]] [[কল]] [[কাট্|কাটে]], কেহো [[মাটি]] [[সিঞ্চ্|সিঞ্চে]],<br>কেহো [[আন্|আনি]] [[ঢাল্|ঢালে]] [[জল]] ।<br>[[নুমা|নুমাইবে]] [[পাৰ্|নোৱাৰি]], '''চেঞ্চা''' [[পোড়া]] [[হ|ভৈলা]],<br>[[গাৱ|গাৱত]] [[নাহিকে]] [[বল]] ॥|t=Some cut banana trees, some sprinkle soil,<br>for not being able to extinguish (the fire), they became very tired (lit: '''cold''' and burnt)<br>there's no strength in their body.

inc-oas|Madhav Kandali|Saptakanda Ramayana|Sundara Kanda|year=14th century|quote=কতো কতো অন্তে পুৰে ৰঢ়ে (ৰড়ে?) '''ঢোণ্ডাকাক'''।<br>সম্যকে ভষাৱৈ যেন মনুষ্যৰ বাক ॥|t=There are many ravens who utter (things) in the innermost apartment,<br>they nicely speak like human speech.

inc-oas|Madhav Kandali|Saptakanda Ramayana|Sundara Kanda|year=14th century|quote=কুশ পাৰি তিনিদিন নিদ্ৰায় আছিৰ। ৰামক সাগৰে '''তেহো''' দেখায়ো নিদিল॥|t=He was sleeping there for 3 days spreading Kusha, '''still''' the sea didn't even show itself to Rama.
inc-oaw|TD|HC|quote=बुद्धिहीन तनु जानिके '''सुमिरौं''' पवन-कुमार|trans=Knowing my body to be devoid of intelligence, I remember Hanuman, the son of Vāyu

inc-oaw|TD|R|quote='''बंदउँ''' गुरु पद कंज कृपा सिंधु नररूप हरि।<br>महामोह तम पुंज जासु बचन रबि कर निकर॥5॥|t=I '''bow''' to the lotus feet of the Guru, who is an ocean of mercy and Hari in human form.<br>Whose words are like rays of the sun [dispelling] the mass of darkness of great delusion.

inc-opa|Guru Nanak|Adi Granth|ang 150|transauthor=Dr. Sant Singh Khalsa|transyear=1972|quote=ਵੁਠੈ ਘਾਹੁ ਚਰਹਿ ਨਿਤਿ ਸੁਰਹੀ ਸਾ ਧਨ '''ਦਹੀ''' ਵਿਲੋਵੈ ॥|ts=vuṭṭhai ghāhu carahi niti surahī sā dhana '''dahīṃ''' vilovai.|t=When it rains, the cows always have grass to graze upon, and housewives can churn the '''milk''' into butter.

And the enemies of the Lord, presently after they shall be honoured and exalted, shall come to nothing and vanish like smoke.|notes translation from the Douay Rheims Bible [https://www.ecatholic2000.com/douay-rheims-bible/psalms.shtml#_Toc51143625720 ]

la|Ammianus Marcellinus|Res Gestae|15|12|3|quote=Nec eōrum aliquandō quisquam ut in Italiā mūnus Mārtium pertimēscēns pollicem sibi praecidit, quōs locāliter '''murcōs''' appellant.|trans=Neither are there among them any who, fearing military duty, cuts off, as in Italy, his thumb, which they regionally call '''''murcī'''''.

la|Anonymous (attr. to Petrus, friend of Torello)|Vita Beati Torelli Puppiensis|24|year=14th century|quote=qui erat in lecto gravi febre '''malatus'''|t=[he] who was in bed, '''ill''' with a serious fever|notes=Life of Torello of Poppi the hermit (1202-1282), as cited in Du Cange (ed. L. Favre, 1883-7), "malatus"

la|Apuleius|[[s:la:De deo Socratis#XXII|De deo Socratis 22]]|quote=Sed '''cumprimis''' mirandum est, quod ea, quae minime videri volunt nescire|t=But what is '''particularly''' remarkable, the very things that they least want to seem ignorant of are the ones they refuse to learn

la|Apuleius|Apologia|1|3|quote=Sustineō enim nōn modo meam, vērum etiam philosophiae dēfēnsiōnem, '''cuia''' magnitūdō vel minimam reprehēnsiōnem prō maximō crīmine aspernātur.|t=I am undertaking not just a defence of myself, but one of Philosophy too, '''whose''' greatness rejects even the smallest blame as if it were the greatest crime.

la|Apuleius|Apologia|34|quote=et fortasse an peracute repperisse vobis videbamini, ut quaesisse me fingeretis ad illecebras magicas duo haec marina, '''veretillam''' et virginal; disce enim nomina rerum Latina, quae propterea varie nominai, ut denuo instructus accuses

la|Apuleius|Apologia|34|quote=et fortasse an peracute repperisse vobis videbamini, ut quaesisse me fingeretis ad illecebras magicas duo haec marina, '''veretillum''' et virginal; disce enim nomina rerum Latina, quae propterea varie nominai, ut denuo instructus accuses

la|Apuleius|Metamorphoses|10|13|21|quote=Nam vespera post opiparas cenas earumque splendidissimos apparatus multas numero partes in cellulam suam mei solebant reportare domini: ille porcorum, pullorum, piscium, et cuiusce modi pulmentorum largissimas reliquias, hic panes, crustula, '''lucunculos''', hamos, laterculos, et plura scitamenta mellita. Qui cum se refecturi clausa cellula balneas petissent, oblatis ego divinitus dapibus affatim saginabar.|t=In the evenings, after luxurious dinners with the most brilliant trimmings, my masters used to bring back lots of leftovers to their lodgings: the one brought extremely generous remnants of pork, fowl, fish, and every other kind of meat; the other breads, cookies, '''fritters''', croissants, biscuits, and many other honey-sweetened dainties. As soon as they locked up their room and went to the baths to refresh themselves, I would stuff myself to capacity on those heaven-sent feasts.|transauthor=J. Arthur Hanson|transyear=1989

la|Apuleius|Metamorphoses|10|24|21|quote=Sed ubi fraudis extremae lapsa '''decipulo''' laqueos insidiarum accessit, tunc illa uxor egregia sororem mariti libidinosae furiae stimulis efferata primum quidem nudam flagris ultime verberat, dehinc, quod res erat, clamantem quodque frustra paelicatus indignatione bulliret fratrisque nomen saepius iterantem velut mentitam atque cuncta fingentem titione candenti inter media femina detruso crudelissime necavit.

la|Apuleius|Metamorphoses|2|27|quote=Ēmeditātīs ad haec illa flētibus quamque sānctissimē poterat adiūrāns cūncta nūmina, tantum scelus '''abnuēbat'''.|t=With cries devised just for this, swearing by all the gods as solemnly as she could, she '''denied''' having committed such a crime.
la|Apuleius|Metamorphoses|quote=Iam prīmum omnibus laciniīs sē '''dēvestit''' Pamphilē.|t=First, Pamphile '''undresses''' herself, taking off all her clothes.

la|Apuleius|The Golden Ass|1|23|quote=Et vocātā ancillulā: "Photis" inquit "sarcinulās hospitis susceptās cum fidē conde in illud cubiculum ac simul ex prōmptuāriō oleum unctuī et lintea tersuī et cētera hoc eidem ūsuī prōfer '''ōciter''' et hospitem meum prōdūc ad proximās balneās."|trans=He called the maid and said: "Photis, pick up our guest's luggage and put it carefully in yon chamber, and while you are at it, '''quickly''' fetch from the storeroom oil for anointing, linen towels for rubbing, and all the other things for this use, and lead my guest forth to the next bathhouse."

la|Augustine of Hippo|De Civitate Dei|7|11|quote=Dixerunt eum Victorem, Inuictum, Opitulum, Inpulsorem, Statorem, Centumpedam, Supinalem, Tigillum, Almum, '''Ruminum''' et alia quae persequi longum est. Haec autem cognomina inposuerunt uni deo propter causas potestatesque diuersas, non tamen propter tot res etiam tot deos eum esse coegerunt: quod omnia uinceret, quod a nemine uinceretur, quod opem indigentibus ferret, quod haberet inpellendi, statuendi, stabiliendi, resupinandi potestatem, quod tamquam tigillus mundum contineret ac sustineret, quod aleret omnia, quod ruma, id est mamma, aleret animalia. In his, ut aduertimus, quaedam magna sunt, quaedam exigua; et tamen unus utraque facere perhibetur. Puto inter se propinquiora esse causas rerum atque primordia, propter quas res unum mundum duos deos esse uoluerunt, Iouem atque Ianum, quam continere mundum et mammam dare animalibus; nec tamen propter haec opera duo tam longe inter se ui et dignitate diuersa duo dii esse compulsi sunt; sed unus Iuppiter propter illud Tigillus, propter illud '''Ruminus''' appellatus est. Nolo dicere, quod animalibus mammam praebere sugentibus magis Iunonem potuit decere quam Iouem, praesertim cum esset etiam diua Rumina, quae in hoc opus adiutorium illi famulatumue praeberet. Cogito enim posse responderi, et ipsam Iunonem nihil aliud esse quam Iouem, secundum illos Valerii Sorani uersus, ubi dictum est: Iuppiter omnipotens regum rerumque deumque Progenitor genetrixque deum. Quare ergo dictus est et '''Ruminus''', cum diligentius fortasse quaerentibus ipse inueniatur esse etiam illa diua Rumina? Si enim maiestate deorum recte uidebatur indignum, ut in una spica alter ad curam geniculi, altera ad folliculi pertineret: quanto est indignius unam rem infimam, id est ut mammis alantur animalia, duorum deorum potestate curari, quorum sit unus Iuppiter, rex ipse cunctorum, et hoc agat non saltem cum coniuge sua, sed cum ignobili nescio qua Rumina, nisi quia ipse est etiam ipsa Rumina; '''Ruminus''' fortasse pro sugentibus maribus, Rumina pro feminis. Dicerem quippe noluisse illos Ioui femininum nomen inponere, nisi et in illis uersibus "progenitor genetrixque" diceretur, et inter eius alia cognomina legerem, quod etiam Pecunia uocaretur, quam deam inter illos minuscularios inuenimus et in quarto libro commemorauimus. Sed cum et mares et feminae habeant pecuniam, cur non et Pecunia et Pecunius appellatus sit, sicut Rumina et '''Ruminus''', ipsi uiderint.|trans=The pagans have called Jupiter by the titles Victor, Invictus, Opitulus, Impulsor, Stator, Centumpeda, Supinalis, Tigillus, Almus, '''Ruminus''', and still others which it would be tedious to enumerate. They have applied all these names to one god for various reasons and because of his various powers. But they have not, though there are so many functions, compelled him to become as many different gods. The functions are that he is victor over all, and invincible, and brings help to the needy, and has the power of impelling, of causing to stand, of stabilizing, and of laying flat; because he maintains and sustains the world like a beam; because he nourishes all things, and nourishes all animals by the breast (ruma). Among these functions, as we observe, some are important and some unimportant, yet one god is supposed to perform both kinds. In my judgement there is a closer relation between the causes of things and their beginnings, for which they would have one universe identical with two gods, Jupiter and Janus, than there is between maintaining the world and giving the breast to animals. However, there was no necessity for having two gods even for two tasks so different from each other in display of power and dignity; the one god Jupiter was called Tigillus for the one task and '''Ruminus''' for the other. I will not say that it would have been more appropriate for Juno than for Jupiter to furnish the breast to sucking animals, especially since there was also a goddess Rumina to furnish her help and service for this work. For I think the reply can be made that Juno herself is none other than Jupiter, according to these verses of Valerius Soranus, where it is said: 'Jupiter, mighty Father of kings and of gods and / of all things, / Mother as well of the gods . . .' Why then was he also called '''Ruminus''', when, if perhaps we were to inquire more carefully, we might find that he is also identical with the goddess Rumina? If there was good reason for supposing it unsuitable to the dignity of the gods, in the case of one stalk of wheat, that one god should have the care of the knots, another that of the sheath, how much more unworthy is it that one low task, namely, to see that animals get nourishment from the breast, should require the power of two deities. One of them was Jupiter, himself king of all things, and he performed this task not along with his wife, but with some unknown Rumina. Unless he is himself Rumina—'''Ruminus''' perhaps for suckling males and Rumina for females. Of course I might say that they were unwilling to give Jupiter a woman’s name, except that it was said of him in those verses I quoted, “Father and Mother as well,” and except that among his other names I have read that he was also called Pecunia. I found this goddess among those petty gods, and have mentioned her in the fourth book. But since both males and females have money, why was Jupiter not called both Pecunia and Pecunius, as he is called Rumina and '''Ruminus'''? I leave the answer to them.|transauthor=William M. Green|transyear=1963

la|Augustine|City of God|13|3|quote=Quāpropter fatendum est prīmōs quidem hominēs ita fuisse īnstitūtōs, ut, sī nōn peccāssent, nūllum mortis experīrentur genus; sed eōsdem prīmōs peccātōrēs ita fuisse morte multātōs, ut etiam quidquid dē eōrum stirpe esset exortum eādem poenā tenērētur '''obnoxium'''.|trans=Therefore it must be said that the first humans were taught that, were they not to have sinned, they wouldn't have experienced any kind of death, and that the first sinners were rewarded with death so that whatever is born of their kind be held '''liable''' to the same punishment.

la|Augustine|In Psalmum 25 enarratio 2 (sermo ad plebem)|quote=Et '''ecce hoc''' est deponere veterem hominem, et induere novum: Quapropter, deponentes mendacium, loquimini veritatem, unusquisque cum proximo suo: quia sumus invicem membra.|t=And '''''this''''' is to shed the old self and put on the new self. Therefore, as you put away lying, speak the truth, each to your neighbour, for we are members (of one body) to each other (Ephesians 4:25).

la|Aulus Gellius|Noctes Atticae|15|10|2|quote=Id cum accideret in dies crebrius neque animis earum mori perseverantium medicina adhiberi quiret, decrevisse Milesios ut virgines quae corporibus suspensis demortuae forent, ut hae omnes nudae, cum eodem laqueo quo essent '''praevinctae''' efferrentur.|t=When this happened more frequently every day, and no remedy had any effect on their resolve to die, the Milesians passed a decree that all those maidens who committed suicide by hanging should be carried to the grave naked, along with the same rope by which they had destroyed themselves.|transauthor=John C. Rolfe

la|Aulus Gellius|Noctes Atticae|19.7|quote= Cetera enim, quae videbantur nimium poetica, ex prosae orationis usu alieniora praetermisimus; veluti fuit quod de Nestore ait "trisaeclisenex" et "dulciorelocus", item quod de tumidis magnisque fluctibus "fluctibus," inquit, "'''multigrumis'''" et flumina gelu concreta "tegmine" esse "onychino" dixit et quae multiplica ludens conposuit, quale illud est, quod vituperones suos "subductisupercilicarptores" appellavit.|trans=But others we passed over as too poetic and unsuited to use in prose; for example, when he calls Nestor ''trisaeclisenex'', or “an old man who had lived three generations” and ''dulciorelocus isle'', or “that sweet-mouthed speaker,” when he calls great swelling waves '''''multigruma''''', or “great-hillocked,” and says that rivers congealed by the cold have an ''onychinum tegimen'', or “an onyx covering”; also his many humorous multiple compounds, as when he calls his detractors ''subductisupercilicarptores'', or “carpers with raised eye-brows.”

la|Aulus Gellius|Noctes Atticae|9|6|quote="capio captus," '''"captito"'''; “facio factus,” “factito.” Sic igitur “actito” producte in prima syllaba pronuntiandum, quoniam ex eo fit quod est “ago” et “actus.”|t=capio captus, '''captito'''; facio factus, factito. So then actito should be pronounced with the first syllable long, since it is from ago and actus.

la|Aulus Gellius|Noctes Atticae|XIII|XXIII|I|thru=II|brackets=1|text=Conprecationes deum inmortalium, quae ritu Romano fiunt, expositae sunt in libris sacerdotum populi Romani et in plerisque antiquis orationibus. In his scriptum est: "Luam Saturni, Salaciam Neptuni, Horam Quirini, Virites Quirini, Maiam Volcani, '''Heriem''' Iunonis, Moles Martis Nerienemque Martis".

la|Ausonius|Epigrams|62 De Glaucia inmatura Morte praevento|1|quote=Laeta bis '''octono''' tibi iam sub consule pubes / cingebat teneras, Glaucia adulte, genas.|t=Already until thy twice '''eighth''' year, glad youth was wreathing thy tender cheeks, grown Glaucias.

la|Ausonius|Epistularum|quote=Nam populi coetus et compita sordida rixis<br>fastidientes cernimus<br>angustas fervere vias et '''congrege''' volgo<br>nomen plateas perdere,<br>turbida congestis referitur vocibus echo:<br>‘Tene, feri, duc, da, cave!’<br>sus lutulenta fugit, rabidus canis impete saevo<br>et impares plaustro boves,<br>

la|Bede|Historia ecclesiastica gentis Anglorum|libre I|capitulum 32|quote=Sī enim, quod '''absit''', verba eius postpōnitis, quandō eum omnipotēns Deus poterit audīre prō vōbīs, quem vōs neglegitis audīre prō Deō?|t=If in fact, and '''God forbid!''' you scorn his teachings, when God omnipotent were to hear him in your favor, would you neglect hearing him as messenger of our God?

la|Bede|Historia ecclesiastica|2|1|quote=Nam mutato repente habitu saeculari '''monasterium''' petiit, in quo tanta perfectionis gratia coepit conuersari, ut, sicut ipse postea flendo solebat adtestari, animo illius labentia cuncta subteressent, ut rebus omnibus, quae uoluuntur, emineret, ut nulla nisi caelestia cogitare soleret, ut etiam retentus corpore ipsa iam carnis claustra contemplatione transiret, ut mortem quoque, quae pene cunctis poena est, uidelicet ut ingressum uitae, et laboris sui praemium amaret.|trans=For soon quitting his secular habit, he repaired to a '''monastery''', wherein he began to behave himself with so much grace of perfection that (as he was afterwards wont with tears to testify) his mind was above all transitory things; that he despised all that is subject to change; that he used to think of nothing but what was heavenly; that whilst detained by the body, he by contemplation broke through the bonds of flesh; and that he loved death, which is a terror to almost all men, as the entrance into life, and the reward of his labours.

la|c. 4th century, Testamentum Porcelli|quote = "Venī hūc, ēversor domī, '''solivertiātor''', fugitīve porcelle, et hodiē tibi dirimō vītam!"|t = Come here, house-destroyer, '''garden-destroyer''', fugitive piglet, and today I destroy your life!

la|C.
