la|Seneca the Younger|Epistulae Morales ad Lucilium|1|2|4|quote=Aliquid cotīdiē adversus paupertātem, aliquid adversus mortem auxilī comparā, nec minus adversus cēterās pestēs; et cum multa percurreris, ūnum excerpe quod illō diē '''concoquās'''.|trans=Provide yourself daily with something [written that is] helpful against poverty, something against death, and no less against other plagues; and when you have run through many [good examples], select one '''for you to reflect upon and thoroughly digest''' that same day.<br/>(A few lines prior Seneca compares reading to proper digestion, so here he means thinking more deeply about an excerpt from a book, and no mere passing notice.)

la|Seneca the Younger|Epistulae Morales ad Lucilium|47|12|quote=“At ego,” inquis, “nūllum habeō dominum.” Bona aetās est: forsitan habēbis. Nescīs quā aetāte Hecubā servīre '''coeperit''', quā Croesus, quā Dārēī māter, quā Platōn, quā Diogenēs?|trans=“But I have no master,” you say. Your age is appropriate: perhaps you will have one. Do you not know at what age [[Hecuba]] '''began''' to be enslaved; or [[Croesus]]; or ([[Sisygambis]]), the mother of [[Darius]]; or [[Plato]]; or [[Diogenes]]?<br/>(Third-person singular perfect active subjunctive of ''coepī'' used here in an indirect question following ''nescīs''.)

la|Seneca the Younger|Epistulae Morales ad Lucilium|47|17|quote=“Servus est.” Sed fortasse līber animō. “Servus est.” Hoc illī '''nocēbit'''?|trans=“He is a slave.” But perhaps he’s free in spirit. “He is a slave.” [Why] '''will''' this '''bring harm''' to that [man]?<br/>(Third-person singular future indicative verb ''nocēbit'' forms a question that takes the dative case for its object: ''illī''.)

la|Seneca the Younger|Epistulae morales ad Lucilium|87|9|quote=M. Cato Censorius, quem tam rei publicae fuit nasci quam Scipionem (alter enim cum hostibus nostris bellum, alter cum moribus gessit), cantherio vehebatur et '''hippoperis''' quidem impositis, ut secum utilia portaret.|t=Cato the Elder, him being born indeed healsome for the society like Scipio (for the one fought war with our foes, the other without our mores), rode along with a gelding and merely two '''saddlebags''' on it to stow his belongings.

la|Seneca the Younger|Medea|1|13|quote=nunc, nunc adeste, sceleris '''ultrices''' deae, crinem solutis squalidae serpentibus, atram cruentis manibus amplexae facem|trans=Now, now be present, you goddesses, you '''avengeresses''' of crime; come with your hair adorned with loose, squalid serpents, come embracing the black torch with your blood-stained hands.

la|Seneca the Younger|Naturales quaestiones|II|56,1|text=Tonitrua nos '''pluraliter''' dicimus; antiqui autem tonitruum dixerunt aut tonum.|t=We use the word thunder '''in the plural''', but our forefathers used it in the singular or called it ''tonum''.

la|Servius|In Vergilii Aeneidem commentarii|1|651|quote=hinc etiam apud Romanos '''Thalassio''' invocatur. cum enim in raptu Sabinarum plebeius quidam raptam pulcherrimam duceret, ne ei auferretur ab aliis, Thalassionis eam ducis nobilis esse simulavit, cuius nomine fuit puellae tuta virginitas.|trans=Because of this, "'''Thalassio'''" is also invoked amongst the Romans. When, during the rape of the Sabines, the plebeians were leading a certain captured beauty, they pretended she was of a noble leader, by whose name her virginity was safeguarded, so that others would not take her from Thalassius.

la|Sextus Julius Frontinus|Strategemata|1|10|4|1|year=c. 84-96 AD|quote='''Scorylo''', dux Dacorum, cum sciret dissociatum armis civilibus populum Romanum neque tamen sibi temptandum arbitraretur, quia externo bello posset concordia inter cives coalescere, duos canes in conspectu popularium commisit iisque acerrime inter ipsos pugnantibus lupum ostendit,quem protinus canes omissa inter se ira aggressi sunt: quo exemplo prohibuit barbaros ab impetu Romanis profuturo.
la|Sextus Pompeius Festus|De verborum significatione|344.34|quote="...<Spa>tiātōrem, '''errātōrem''' Catō in M."

la|Sextus Pompeius Festus|De Verborum Significatione|quote=Poenitam offam Naevius appellpat '''absegmen''' carnis cum coda: antiqui autem offam vocabant abscisum globi forma, ut manu glomeratam pultem

la|Sidonius Apollinaris|Epistolae|year=c. 489|quote=Ipse hic Parthicus Arsaces precatur, aulae Susidis ut tenere culmen possit foedere sub stipendiali. Nam quod partibus arma Bosphoranis grandi hinc surgere sentit apparatu, maestam Persida iam sonum ad duelli ripa '''Euphratide''' vix putat tuendam; qui cognata licet sibi astra fingens Phoebea tumeat propinquitate, mortalem hic tamen implet obsecrando.|t=Here even the Parthian Arsaces prays that he may be enabled to keep the towering palace of Susa under covenant of tribute; for perceiving that an armament with a vast muster of warlike might is surging up from here to take the side of Constantinople, he thinks that Persia, depressed at the very sound of war, can scarcely be defended by '''the Euphrates’''' bank; and although he feigns himself related to the stars, and vaunts his kinship with Phoebus the Sun, here in Bordeaux he plays a mortal’s part by making supplication.|transauthor=W. B. Anderson|transyear=1965

la|Sidonius Apollinaris|Letters|7|7|4|quote=parum in commūne cōnsulitis; et, cum in concilium convenītis, nōn tam cūrae est pūblicīs medērī perīculīs quam prīvātīs studēre fortūnīs; quod utique saepe diūque facientēs iam nōn prīmī '''comprōvinciālium''' coepistis esse, sed ultimī.|t=You consider the common good too little; and, when you come together into a council, there is not so much concern to remedy public dangers than to pursue private fortunes. At any rate, because of you doing this often and for a long time, you have already begun to be not the first of the '''comprovincial''', but the last.
la|Statius|Achilleid|1|917|quote=Nec tamen '''abnuerit''' generō sē iungere tālī.|t=Nor will he '''refuse''' to join with such a son in law.

la|Statius|Silvae|5|2|136|quote=an iuga Pannoniae mutatoresque domorum / Sauromatas quaties? an te '''septenus''' habebit / Hister et umbroso circumflua coniuge Peuce?|t=Or shall you shake Pannonia’s ridges and nomad Sarmatians? Or shall '''sevenfold''' Hister have you, and Peuce, surrounded by her spouse’s shady stream?|transauthor=D. R. Shackleton Bailey|transyear=2015

la|Suetonius|De vita Caesarum|2|10|quote=Omnium bellōrum initium et causam hinc sūmpsit: nihil convenientius dūcēns quam necem avunculī vindicāre tuērīque ācta, '''cōnfestim''' ut Apollōniā rediit, Brūtum Cassiumque et vī necopīnantīs et, quia prōvīsum perīcu­lum subterfūgerant, lēgibus adgredī reōsque caedis absentīs dēferre statuit.|trans=The source and cause of all the wars he took from this: holding nothing more fitting than to avenge his uncle and maintain the validity of his enactments, '''immediately''' on returning from Apollonia he resolved to take the unexpecting Brutus and Cassius by force as well as to resort to laws and prosecute them for murder in their absence, as they had fled the foreseen danger.

la|Suetonius|De vita Caesarum|4|37|quote=Nepōtātus sūmptibus omnium prōdigōrum ingenia superāvit, commentus novum balneārum ūsum, portentōsissima genera cibōrum atque cēnārum, ut calidīs frīgidīsque unguentīs lavārētur, prētiōsissima margarīta acētō liquefacta sorbēret, convīvīs ex aurō pānēs et '''obsōnia''' appōneret, aut frūgī hominem esse oportere dictitāns aut Caesarem.|trans=In the devices of his profuse expenditure, he surpassed all the prodigals that ever lived; inventing a new kind of bath, with strange dishes and suppers, washing in precious unguents, both warm and cold, drinking pearls of immense value dissolved in vinegar, and serving up for his guests loaves and other '''victuals''' modelled in gold; often saying, " that a man ought either to be a good economist or an emperor."|transyear=1889|transauthor=Alexander Thomson

la|Suetonius|De vita Caesarum|5|41|quote=Historiam in adulēscentia hortante T. Līviō, Sulpiciō vērō Flāvō etiam adiuvante, scrībere adgressus est. Et cum prīmum frequentī auditōriō commīsisset, aegrē perlēgit refrīgerātus saepe ā sēmet ipsō. Nam cum initiō recitātiōnis dēfrāctīs complūribus subsellīs obēsitāte cuiusdam rīsus exortus esset, nē sēdātō quidem tumultū temperāre potuit, quīn ex intervāllō subinde factī reminīscerētur '''cachinnōs'''que revocāret.|trans=In his youth he undertook to write a history, urged by [[w:Livy|Livy]] and helped by Sulpicius Flavus. And when he first called together a numerous auditory, he read it poorly and often interrupted by no one but himself. For when, at the beginning of the recitation, laughter was roused by more benches broken by somebody's fatness, not even with the tumult sedated could he calm down, but from time to time remembered the event and brought '''laughter''' back.

la|Suetonius|De Vita Caesarum|87|2|quote=Ponit assidue et pro stulto "baceolum" et pro pullo "pulleiaceum" et pro cerrito "vacerrosum" et "vapide" se habere pro male et "'''betizare'''" pro languere, quod vulgo "lachanizare" dicitur|t=He also habitually used "''baceolus''" (dolt) for "''stultus''" (fool), "''pulleiaceus''" (darkish) for "''pullus''" (dark), "''vacerrosus''" (blockhead) for "''cerritus''" (mad); also "''vapide se habere''" (to feel flat) for "''male se habere''" (to feel bad) and '''"betizare"''' (to be like a beet) for "''languere''" (to be weak) which is "''lanchanizare''" in vulgar terms

la|Tac.|Germania|34|2|1|quote=[[ipsum]] [[quīn]] [[etiam]] [[Ōceanum]] [[illā]] [[temptāvimus]]; [[et]] [[superesse]] [[adhūc]] '''Herculis Columnās''' [[fāma]] [[vulgāvit]], [[sīve]] [[adiit]] [[Herculēs]], [[seu]] [[quicquid]] [[ubīque]] [[magnificum]] [[est]], [[in]] [[clāritātem]] [[ejus]] [[referre]] [[cōnsēnsimus]].|trans=Indeed, we even attempted the Ocean itself with that, and the rumour spread that the '''Pillars of Hercules''' still exist, whether Hercules reached them or we agreed to attribute whatever is magnificent anywhere in the world to his glory.
la|Tacitus|Annales|1|4|quote=hunc et prima ab infantia eductum in domo '''regnatrice'''|t=From the earliest infancy he had been raised in an '''imperial''' house.

la|Tacitus|Annales|11|2|quote=Ipsa ad perniciem Poppaeae festinat subditis qui terrore carceris ad '''voluntariam mortem''' propellerent.|trans=She (Messalina) is accelerating Poppaea's destruction by suborned agents that they might drive her with a great fear of prison to (commit) '''suicide'''.

la|Tacitus|Annales|3|61|quote=Prīmī omnium Ephesiī adiēre, memorantēs nōn, ut vulgus crēderet, Diānam atque Apollinem Dēlō genitōs: esse apud sē Cenchrium amnem, lūcum Ortygiam, ubi Lātōnam partū gravidam et oleae, quae tum etiam maneat, '''adnīsam''' ēdidisse ea nūmina, deōrumque monitū sacrātum nemus, atque ipsum illīc Apollinem post interfectōs Cyclōpās lovis īram vītāvisse.|trans=First went the Ephesians, reminding that Diana and Apollo weren't born, as people believe, on Delos: that in their region there was the river Cenchrius and the grove Ortygia, where Latona, pregnant with her issue and '''leant''' on an olive tree which survives even these days, gave birth to those gods; and the grove was sacred by the gods' injunction, and that Apollo himself had avoided the anger of Jupiter after killing the Cyclops.

la|Tacitus|Annals|13|14|quote=Nōn '''abnuere''' se, quīn cūncta īnfēlīcīs domūs mala patefīerent, suae in prīmīs nūptiae, suum venēficium.|t=She didn't '''reject''' that all the evils of the unhappy house be made known, her marriage first of all, and her poisoning.
la|Ter.|Heaut.|271|thru=273|text=ego te autem novi quăm ĕsse soleas inpotens;<br>inversa verba, eversas cervices tuas,<br>gemitus '''screatus''' tussis risus abstine.

la|Terence|Heauton Timorumenos|357|quote=Hīc sīquid nōbīs forte advorsī ēvēnerit,<br>tibi erunt parāta verba, huic hominī verbera:<br>quāpropter haec rēs '''ne‿ŭtĭquam''' neglēctust mihi.|notes=Iambic senarius|t=If by chance anything here goes wrong for us,<br>There will be words for you, lashes for myself here:<br>Therefore this matter is '''by no means''' something for me to disregard.

la|Tertullian|Ad nationes libri duo|1|8|quote=Age nunc, perseuerauerit Philomelae medicamentis ⟨ . . . .⟩ quam et ipsam prudentiores non linguae caede, sed ⟨ra⟩p⟨ti pu⟩doris rubore mutam interpretantur. Si ergo vixit, ⟨potuit⟩ effutire aliquid : obtusum et exarticulatum sonum tinnitumque sine modulatu labellorum, expanso ore, lingua stupente de solis faucibus cogi licet. Id fors tunc infantes, quia unicum, facilius commentati paulo modulatius, utpote '''linguatul⟨i⟩''' ⟨in⟩ inventum alicuius interpretationis impegeri<n>t.|t=Come, even suppose that by the remedies of a Philomela she retained her life, in the way supposed by wisest persons, who account for the dumbness not by cutting out the tongue, but from the blush of shame; if on such a supposition she lived, she would still be able to blurt out some dull sound. And a shrill inarticulate noise from opening the mouth only, without any modulation of the lips, might be forced from the mere throat, though there were no tongue to help. This, it is probable, the infants readily imitated, and the more so because it was the only sound; only they did it a little more neatly, as they '''had tongues'''; and then they attached to it a definite signification. |transauthor=Peter Holmes|transyear=1869

la|Tertullian|Apologeticus|11|8|quote=Ceterum si propterea Liber deus, quod vitem demonstravit, male cum Lucullo actum est, qui primus '''cerasia''' ex Ponto Italiae promulgavit, quod non est propterea consecratus ut frugis novae auctor, qui ostensor.|trans=But if Bacchus is made a god because he discovered the grapevine, Lucullus, who first introduced '''cherries''' from Pontus to Italy, has not been fairly dealt with; for as the discoverer of a new fruit, he has not, as though he were its creator, been awarded divine honours.

la|Tertullian|De Pallio|1|3|quote=Equidem haud mīror prae documentō superiōre. Nam et ariētem (nōn quem Laberius reciprocicornem ait, lānicutem et '''testitrahum''', sed trabēs māchina est quae mūrōs frangere mīlitat) nēminī unquam adhūc lībrātum illa dicitur Carthago, 'studiīs asperrima bellī', prīma omnium armāsse in oscillum pendulī impetūs, commentāta vim tormentī dēbile pecoris caput vindicantis.|trans=I'm not surprised at all on account of a previous example. For the ram too (not the one whom [[w:Decimus Laberius|Laberius]] calls reciprocally-horned, wooly-skinned and '''testicle-dragging''', but the siege weapon that smashes walls), not swung into anyone yet, Carthage, 'the toughest in the arts of war', is said to have first mobilised in the oscillation of violence, having realised the power of the engine by analogy of the anger of the beast that avenges itself with its head.

la|Tertullian|De spectaculis|27|quote=Nemo venenum temperat felle et elleboro, sed conditis pulmentis et bene saporatis, et plurimum dulcibus id mali inicit. Ita et diabolus letale quod conficit rebus dei gratissimis et acceptissimis imbuit. Omnia illic seu fortia seu honesta seu sonora seu canora seu subtilia [perinde/proinde] habe ac [si] stillicidia mellis de '''libacunculo''' venenato nec tanti gulam facias voluptatis quanti periculum per suavitatem.|t=No one mixes poison with gall and hellebore; no, it is into delicacies well made, well flavoured, and, for the most part, sweet things, that he drops the venom. So does the devil; the deadly draught he brews, he flavours with the most agreeable, the most welcome gifts of God. So count all you find there—brave and honest, resounding, musical, exquisite—as so much honey dripping from a poisoned '''bit of pastry'''; and do not count your appetite for the pleasure worth the risk in the sweetness.|transauthor=T.R. Glover<ref>[https://archive.org/details/apologydespectac00tertuoft/page/292/ Tertullian. Apology. de Spectaculis. with an English Translation by T.R. Glover.]</ref>|transyear=1931

la|Varro|De Lingua Latina|5|110|quote='''Insicia''' ab eo quod insecta caro, ut in Carmine Saliorum <prosicium> est, quod in extis dicitur nunc prosectum.|t=''Insicia'' ‘minced meat’ from this, that the meat is ''insecta'' ‘cut up,’ just as in the ''Song of the Salii'' the word ''prosicium'' ‘slice’ is used, for which, in the offering of the vitals, the word ''prosectum'' is now used.|transauthor=Roland G. Kent|transyear=1938

la|Varro|Res Rusticae|1|49|2|quote=Dicam, inquit, de fructibus maturis capiendis. Primum de pratis summissis herba, cum crescere desiit et aestu arescit, subsecari falcibus debet et, quaad perarescat, furcillis versari; cum perarvit, de his manipulos fieri ac vehi ad villam; tum de pratis stipulam rastellis eradi atque addere faenisiciae cumulum. Quo facto '''sicilienda''' prata, id est falcibus consectanda quae faenisices praeterierunt ac quasi herba tuberosum reliquerunt campum. A qua sectione arbitror dictum '''''sicilire''''' pratum.|trans=he continued: “I shall discuss next the subject of harvesting the ripe crops. First the grass on the hay-meadows should be cut close with the sickle when it ceases to grow and begins to dry from the heat, and turned with the fork while it is drying out; when it is quite dry it should be made into bundles and hauled to the barn. Then the loose hay from the meadows should be raked up and added to the hay-pile. After doing this you should ‘'''sickle'''’ the meadows—that is, cut with the sickle what the mowers have passed over, leaving the field humped, as it were, with tufts of grass. I suppose the verb '''''sicilire''''', used with meadow as object, is derived from this cutting (''sectio'').|transauthor=W. D. Hooper, Harrison Boyd Ash.|transyear=1934
la|Verg.|A.|4|615|thru=618|text=bellō audācis populī uexātus et armīs,<br>fīnibus '''extorris''', complexū āuulsus Iūlī<br>auxilium implōret uideatque indigna suōrum<br>fūnera;{{...

la|Vergil|Aeneid|7|568|thru=571|quote=Hīc '''specus''' horrendum et saevī spīracula Dītis<br>mōnstrantur, ruptōque ingēns Acherōnte vorāgō<br>pestiferās aperit faucēs, quīs condita Erīnȳs,<br>invīsum nūmen, terrās caelumque levābat.|trans=Here the horrible '''cave''' and the breathing hole of the cruel Dis<br>is shown, and a giant whirlpool, with the Acheron burst forth,<br>opens its pestilential jaws, in which Erinys,<br>hated god, relieved the Earth and the heavens by hiding.

la|Vergil|Georgics|2|346|thru=353|text=Quod superest, quaecumque premes virgulta per agros,<br>Sparge fimo '''pingui''' et multa memor occule terra,<br>Aut lapidem bibulum aut squalentis infode conchas;<br>Inter enim labentur aquae tenuisque subibit<br>Halitus atque animos tollent sata; iamque reperti,<br>Qui saxo super atque ingentis pondere testae<br>Urgerent; hoc effusos munimen ad imbris,<br>Hoc, ubi hiulca siti findit canis aestifer arva.|t=For the rest, whate'er<br>The sets thou plantest in thy fields, thereon<br>Strew refuse '''rich''', and with abundant earth<br>Take heed to hide them, and dig in withal<br>Rough shells or porous stone, for therebetween<br>Will water trickle and fine vapour creep,<br>And so the plants their drooping spirits raise.<br>Aye, and there have been, who with weight of stone<br>Or heavy potsherd press them from above;<br>This serves for shield in pelting showers, and this<br>When the hot dog-star chaps the fields with drought.|transauthor={{w|James B. Greenough

la|Virgil|Aeneid|1|527|thru=528|quote=“Nōn nōs aut ferrō Libycōs populāre Penātīs<br/>vēnimus, aut raptās ad lītora vertere '''praedās'''.”|trans=''“We come neither to pillage by sword the household gods of Libya, nor to drive captured '''plunder''' to the shores.”''<br/>(The plunder “driven” or “turned” implies taking herds of animals; it might also mean taking humans into slavery.)

la|Virgil|Aeneid|1|569|thru=571|quote=“Seu vōs Hesperiam magnam Sāturniaque arva,<br/>sīve Erycīs fīnīs rēgemque optātis Acestēn,<br/>auxiliō tūtōs '''dīmittam''', opibusque iuvābō.”|trans=“Whatever your choices – great Hesperia and the fields of Saturn, or the land of Eryx and King Acestes – '''I shall send''' [you] '''forth''' with protective escorts, and help with supplies.” – Queen Dido

la|Virgil|Aeneid|1|67|thru=68|quote=“Gēns '''inimīca''' mihī Tyrrhēnum nāvigat aequor,<br/>Īlium in Ītaliam portāns vīctōsque Penātēs.”|trans=''“A race '''inimical''' to me is sailing the calm Tyrrhenian Sea, bringing Ilium to Italy, along with [their] conquered household-gods.”''<br/>(Juno is describing the Trojan war survivors led by Aeneas. See: {{w|Tyrrhenian Sea

la|Virgil|Aeneid|1|88|thru=89|quote='''Ēripiunt''' subitō nūbēs caelumque diemque<br/>Teucrōrum ex oculīs; pontō nox incubat ātra.|trans=''Stormclouds suddenly '''take away''' both sky and day[light] from the eyes of the Trojans; black night broods upon the sea.''<br/>(“They take away, suddenly, stormclouds…”: The poet exploits Latin’s flexible word-order and begins line 88 with the energetic verb “ēripiunt.” Note: The Trojans were “Teucrians” or descendants of {{w|King Teucer

la|Virgil|Aeneid|2|279|thru=280|quote=“[...] Ultrō flēns ipse vidēbar<br/>compellāre virum et maestās '''exprōmere''' vōcēs: [...].”|trans=“[In my dream,] spontaneously weeping myself, I seemed to address [Hector] and '''to utter''' sorrowful words: [...].”

la|Virgil|Aeneid|2|285|thru=286|quote=“‘[...] Quae causa indigna '''serēnōs''' / foedāvit voltūs? [...].’”|trans=''“‘What shameful cause disfigured your '''serene''' face?’”''<br/>(Aeneas dreams he is speaking to the dead and disfigured Hector. The Latin plural “serenos voltus,” here translated as English singular, implies a heroic character which projects steadfast calm despite changing circumstances.)

la|Virgil|Aeneid|2|289|quote=“‘Heu fuge, nāte deā, tēque hīs, ait, '''ēripe''' flammīs.’”|trans=[Aeneas recalls Hector’s dire warning:] “‘Alas! Flee, goddess-born,’ [Hector] says, ‘and '''deliver''' yourself from these flames!’”

la|Virgil|Aeneid|2|48|thru=49|quote=“Equō nē crēdite, Teucrī.<br/>Quicquid id est, timeō Danaōs, et dōna '''ferentīs'''.”|trans=“Trojans, do not trust the horse! Whatever it is, I fear the Greeks, even [when they are] '''bearing''' gifts.” – Laocoön

la|Virgil|Aeneid|2|49|quote=[[w:en:Timeo Danaos et dona ferentes|Equo ne credite, Teucri! '''Quidquid''' id est, timeo Danaos et dona ferentes]].|trans=Do not trust the horse, Trojans! '''Whatever''' it is, I fear the Greeks even if they are bearing gifts.

la|Virgil|Aeneid|2|581|thru=582|quote=“‘Occiderit ferrō Priamus? Troiā ārserit ignī?<br/>Dardanium '''totiēns''' sūdārit sanguine lītus?’”|trans=“‘[After] Priam has fallen by the sword? With Troy consumed by fire? The Dardan shore having sweated blood '''so many times'''?’”<br/>(An expression of surprise or indignation posed as questions using three future perfect verbs: ''occiderit, ārserit, sūdārit.'' Here, “totiēns” refers to the bloodshed throughout the Trojan War.)

la|Virgil|Aeneid|2|606|thru=607|quote=“‘[...] Tū nē qua parentis / '''iussa''' timē, neu praeceptīs pārēre recūsā.’”|trans=''“‘You, [my son] – That which [your divine] parent '''has ordered''', fear not, nor refuse to obey [what she] has instructed.’”''<br/>(Aeneas recalls the words of his mother, Venus.)

la|Virgil|Aeneid|3|192|thru=193|quote=Postquam altum tenuēre ratēs, nec iam amplius ūllae<br/>adpārent terrae, caelum '''undique''' et '''undique''' pontus|trans=“After [our] ships held the deep, now neither [was there] any more sight of land: the sky [was] '''all around''' [us], and '''everywhere''' the sea.”<br/>(An example of [[hyperbole]] or exaggeration in a figure of speech.)

la|Virgil|Aeneid|4|129-130|quote=Ōceanum intereā surgēns Aurōra relīquit.<br/>It portīs '''iubare''' exortō dēlēcta iuventūs [...].|trans=Meanwhile Aurora, rising, departs from Oceanus. [Then,] '''with Dawn’s radiance''' having shone forth, chosen youth go out the [city] gates [...].

la|Virgil|Aeneid|4|141-142|quote=[...] Ipse ante aliōs pulcherrimus omnis<br/>īnfert sē socium Aenēās atque agmina '''iungit'''.|trans=[The Trojan leader] himself, before all others, most handsome — Aeneas comes forward as [Dido’s] companion, and also '''unites''' [their combined] ranks.<br/>(Symbolic of personal, civic and military alliances as Dido and Aeneas, Carthaginians and Trojans, join in regal formation for the hunt.)

la|Virgil|Aeneid|4|213|thru=214|quote=“[...] cōnūbia '''nostra''' / reppulit, ac dominum Aenēān in rēgna recēpit.”|trans=''“[The woman …] has rejected '''our''' marriage-offer, and accepted Aeneas as lord in her realm.”''<br/>(King Iarbas, whom Queen Dido has rejected, refers to himself using the “royal we.”'')

la|Virgil|Aeneid|4|271|quote=“Quid '''struis'''? Aut quā spē Libycīs teris ōtia terrīs?”|trans=''“What '''do you think you are doing'''? Or with what [false] hope are you wasting idle hours in the lands of Libya?”''<br/>(Aeneas is overseeing building projects in Carthage just as Mercury arrives to confront him; Mercury’s criticism, however, is less about the physical construction than it is about self-deception. Other translations: West, 1990: “What do you have in mind?”; Fagles, 2006: “What are you plotting now?”; Bartsch, 2020: “What’s your plan?”)

la|Virgil|Aeneid|4|301|thru=303|quote=[...] quālīs commōtīs excitā sacrīs<br/>'''Thyias''', ubi audītō stimulant trietērica Bacchō<br/>orgia, nocturnusque vocat clāmōre Cithaerōn.|trans=[...] like a '''Maenad''', thrilled by the shaken emblems of the god, when the biennial festival rouses her, and, hearing the Bacchic cry, Mount Cithaeron summons her by night with its noise.|transauthor=A. S. Kline|transyear=2002

la|Virgil|Aeneid|4|356|thru=358|quote=“Nunc etiam '''interpres''' dīvom, Iove missus ab ipsō —<br/>testor utrumque caput — celerīs mandāta per aurās<br/>dētulit [...].|trans=''“And now even the '''messenger''' of the gods, sent from Jove himself – I swear by your life and mine – has delivered commands [to me] through the swift winds.”''<br/>(The messenger was [[Mercury]]. Syncopation: “divom” for “divorum”.)

la|Virgil|Aeneid|4|358|thru=359|quote=“[...] ipse deum '''manifēstō in lūmine''' vīdī<br/>intrantem mūrōs, vōcemque hīs auribus hausī.”|trans=“I myself saw – '''with clear [vision], in daylight''' – the god [Mercury] entering the [city] walls, and with these ears I heard his message.”

la|Virgil|Aeneid|4|399|thru=400|quote=Frondentīsque ferunt rēmōs et rōbora silvīs<br/>'''īnfabricāta''', fugae studiō.|trans=And [the Trojans] carry from the woods still-leafy oars and sturdy, '''unhewn''' timbers, [all] in their haste to flee [Carthage].<br/>(The incomplete hexameter of line 4.400 includes Virgil’s only use of “infabricata.”)

la|Virgil|Aeneid|4|460|thru=461|quote=Hinc exaudīrī vōcēs et verba '''vocantīs'''<br/>vīsa virī, nox cum terrās obscūra tenēret.|trans=[Dido’s shrine honoring Sychaeus:] From here, it seemed, she was hearing voices, and words from her [dead] husband '''calling [her name]''', whenever dark night held the lands.

la|Virgil|Aeneid|4|466|thru=468|quote=[...] semperque relinquī / sōla sibī, semper longam '''incomitāta''' vidētur / īre viam, et Tyriōs dēsertā quaerere terrā.|trans=[Dido’s anguished dreams:] and always to be left to herself all alone, forever she seems to go a long way, '''unattended''', and looking for her Tyrian [companions] in a solitary land.

la|Virgil|Aeneid|4|659|thru=660|quote=“'''Moriēmur''' inultae / sed '''moriāmur'''”|trans=''“'''We will die''' unavenged, but '''let us die'''.”''<br/>(Dido here speaks of herself using the royal we or majestic we, which some translations honor, and others alter to first-person singular: “I shall die…”.)

la|Virgil|Aeneid|4|685|quote=[...] Sīc '''fāta''' gradūs ēvāserat altōs [...].|trans=''As she '''had spoken''' these words [Anna] had been climbing the high steps [up to Dido’s pyre…].''<br/>(T.E. Page [1967], pg. 393, notes that “‘fata’ is really a present” tense in this context, i.e.: ''While saying'' these words….)

la|Virgil|Aeneid|4|690-691|quote=Ter sēsē attollēns '''cubitō'''que adnīxa levāvit,<br/>ter revolūta torō est [...].|trans=''Lifting herself three times, [Dido] had tried to raise '''upon''' her '''elbow''', and thrice she had rolled back upon the bed [...].''<br/>(Fratantuono and Smith [2022], pg. 916: “The only elbow in Virgil: another graphic detail as the poet continues his emphasis on the physical.”)

la|Virgil|Aeneid|4|8-9|quote=cum sīc '''ūnanimam''' adloquitur male sāna sorōrem:<br/>“Anna soror, quae mē suspēnsam īnsomnia terrent!”|trans=''When, badly distraught, [Dido] speaks in this way with her '''like-minded''' sister: “Anna, [dear] sister, [I am] restless — what dreams frighten me!”''<br/>(Dido’s closest confidant, her sister Anna, first appears here in the epic. Translations vary – Mackail, 1885: “opens her confidence to her sister”; Knight, 1956: “the sister whose heart was one with hers”; Fagles, 2006: “confides now to the sister of her soul”; Ahl, 2007: “what was her soul’s other self, in a manner, her sister”; Ruden, 2021: “her loving sister”.)

la|Virgil|Aeneid|4|88-89|quote=[...] '''pendent''' opera interrupta, minaeque<br/>mūrōrum ingentēs aequātaque māchina caelō.|trans=[...] Works are interrupted — [pieces] '''hang''' [in mid-air] — [for] the massive battlements of walls and machines level with the sky.<br/>(Cranes, hoists, and scaffolds sit idle — construction of Carthage halts — because the queen has become so distracted: The work is both literally and figuratively “suspended.”)

Bambhadatta page 16 lines 16-18|transauthor=John Jacob Meyer|transyear=1909|quote=𑀢𑀑 𑀧𑀬𑀢𑁆𑀢𑁂 '''𑀦𑀺𑀩𑁆𑀪𑀭𑁂''' 𑀓𑀻𑀮𑀸-𑀭𑀲𑁂 𑀓𑀻𑀮𑀁𑀢𑁂𑀲𑀼 𑀯𑀺𑀯𑀺𑀳-𑀓𑀻𑀮𑀸𑀳𑀺𑀁 𑀢𑀭𑀼𑀡-𑀦𑀭-𑀦𑀸𑀭𑀻-𑀲𑀢𑁆𑀣𑁂𑀲𑀼<br>𑀅𑀢𑀓𑁆𑀓𑀺𑀬𑀁-𑀘𑁂𑀯 𑀫𑀬-𑀧𑀭𑀯𑁆𑀯𑀲𑁄 𑀕𑀸𑀮𑀺𑀬-𑀫𑀺𑀁𑀞𑁄 𑀦𑀺𑀭𑀁𑀓𑀼𑀲𑁄 𑀯𑀺𑀬𑀭𑀺𑀑 𑀭𑀸𑀬-𑀳𑀢𑁆𑀣𑀻|t=When thereupon the pleasure of sports was at its '''height''' and the companies of young men and women were amusing themselves with various pastimes, unexpectedly a royal elephant that was beside himself with rut and had thrown off his driver and [so] was not curbed by the hook, strayed thither.

pra|Devendra|Uttarādhyayana-Vṛtti|VIII. Mūladeva page 58, line 32|quote=𑀦 𑀏𑀓𑀫𑁆𑀫𑀺 𑀧𑀟𑀺𑀬𑀸𑀭𑁂 𑀤𑁄𑀦𑁆𑀦𑀺 𑀓𑀭𑀯𑀸𑀮𑀸𑀇𑀁 𑀫𑀸𑀬𑀁𑀢𑀺, 𑀦 𑀬 𑀅𑀮𑁄𑀡𑀺𑀬𑀁 𑀲𑀺𑀮𑀁 𑀓𑁄𑀇 '''𑀘𑀝𑁆𑀝𑁂𑀇'''|t=Two swords do not find room in one scabbard, nor does anyone '''eat''' the gleaned ear of corn without salt.

pra|Hala|Sattasai|310|transauthor=Peter Khoroche and Herman Tieken|transyear=2009|quote=𑀡 𑀕𑀼𑀡𑁂𑀡 𑀳𑀻𑀭𑀇 𑀚𑀡𑁄 𑀳𑀻𑀭𑀇 𑀚𑁄 𑀚𑁂𑀡 𑀪𑀸𑀯𑀺𑀑 𑀢𑁂𑀡<br>𑀫𑁄𑀢𑁆𑀢𑀽𑀡 𑀧𑀼𑀮𑀺𑀁𑀤𑀸 '''𑀫𑁄𑀢𑁆𑀢𑀺𑀆𑀇''' 𑀕𑀼𑀁𑀚𑀸𑀉 𑀕𑁂𑀡𑁆𑀳𑀁𑀢𑀺|t=People are not captivated by true qualities but by what takes their fancy.<br>The Pulindas brush '''pearls''' aside but seize upon the guñja seeds the jeweler uses as weights.

pra|Vakpatiraja|Gaudavaho|54|transauthor=Narhari Govind Suru|transyear=1975|quote='''𑀕𑀡𑀯𑀇𑀡𑁄''' 𑀲𑀇-𑀲𑀁𑀕𑀅-𑀕𑁄𑀭𑀻-𑀳𑀭-𑀧𑁂𑀫𑁆𑀧-𑀭𑀸𑀅-𑀯𑀺𑀮𑀺𑀅𑀲𑁆𑀲 𑁇<br/>𑀤𑀁𑀢𑁄 𑀯𑀸𑀫-𑀫𑀼𑀳𑀤𑁆𑀥𑀁𑀢-𑀧𑀼𑀁𑀚𑀺𑀑 𑀚𑀅𑀇 𑀳𑀸𑀲𑁄-𑀯𑁆𑀯 𑁈𑁫𑁪𑁈 |t=54. ru|Иван Тургенев|Отцы и дети|1862|quote=Четверть часа спустя оба экипажа остановились перед '''крыльцом''' нового деревянного дома, выкрашенного серою краской и покрытого железною красною крышей.|trans=A quarter of an hour later both carriages drew up in front of the '''porch''' of a new wooden house, painted grey, with a red iron roof.

sa||AV|11|8|22|quote='''निन्दाश्''' च वा अनिन्दाश् च यच् च हन्तेति नेति च ।<br>शरीरं श्रद्धा दक्षिणाश्रद्धा चानु प्राविशन् ॥|trans='''Reproaches''', freedom from reproach, all blamable, all blameless deeds,<br>Bounty, belief, and unbelief entered the body as a home.

sa||AV|11|9|22|quote=ये च॒ धीरा॒ ये चाधी॑राः॒ परा॑ञ्चो बधि॒राश्च॒ ये<br>'''त॑म॒सा''' ये च॑ तूप॒रा अथो॑ बस्ताभिवा॒सिनः॑।<br>सर्वां॒स्ताँ अ॑र्बुदे॒ त्वम॒मित्रे॑भ्यो दृ॒शे कु॑रूदा॒रांश्च॒ प्र द॑र्शय ॥|trans=The clever and the foolish ones, those who are twisted round, the deaf,<br>The '''dusky-hued''', the hornless goats and those whose voice is like the buck's,<br>All these, O Arbudi, do thou make visible to our enemies: cause them to look on mists and fog.

sa||AV|12|4|3|quote=कूटयास्य सं शीर्यन्ते श्लोणया काटमर्दति ।<br>बण्डया दह्यन्ते गृहाः '''काणया''' दीयते स्वम् ॥|t=They perish through a hornless cow, a lame cow sinks them in a pit.<br>Through a maimed cow his house is burnt: a '''one-eyed''' cow destroys his wealth.

sa||AV|15|17|quote=योऽस्य प्रथमो व्यानः सेयं भूमिः ॥<br>योऽस्य द्वितीयो व्यानस्तदन्तरिक्षम् ॥<br>योऽस्य तृतीयो व्यानः सा द्यौः ॥<br>योऽस्य चतुर्थो व्यानस्तानि नक्षत्राणि ॥<br>योऽस्य पञ्चमो व्यानस्त ऋतवः ॥<br>योऽस्य षष्ठो व्यानस्त आर्तवाः ॥<br>योऽस्य '''सप्तमो''' व्यानः स संवत्सरः ॥|trans=His first diffused breath is this Earth.<br>His second diffused breath is that Firmament.<br>His third diffused breath is that Heaven.<br>His fourth diffused breath are those Constellations.<br>His fifth diffused breath are the Seasons.<br>His sixth diffused breath are the Season-groups.<br>His '''seventh''' diffused breath is the year.

sa||AV|4|7|6|quote='''पवस्तैस्''' त्वा पर्य् अक्रीणन् दूर्शेभिर् अजिनैर् उत ।<br>प्रक्रीर् असि त्वम् ओषधे ऽभ्रिखाते न रूरुपः ॥|trans=[People] have traded you for '''garments''', woven cloths, and deer-skins.<br>O Plant, dug up with a pickaxe, you are a thing of sale; do not cause us harm!

sa||AV|4|7|6|quote=पवस्तैस् त्वा पर्य् अक्रीणन् '''दूर्शेभिर्''' अजिनैर् उत ।<br>प्रक्रीर् असि त्वम् ओषधे ऽभ्रिखाते न रूरुपः ॥|trans=[People] have traded you for garments, '''woven cloths''', and deer-skins.<br>O Plant, dug up with a pickaxe, you are a thing of sale; do not cause us harm!

sa||AV|6|119|3|quote=वैश्वानरः '''पविता''' मा पुनातु यत् संगरम् अभिधावाम्य् आशाम् ।<br>अनाजानन् मनसा याचमानो यत् तत्रैनो अप तत् सुवामि ॥|trans=May Vaiśvānara '''the Purifier''' purify me when I oppose their (my debtors') hope and break my promise,<br>Unknowing in my heart. With supplication, whatever guilt there is in that, I banish.

sa||AV|9|6|53|quote=यद्वा '''अतिथिपतिर्'''अतिथीन् परिविष्य गृहानुपोदैत्यवभृथमेव तदुपावैति ॥|t=Or if the '''host''', having offered food to his guest, goes up to the house, he virtually enters the bath of purification.

sa||AV|9|8|1|quote='''हरिमाणं''' ते अङ्गेभ्योऽप्वामन्तरोदरात्।<br>यक्ष्मोधामन्तरात्मनो बहिर्निर्मन्त्रयामहे ॥|trans='''The yellow Jaundice''' from thy limbs, and Colic from the parts within,<br>And Phthisis from thine inward soul we charm away with this our spell.

sa||Bh|1|7|23|quote=त्वमाद्यः पुरुषः साक्षादीश्वरः प्रकृतेः परः ।<br/> मायां व्युदस्य '''चिच्छक्त्या''' कैवल्ये स्थित आत्मनि ॥|t=You are the original man who expands himself all over the creations and is transcendental to material energy. You have cast away the effects of the illusion by '''mental capacity'''. You are always situated in eternal bliss and transcendental knowledge.

sa||Bh|11|7|62|quote=एकदा जग्मतुस्तासामन्नार्थं तौ कुटुम्बिनौ । '''परितः''' कानने तस्मिन्नर्थिनौ चेरतुश्चिरम् ॥|t=Once the two householders went to find food for them [their children]. '''All around''' the forest, the two seekers wandered for a long time.

sa||Bh|4|14|11|quote=निरूपितः प्रजापालः स '''जिघांसति''' वै प्रजाः। तथापि सान्‍त्वयेमामुं नास्मांस्तत्पातकं स्पृशेत्॥|t=We appointed this king of the state in order to give protection to the citizens, but he '''desires to harm''' them. Despite all these discrepancies, we should at once try to pacify him. By doing so, we may not be touched by the sinful results caused by him.

sa||Bhag|11|44|quote=प्रणम्य प्रणिधाय कायं प्रसादये त्वामहमीशमीड्यम्|trans=''praṇamya praṇidhāya kāyaṁ prasādaye tvām-aham-īśam-'''īḍyam''''' <br /> saluting, having bent my body, seeking favour of yours I am [O!] lord '''praiseworthy'''

sa||Bhag|3|8|quote=नियतं कुरु कर्म त्वं कर्म '''ज्यायो''' ह्यकर्मणः। शरीरयात्रापि च ते न प्रसिद्धयेदकर्मणः॥|t=Do your duties with discipline, for doing something is '''better''' than being without work. One's body cannot even be maintained without doing work.

sa||Bhāratamañjarī|1|636|quote=स गत्वा '''मृण्मयं''' द्रोणं श्रद्धावान् पूजयन् सदा ।<br/>अस्त्राभ्यासं स्वयं चक्रे येनाभूद् धन्विनां वरः ॥|t=He [Ekalavya] went to the '''clay-made''' [statue of] Droṇa, always with reverence and faith;<br/> He trained with his weapons by himself, by which he became the best of the archers.

sa||Bhāratamañjarī|8|155|quote=श्रुत्वैतत् खड्गम् आकृष्य '''हन्तुम्''' आत्मानम् उद्यतम् ।<br/>प्रतिज्ञाभङ्गनिर्भिन्नं पार्थं कृष्णो ऽब्रवीत् पुनः ॥|t=On hearing this, Kṛṣṇa spoke to Arjuna who, having his vow broken was ready '''to kill''' himself having drawn his sword.

sa||BhP|3|14|47|quote=स वै महाभागवतो महात्मा महानुभावो महतां '''महिष्ठः''' ।<br>प्रवृद्धभक्त्या ह्यनुभाविताशये निवेश्य वैकुण्ठमिमं विहास्यति ॥|t=Verily, he would be the greatest devotee of unlimited vision and of great prowess and '''the greatest''' of the great. For, by his deep devotion, he will establish Lord Viṣṇu in his heart, purified by devotion, and give up the ego about his body.

sa||BhP|3|19|23|quote=तदा दितेः समभवत्सहसा हृदि वेपथुः। स्मरन्त्या भर्तुरादेशं स्तनाच्च्'''आसृक्''' प्रसुस्रुवे॥|t=At that very moment, a shudder suddenly ran through the heart of Diti, the mother of Hiraṇyākṣa. She recalled the words of her husband, Kaśyapa, and '''blood''' flowed from her breasts.

sa||BhP|4|24|38|quote=नम ऊर्जे इषे त्रय्याः पतये यज्ञरेतसे। '''तृप्तिदाय''' च जीवानां नमः सर्वरसात्मने॥|t=My Lord, you are the provider of the Pitṛlokas as well as all the demigods. You are the predominating deity of the moon and the master of all three Vedas. I offer my respectful obeisances unto you because you are the '''source of satisfaction''' for all living entities.

sa||BhP|7|12|25|quote=खे खानि वायौ निश्वासांस्तेजःसूष्माणमात्मवान्। अप्स्व्'''असृक्'''श्लेष्मपूयानि क्षितौ शेषं यथोद्भ‍वम्॥|t=A sober, self-realized person who has full knowledge should merge the various parts of the body in their original sources. The holes in the body are caused by the sky, the process of breathing is caused by the air, the heat of the body is caused by fire, and semen, '''blood''' and mucus are caused by water. The hard substances, like skin, muscle and bone, are caused by earth. In this way all the constituents of the body are caused by various elements, and they should be merged again into those elements.

sa||BhP|7|2|8|quote=मच्छूलभिन्नग्रीवस्य भूरिणा रुधिरेण वै। '''असृक्'''प्रियं तर्पयिष्ये भ्रातरं मे गतव्यथः॥|t=I shall therefore sever Lord Viṣṇu’s head from his trunk by my trident, and with the profuse rudhira [blood] from his body I shall please my brother Hiraṇyākṣa, who was so fond of sucking asṛk ['''blood''']. Thus shall I too be peaceful.

sa||BṛĀrUp|2|1.20|quote=स य'''थोर्णवाभिस्'''  तन्तुनोच्चरेत्।<br>यथाग्नेः क्षुद्रा विष्फुलिङ्गा व्युच्चरन्त्य् एवम् एवास्माद् आत्मनः सर्वे प्राणाः सर्वे लोकाः सर्वे देवाः सर्वाणि भूतानि सर्व एत आत्मानो व्युच्चरन्ति तस्योपनिषत् सत्यस्य सत्यम् इति प्राणा वै सत्यं तेषाम् एष सत्यम्|trans=As a '''spider''' sends forth itself by its thread, and as tiny sparks spring forth from a fire, so indeed do all the vital functions, all the worlds, all the gods, and all beings spring from this Self. Its hidden name (upaniṣad) is 'The truth behind the truth', for the truth consists of the vital functions, and the self is the truth behind the vital functions.

sa||BṛĀrUp|6|4|13|quote=अथ यस्य जायाम् आर्तवं विन्देत् त्र्यहं कंसे न पिबेत् ।<br/>अहतवासाः ।<br/>नैनां वृषलो न '''वृषल्य्''' उपहन्यात् ।<br/> त्रिरात्रान्त आप्लुत्य व्रीहीन् अवघातयेत् ॥|t=If anybody’s wife is menstruating, she should not drink for three days in a metal cup<br/>And wear a new dress<br/>No Śūdra man or'''Śūdra woman''' should touch her<br/>After three nights she should be put to thresh rice

sa||BṛĀrUp|6|4|18|quote=अथ य इच्छेत् पुत्रो मे पण्डितो विगीतः समितिंगमः शुश्रूषितां वाचं भाषिता जायेत सर्वान् वेदान् अनुब्रुवीत सर्वम् आयुर् इयाद् इति '''मांसौदनं''' पाचयित्वा सर्पिष्मन्तम् अश्नीयाताम् ईश्वरौ जनयितवा औक्षेण वार्षभेण वा ॥|trans=If a man wishes that a son should be born to him who will be a famous scholar, frequenting assemblies and speaking delightful words, a student of all the Vedas and an enjoyer of the full term of life, he should have '''rice cooked with the meat''' of an ox or a bull and he and his wife should eat it with clarified butter. Then they should be able to beget such a son.
sa||CS|4|1|47|2|quote=कर्ता '''भोक्ता''' न स पुमानिति केचिद्व्यवस्थिताः ॥|t=They do not believe in a Self who is the doer and the '''enjoyer'''.

sa||CS|4|3|13|3-4|quote=स्मार्तं हि ज्ञानमात्मनस्तस्यैव मनसोऽनुबन्धादनुवर्तते यस्यानुवृत्तिं पुरस्कृत्य पुरुषो जातिस्मर इत्युच्यते ।<br/> यानि खल्वस्य गर्भस्य सत्त्वजानि यान्यस्य सत्त्वतः सम्भवतः सम्भवन्ति तान्यनुव्याख्यास्यामः तद्यथा भक्तिः शीलं शौचं द्वेषः स्मृतिर्मोहस्त्यागो मात्सर्यं शौर्यं भयं क्रोधस्तन्द्रोत्साहस्तैक्ष्ण्यं '''मार्दवं''' गाम्भीर्यमनवस्थितत्वमित्येवमादयश्चान्ये ते सत्त्वविकारा यानुत्तरकालं सत्त्वभेदमधिकृत्योपदेक्ष्यामः ॥|t=We shall now enumerate the mind-born parts of the embryo, i. e those that pass from the mind, to the embryo during its formation. These are - inclination, character, purity, hate, recollection, infatuation, liberality, envy, valour, fear, anger, torpor, enthusiasm, keenness, '''softness''', profundity, fickleness, and such others; as also the conditions of the mind, which we shall later describe in connection with the analysis of mind. The mind is indeed of diverse dispositions; all these obtain in the same man but not at the same time. When a man is said to be of a particular disposition, he is said to be so by reason of its preponderance.

sa||MaitrUp|1|6|9|quote=कालकाञ्जा वा असुरा इष्टका अचिन्वत दिवमारोक्ष्यामा इति तानिन्द्रो ब्राह्मणो ब्रुवाण उपैत् स एतामिष्टकामप्युपाधत्त प्रथमा इव दिवमाक्रमन्त अथ स ताम् आबृहत् तेऽसुराः पापीयांसो भवन्तोऽपाभ्रंशन्त या उत्तमा आस्तां तौ यमश्वा अभवताम् येऽधरे त '''ऊर्णावाभयः'''|trans=The Asuras called Kālakāñja attempted to stack an altar up to the sky. Indra, passing himself off as a Brahmin, inserted one of his bricks into the altar. As soon as the Kālakāñja ascended, Indra removed the brick and they fell: the two who were at the top became Yama's dogs, the others who remained further down, they became '''spiders'''.

sa||MBh|18|5|38|quote=धर्मे चार्थे च कामे च मोक्षे च भरतर्षभ ।<br>यदिहास्ति तद्'''अन्यत्र''' यन्नेहास्ति न तत्क्वचित् ॥|t=Bull among Bharatas, whatever is here, on Law, on Profit, on Pleasure, and on Salvation, that is found '''elsewhere'''. But what is not here is nowhere else.

sa||MBh|8|39|31|quote=नैव नाम तव प्रीतिर् नैव नाम कृतज्ञता ।<br/> '''यतस्''' त्वं पुरुषव्याघ्र माम् एवाद्य जिघांससि ॥|t=You certainly do not have any kindness or gratefulness,<br/>'''because of which''' you, O tiger among men, wish to kill me today.

sa||Naiṣadhacarita|quote=पदे पदे सन्ति भटा र'''णोद्भटा''' न तेषु हिंसारस एष पूर्यते ।<br/>धिग् ईदृशं ते नृपते कुविक्रमं कृपाश्रये यः कृपणे पतत्त्रिणि ॥|t=There are warriors '''eminent''' in combat at every step; yet your passion for violence is not fulfilled by them.<br/> O King, fie upon your malicious valor which you spend on a poor and pitiful bird.

sa||R|1|2|11|quote=तं शोणितपरीताङ्गं '''वेष्टमानं''' महीतले ।<br/> भार्या तु निहतं दृष्ट्वा रुराव करुणां गिरम् ॥|t=Seeing him struck and having a blood-covered body, '''clinging''' to the ground, the wife cried in a miserable voice.

sa||R|1|48|quote=तस्यान्तरं विदित्वा च सहस्राक्षः शचीपतिः।<br>मुनिवेषधरो भूत्वा अहल्यामिदमब्रवीत्॥<br>ऋतुकालं प्रतीक्षन्ते नार्थिनः सुसमाहिते।<br>संगमं त्वहमिच्छामि त्वया सह सुमध्यमे॥<br>मुनिवेषं सहस्राक्षं विज्ञाय रघुनन्दन।<br>मतिं चकार दुर्मेधा देवराजकुतूहलात्॥<br>अथाब्रवीत् सुरश्रेष्ठं कृतार्थेनान्तरात्मना।<br>कृतार्थास्मि सुरश्रेष्ठ गच्छ शीघ्रमितः प्रभो॥<br>आत्मानं मां च '''देवेश''' सर्वथा रक्ष गौतमात्।<br>इन्द्रस्तु प्रहसन् वाक्यमहल्यामिदमब्रवीत्॥<br>सुश्रोणि परितुष्टोऽस्मि गमिष्यामि यथागतम्।<br>एवं संगम्य तु तदा निश्चक्रामोटजात् ततः॥|t=[O Rama, one day, when the sage Gautama had gone to a distant place] Indra, finding the opportunity, assumed the sage's disguise, and said to Ahalya: "O Attractive One, those who are amorous do not wait for the right time. I desire union with thee, O slender waisted one!" O Rama, although Ahalya recognized Indra disguised as her husband, she out of curiosity about the king of gods, made a foolish decision [and yielded to his desire]. Afterwards, having been satisfied, Ahalya addressed Indra saying : "O best among the gods, I am highly satisfied, now depart quickly from here, Lord. O '''Chief of the gods''', save thyself and me from Gautama." Indra laughed and answered : "O Thou of beautiful waist, I am [also] very satisfied;, I will now depart the same way I entered!" Saying this, he sought to leave the hut of Gautama.

sa||R|1|55|quote=स गत्वा हिमवत्पार्श्वे किंनरोरगसेवितम्। महादेवप्रसादार्थं तपस्तेपे महातपाः॥ केनचित् त्वथ कालेन '''देवेशो''' वृषभध्वजः। दर्शयामास वरदो विश्वामित्रं महामुनिम्॥ किमर्थं तप्यसे राजन् ब्रूहि यत् ते विवक्षितम्। वरदोऽस्मि वरो यस्ते कांक्षितः सोऽभिधीयताम्॥ एवमुक्तस्तु देवेन विश्वामित्रो महातपाः। प्रणिपत्य महादेवं विश्वामित्रोऽब्रवीदिदम्॥ यदि तुष्टो महादेव धनुर्वेदो ममानघ। सांगोपांगोपनिषदः सरहस्यः प्रदीयताम्॥ यानि देवेषु चास्त्राणि दानवेषु महर्षिषु। गन्धर्वयक्षरक्षःसु प्रतिभान्तु ममानघ॥ तव प्रसादाद् भवतु देवदेव ममेप्सितम्। एवमस्त्विति '''देवेशो''' वाक्यमुक्त्वा गतस्तदा॥|t=[Vishwamitra] retired to the forest to practise ascetic worship of Mahādeva (Shiva). After some time, Shiva, the '''Lord of Gods''', with the bull on his flag, appeared before Vishwamitra and said to him : "O King, why art thou undergoing penance ? What is thy desire ? I will grant thee whatsoever thou askest". Vishwamitra, making obeisance to Shri Mahādeva said to him : "O Great God, if I have found favour with thee, then instruct me in the Upanishads and other branches of learning, teach me also the mysteries and the science of archery. Whatever weapons are known to the danavas, yakshas, asuras, gandharvas and other beings, let them be revealed to me by thy grace." On hearing the request of the king, the '''Lord of Gods''' answered, "Be it so" and returned to his abode.

sa||R|3|8|7|quote=अभ्यनुज्ञातुम् इच्छामः सहैभिर् मुनिपुङ्गवैः ।<br/> धर्मनित्यैस् तपोदान्तैर् '''विशिखैर्''' इव पावकैः ॥|t=We wish to be authorized by these great sages,<br/>who are continually pious and self-restrained by penance, like fires '''without flame'''.

sa||R|5|10|49|quote=आतोद्यानि विचित्राणि परिष्वज्य वरस्त्रियः ।<br/>निपीड्य च '''कुचैः''' सुप्ताः कामिन्यः कामुकान् इव ॥|t=Exquisite women were sleeping with various musical instruments<br/> pressed upon their '''bosoms''' like passionate ones embracing their lovers.

sa||RV|1|102|5|quote=नाना॒ हि त्वा॒ हव॑माना॒ जना॑ इ॒मे धना॑नां धर्त॒र् अव॑सा विप॒न्यवः॑ ।<br>अ॒स्माकं॑ स्मा॒ रथ॒म् आ ति॑ष्ठ सा॒तये॒ जैत्रं॒ ही॑न्द्र॒ '''निभृ॑तं॒''' मन॒स् तव॑ ॥|trans=For, from various quarters these people here call to you, O holder of stakes, admiring you because of the help (that you give them).<br>Ride our chariot so that it may win: because, your '''firm''' soul, O Indra, (is) made for victory.

sa||RV|1|113|20|quote=यच् चि॒त्रम् '''अप्न॑''' उ॒षसो॒ वह॑न्तीजा॒नाय॑ शशमा॒नाय॑ भ॒द्रं ।<br>तन् नो॑ मि॒त्रो वरु॑णो मामहन्ता॒म् अदि॑तिः॒ सिन्धुः॑ पृथि॒वी उ॒त द्यौः ॥|trans=Whatever splendid '''wealth''' the Dawns bring with them to bless the man who offers praise and worship,<br>That may Mitra, Varuṇa grant us, and Aditi and Sindhu, Earth and Heaven.

sa||RV|1|116|1|quote=नास॑त्याभ्यां ब॒र्हिरि॑व॒ प्र वृ॑ञ्जे॒ '''स्तोमाँ॑ इयर्म्य्'''अ॒भ्रिये॑व॒ वातः॑ ।<br>यावर्भ॑गाय विम॒दाय॑ जा॒यां से॑ना॒जुवा॑ न्यू॒हतू॒ रथे॑न ॥|t=I trim like grass my song for the Nāsatyas and '''send their lauds forth''' as the wind drives rain-clouds,<br>Who, in a chariot rapid as an arrow, brought to the youthful Vimada a consort.<ref>[https://sacred-texts.com/hin/rigveda/rv01116.htm], Rig Veda, tr. by Ralph T.H. Griffith, [1896], at sacred-texts.com</ref>

sa||RV|1|116|18|quote=यदया॑तं॒ दिवो॑दासाय व॒र्तिर्भ॒रद्वा॑जायाश्विना॒ हय॑न्ता ।<br>रे॒वदु॑वाह सच॒नो रथो॑ वां वृष॒भश्च॑ '''शिंशु॒मार॑'''श्च यु॒क्ता ॥|trans=When to his house ye came, to Divodâsa, hasting to Bharadvâja, O ye Aṣvins, The car that came with you brought splendid riches: a '''porpoise''' and a bull were yoked together.|transauthor=Ralph T. H. Griffith|transyear=1890

sa||RV|1|144|7|quote=अग्ने॑ जु॒षस्व॒ प्रति॑ हर्य॒ तद् वचो॒ मन्द्र॒ स्वधा॑व॒ ऋत॑जात॒ सुक्र॑तो ।<br>यो वि॒श्वतः॑ '''प्र॒त्यङ्ङ्''' असि॑ दर्श॒तो र॒ण्वः संदृ॑ष्टौ पितु॒माँ इ॑व॒ क्षयः॑ ॥|t=Agni, accept with joy, be glad in this our prayer, joy-giver, self-sustained, strong, born of Holy Law!<br>For fair to see art thou '''turned towards''' every side, pleasant to look on as a dwelling filled with food.

sa||RV|1|145|4|quote=उ॒प॒स्थायं॑ चरति॒ यत्स॒मार॑त स॒द्यो जा॒तस्त॑त्सार॒ युज्ये॑भिः ।<br/> अ॒भि '''श्वा॒न्तं''' मृ॑शते ना॒न्द्ये॑ मु॒दे यदीं॒ गच्छ॑न्त्युश॒तीर॑पिष्ठि॒तम् ॥|tr=upasthā́yaṃ carati yátsamā́rata sadyó jātástatsāra yújyebhiḥ .<br/> abhí '''śvāntáṃ''' mṛśate nāndyè mudé yádīṃ gáchantyuśatī́rapiṣṭhitám .|t=Whatever he meets he grasps and then runs farther on, and straightway, newly born, creeps forward with his kin.<br/> He stirs the '''tranquil''' man to pleasure and great joy what time the longing gifts approach him as he comes.

sa||RV|1|15|12|quote=गार्ह॑पत्येन सन्त्य ऋ॒तुना॑ यज्ञ॒नीर् अ॑सि ।<br>दे॒वान् दे॑वय॒ते '''य॑ज''' ॥|trans=With Ṛtu, through the house-fire, you, kind Giver, guide the worship-ritual:<br>'''Worship''' the Gods for the sake of the pious one.

sa||RV|1|32|13|quote=नास्मै॑ वि॒द्युन् न '''त॑न्य॒तुः''' सि॑षेध॒ न यां मिह॒म् अकि॑रद् ध्रा॒दुनिं॑ च ।<br>इन्द्र॑श् च॒ यद् यु॑यु॒धाते॒ अहि॑श् चो॒ताप॒रीभ्यो॑ म॒घवा॒ वि जि॑ग्ये ॥|t=The lightning and '''thunder''' failed to help him [against Indra]; the mist and hail that he spread around were similarly of no use to him.<br>When Indra and the Dragon fought, the Generous One [Indra] attained a victory for all times to come.

sa||RV|1|36|5|quote=म॒न्द्रो होता॑ गृ॒हप॑ति॒रग्ने॑ दू॒तो वि॒शाम॑सि।<br>त्वे विश्वा॒ संग॑तानि व्र॒ता ध्रु॒वा यानि॑ दे॒वा '''अकृ॑ण्वत'''॥|trans=Thou, Agni, art a cheering priest, lord of the house, men’s messenger.<br>All constant high decrees '''established''' by the gods, gathered together, meet in thee.

sa||RV|1|79|6|quote='''क्षपो''' राजन्नुत त्मनाग्ने वस्तोरुतोषसः।<br>स तिग्मजम्भ रक्षसो दह प्रति॥|trans=O Agni, shining of thyself by '''night''' and when the morning breaks,<br>Burn, thou whose teeth are sharp, against the Rākṣasas.

sa||RV|1|91|21|quote=अषा॑ळ्हं '''यु॒त्सु''' पृत॑नासु॒ पप्रिं॑ स्व॒र्षाम॒प्सां वृ॒जन॑स्य गो॒पाम् ।<br> भ॒रे॒षु॒जां सु॑क्षि॒तिं सु॒श्रव॑सं॒ जय॑न्तं॒ त्वामनु॑ मदेम सोम ॥|trans=Invincible '''in fight''', saver in battles, guard of our camp, winner of light and water, <br> Born amid hymns, well-housed, exceeding famous, victor, in thee will we rejoice, O Soma.

sa||RV|1|94|6|quote=त्वम् अध्व॒र्युर् उ॒त होता॑सि पू॒र्व्यः '''प्र॑शा॒स्ता''' पोता॑ ज॒नुषा॑ पु॒रोहि॑तः ।<br>विश्वा॑ वि॒द्वाँ आर्त्वि॑ज्या धीर पुष्य॒स्य् अग्ने॑ स॒ख्ये मा रि॑षामा व॒यं तव॑ ॥|trans=Thou art Presenter and the chief Invoker, thou '''Director''', Purifier, great High Priest by birth.<br>Knowing all priestly work thou perfectest it, O Sage. Let us not in thy friendship, Agni, suffer harm.

sa||RV|1|94|6|quote=त्वम् अध्व॒र्युर् उ॒त होता॑सि पू॒र्व्यः प्र॑शा॒स्ता '''पोता॑''' ज॒नुषा॑ पु॒रोहि॑तः ।<br>विश्वा॑ वि॒द्वाँ आर्त्वि॑ज्या धीर पुष्य॒स्य् अग्ने॑ स॒ख्ये मा रि॑षामा व॒यं तव॑ ॥|trans=You are the Presenter and the chief Invoker, you are the Director, '''Purifier''', great High Priest by birth.<br>Knowing all priestly work you perfect it, O Sage. Let us not in your friendship, Agni, suffer harm.

sa||RV|1|94|7|quote=यो विश्वतः सुप्रतीकः '''सदृङ्ङ्''' असि दूरे चित् सन् तळिद् इवाति रोचसे ।<br>रात्र्याश् चिद् अन्धो अति देव पश्यस्य् अग्ने सख्ये मा रिषामा वयं तव ॥|trans=Lovely of form art thou, '''alike''' on every side; though far, thou shinest brightly as if close at hand.<br>O God, thou seest through even the dark of night. Let us not in thy friendship, Agni, suffer harm.

sa||RV|1|94|9|quote=व॒धैर्दुः॒शंसाँ॒ अप॑ '''दू॒ढ्यो॑''' जहि दू॒रे वा॒ ये अन्ति॑ वा॒ के चि॑द॒त्रिणः॑ ।<br>अथा॑ य॒ज्ञाय॑ गृण॒ते सु॒गं कृ॒ध्यग्ने॑ स॒ख्ये मा रि॑षामा व॒यं तव॑ ॥|trans=Smite with thy weapons those of evil speech and '''those with evil thoughts''', devouring demons, whether near or far away.<br>Then to the singer of your praises, give free way for worship. Let us not, in thy friendship, Agni, suffer harm.
sa||RV|10|110|10|1|quote=उपावसृज त्मन्या समञ्जन्देवानां '''पाथ''' ऋतुथा हवींषि ।|t=Send to our '''offering''' which thyself thou balmest the Companies of Devas in ordered season.

sa||RV|10|112|3|quote=हरि॑त्वता॒ '''वर्च॑सा॒''' सूर्य॑स्य॒ श्रेष्ठै॑ रू॒पैस् त॒न्वं॑ स्पर्शयस्व ।<br>अ॒स्माभि॑र् इन्द्र॒ सखि॑भिर् हुवा॒नः स॑ध्रीची॒नो मा॑दयस्वा नि॒षद्य॑ ॥|trans=Deck out thy body with the fairest colours, with golden '''splendour''' of the Sun adorn it.<br>O Indra, turn thee hitherward invited by us thy friends; be seated and be joyful.
sa||RV|10|125|6|quote=अ॒हं रु॒द्राय॒ धनु॒रा त॑नोमि ब्रह्म॒द्विषे॒ '''शर॑वे॒''' हन्त॒वा उ॑ ।|trans=I bend the bow for Rudra that his '''arrow''' may strike and slay the hater of devotion.

sa||RV|10|164|3|quote=यद् आशसा निःशसाभिशसोपारिम जाग्रतो यत् स्वपन्तः ।<br>अग्निर् विश्वान्य् अप '''दुष्कृतान्य्''' अजुष्टान्य् आरे अस्मद् दधातु ॥|trans=If by address, by blame, by imprecation we have committed sin, while awake or asleep,<br>All hateful acts of ours, all '''evil doings''' may Agni banish away to distant places.
sa||RV|10|46|3|quote=स शेवृधो जात आ '''हर्म्येषु''' नाभिर्युवा भवति रोचनस्य ॥|trans=[Agni], born in our '''houses''', Youthful, joy-bestower, he now becomes the central point of brightness.

sa||RV|10|68|7|quote=बृहस्पतिरमत हि त्यदासां नाम स्वरीणां सदने गुहा यत् ।<br>'''आण्डे'''व भित्त्वा शकुनस्य गर्भमुदुस्रियाः पर्वतस्य त्मनाजत् ॥|trans=That secret name borne by the lowing cattle within the cave Bṛhaspati discovered,<br>And drove, himself, the bright kine from the mountain, like a bird's young after the '''egg''''s breaking.

sa||RV|10|82|7|quote=न तं वि॑दाथ॒ य इ॒मा ज॒जाना॒न्यद् यु॒ष्माक॒म् अन्त॑रं बभूव ।<br/>'''नी॒हा॒रेण॒''' प्रावृ॑ता॒ जल्प्या॑ चासु॒तृप॑ उक्थ॒शास॑श् चरन्ति ॥|t=You do not know Him who created these beings, something else has arisen among you.<br/>Covered in '''mist''' and stammering speech, the hymn-chanters wander, unsatisfied.

sa||RV|2|23|12|quote=अदे॑वेन॒ मन॑सा॒ यो रि॑ष॒ण्यति॑ शा॒सामु॒ग्रो मन्य॑मानो॒ '''जिघां॑सति'''। बृह॑स्पते॒ मा प्रण॒क्तस्य॑ नो व॒धो नि क॑र्म म॒न्युं दु॒रेव॑स्य॒ शर्ध॑तः॥|tr=ádevena mánasā yó riṣaṇyáti śāsā́mugró mányamāno '''jíghāṃsati'''. bṛ́haspate mā́ práṇaktásya no vadhó ní karma manyúm durévasya śárdhataḥ.|t=Whosoever with ungodly mind harms us, who, considering himself powerful in commands '''seeks to do us harm'''<br>Let not his deadly blow reach us, O Bṛhaspati; may we humiliate the strong ill-doer's wrath.

sa||RV|2|27|14|quote=अदिते मित्र वरुणोत मृळ यद् वो वयं चकृमा कच् चिद् आगः ।<br>उर्व् अश्याम् अभयं ज्योतिर् इन्द्र मा नो दीर्घा अभि नशन् '''तमिस्राः''' ॥|trans=Aditi, Mitra, Varuṇa, forgive us however we have erred and sinned against you.<br>May I obtain the broad light free from peril: O Indra, let not the long, '''dark nights''' harm us.

sa||RV|2|43|2|quote='''उ॒द्गा॒ते'''व॑ शकुने॒ साम॑ गायसि ब्रह्मपु॒त्र इ॑व॒ सव॑नेषु शंससि।<br> वृषे॑व वा॒जी शिशु॑मतीर॒पीत्या॑ स॒र्वतो॑ नः शकुने भ॒द्रमा व॑द वि॒श्वतो॑ नः शकुने॒ पुण्य॒मा व॑द॥|t=Thou like the '''chanter-priest''' chantest the holy song, O Bird; thou singest at libations like a Brahman's son.<br>Even as a vigorous horse when he comes near the mare, announce to us good fortune, Bird, on every side, proclaim in all directions happy luck, O Bird.

sa||RV|2|43|2|quote=उ॒द्गा॒तेव॑ शकुने॒ साम॑ '''गायसि''' ब्रह्मपु॒त्र इ॑व॒ सव॑नेषु शंससि।<br> वृषे॑व वा॒जी शिशु॑मतीर॒पीत्या॑ स॒र्वतो॑ नः शकुने भ॒द्रमा व॑द वि॒श्वतो॑ नः शकुने॒ पुण्य॒मा व॑द॥|t=Thou like the chanter-priest '''chantest''' the holy song, O Bird; thou singest at libations like a Brahman's son.<br>Even as a vigorous horse when he comes near the mare, announce to us good fortune, Bird, on every side, proclaim in all directions happy luck, O Bird.

sa||RV|4|30|quote=अपो॒षा अन॑सः सर॒त् संपि॑ष्टा॒द् अह॑ बि॒भ्युषी॑ ।<br>नि यत्सीं॑ शि॒श्नथ॒द् वृषा॑ ॥<br>ए॒तद् अ॑स्या॒ अनः॑ शये॒ सुसं॑पिष्टं॒ '''विपा॒श्य्''' आ ।<br>स॒सार॑ सीं परा॒वतः॑ ॥|trans=Then from her chariot Uṣas fled, affrighted, from her ruined car.<br>When the strong God had shattered it.<br>So there this car of Uṣas lay, broken to pieces, '''in [the river] Vipāś''',<br>And she herself fled far away.

sa||RV|5|54|7|quote=न स जीयते मरुतो न हन्यते न '''स्रेधति''' न व्यथते न रिष्यति।<br>नास्य राय उप दस्यन्ति नोतय ऋषिं वा यं राजानं वा सुषूदथ॥|trans=Never is he, O Maruts, slain or overcome, never doth he '''decay''' ne' er is distressed or harmed;<br>His treasures, his resources, never waste away, whom. whether he be prince or Rsi, ye direct.

sa||RV|5|58|7|quote=प्रथिष्ट यामन्पृथिवी चिदेषां '''भर्तेव''' गर्भं स्वमिच्छवो धुः ।<br>वातान्ह्यश्वान्धुर्यायुयुज्रे वर्षं स्वेदं चक्रिरे रुद्रियासः ॥|trans=Even Earth hath spread herself wide at their coming, and they as '''husbands''' have with power impregned her.<br>They to the pole have yoked the winds for coursers: their sweat have they made rain, these Sons of Rudra.

sa||RV|6|17|3|quote=यो नो॑ अग्ने दु॒रेव॒ आ मर्तो॑ व॒धाय॒ दाश॑ति ।<br>तस्मा॑न् नः '''पा॒ह्य्''' अंह॑सः ॥|trans=Whatever sinner, Agni, brings oblations to procure our death,<br>'''Save''' us from woe that he would work.

sa||RV|6|24|10|quote=सच॑स्व ना॒यम् अव॑से अ॒भीक॑ इ॒तो वा॒ तम् इ॑न्द्र पाहि रि॒षः ।<br>अ॒मा चै॑न॒म् '''अर॑ण्ये''' पाहि रि॒षो मदे॑म श॒तहि॑माः सु॒वीराः॑ ॥|trans=Hasting to help, come hither and protect him, keep him from harm when he is here, O Indra.<br>At home, '''abroad''', from injury preserve him. May brave sons gladden us through a hundred winters.

sa||RV|6|47|21|quote=दिवे दिवे '''सदृशीर्''' अन्यम् अर्धं कृष्णा असेधद् अप सद्मनो जाः ।<br/>अहन् दासा वृषभो वस्नयन्तोद-व्रजे वर्चिनं शम्बरं च ॥|trans=Day after day he drove them far from their seat, from place to place, those darksome creatures who were all '''alike'''.<br/>The Hero slew the meanly-huckstering Dāsas, Varcin and Śambara, where the waters gather.
sa||RV|6|64|1|quote='''कृ॒णोति॒''' विश्वा॑ सु॒पथा॑ सु॒गान्यभू॑दु॒ वस्वी॒ दक्षि॑णा म॒घोनी॑ ॥|trans=She '''makes''' all paths easy and fair to travel, and truly has shown herself benign and friendly.

sa||RV|6|68|05|quote=स इत् सु॒दानुः॒ स्ववाँ॑ ऋ॒तावेन्द्रा॒ यो वां॑ वरुण॒ दाश॑ति॒ त्मन् ।<br>इ॒षा स द्वि॒षस् त॑रे॒द् दास्वा॒न् वंस॑द्र॒यिं '''र॑यि॒वत॑श्''' च॒ जना॑न् ॥|trans=Only he is truly rich in gifts and favor, truly righteous by law, O Indra and Varuna, who is willing to revere you two.<br>The generous one, through food, should surpass his foes; he should conquer wealth and '''wealthy people''' for himself.

sa||RV|6|75|17|quote=यत्र बाणाः सम्पतन्ति कुमारा '''विशिखा''' इव ।<br/> तत्रा नो ब्रह्मणस् पतिर् अदितिः शर्म यच्छतु विश्वाहा शर्म यच्छतु ॥|t=Where the arrows are falling scatteredly, like children '''without shikha''' [i.e. before having undergone religious tonsure];<br/>May Aditi and Bṛhaspati always provide protection there.

sa||RV|8|41|5|quote=यो '''ध॒र्ता''' भुव॑नानां॒ य उ॒स्राणा॑मपी॒च्या॒३॒॑ वेद॒ नामा॑नि॒ गुह्या॑।<br> स क॒विः काव्या॑ पु॒रु रू॒पं द्यौरि॑व पुष्यति॒ नभ॑न्तामन्य॒के स॑मे॥|t=He who is the '''sustainer''' of the worlds, who knows the hidden and secret names of the (solar) rays, he is the sage who cherishes the acts of sages, as the heaven cherishes numerous forms; may all our adversaries perish.

sa||RV|9|81|1|quote=प्र सोमस्य पवमानस्योर्मय इन्द्रस्य यन्ति जठरं सुपेशसः ।<br>'''दध्ना''' यदीमुन्नीता यशसा गवां दानाय शूरमुदमन्दिषुः सुताः ॥|trans=The beauteously adorned waves of Soma move onward to Indra's throat, as he purifies himself,<br>When they, brought forward with the lovely '''curd''' of kine, effused, have cheered the Hero to bestow his gifts.

sa||RVKh||quote=आ॒र्द्रां पु॒ष्करि॑णीं पु॒ष्टिं सु॒वर्णां॑ '''हेम॒मालि॑नीम्''' ।<br>सू॒र्यां हि॒रण्म॑यीं ल॒क्ष्मीं जात॑वेदो म॒ आव॑ह ॥|trans=O Jātavedas, invoke her for me, who is like water, adorned with lotuses, the nourishing one; invoke her who is golden hued, and '''garlanded with gold'''.<br>Invoke her for me who is [brilliant] like the Sun, golden hued, invoke Lakṣmī for me.

sa||Saundarananda|2|55|quote='''तुतुषुस्''' तुषिताश् चैव शुद्धावासाश् च देवताः ।<br>सद्धर्मबहुमाणेण सत्त्वानां चानुकम्पया ॥|t=The deities of Tuṣita and Śuddhāvāsa '''became calm'''<br>Through the great esteem toward the dharma and the compassion toward sentient beings.
sa||ŚBr|10|4|2|13|quote=पञ्चदशात्मनो ऽकुरुत '''अष्टाचत्वारिंशद्''' इष्टकान्त् स नैव व्याप्नोत्|trans=He made himself fifteen bodies of '''forty-eight''' bricks each: he did not succeed.

sa||ŚBr|10|4|2|14|quote=षोडशात्मनो ऽकुरुत '''पञ्चचत्वारिंशद्''' इष्टकान्त् स नैव व्याप्नोन् न सप्तदशधा व्यभवत्|trans=He made himself sixteen bodies of '''forty-five''' bricks each: he did not succeed. He did not develop seventeenfold.

sa||ŚBr|2|4|1.1|quote=अथ '''हुते'''ऽग्निहोत्र उपतिष्ठते । भूर्भुवः स्वरिति तत्सत्येनैवैतद्वाचं समर्धयति यदाह भूर्भुवः स्वरिति तया समृद्धयाशिषमाशास्ते सुपोषः पोषैरिति तत्पुष्टिमाशास्ते|trans=Now he approaches the fires where the Agnihotra '''has been libated''' and utters: "Earth! ether! sky!" In saying "Earth! ether! sky!", he renders his speech auspicious by means of the truth, and with that (speech) thus rendered propitious he invokes a blessing:--"May I be well supplied with offspring!" whereby he prays for offspring; "--well supplied with men!" whereby he prays for men (heroes); "--well supplied with viands!' whereby he prays for prosperity.

sa||ŚBr|6|3|3.26|quote=समंबिला योनिर्वा इयं रेत इदं यद्वै रेतसो योनिमतिरिच्यतेऽमुया तद्भवत्यथ यन्न्यूनं '''व्यृद्धं''' तदेतद्वै रेतसः समृद्धं यत्समम्बिलं चतुःस्रक्तिरेष कूपो भवति चतस्रो वै दिशः सर्वाभ्य एवैनमेतद्दिग्भ्यः खनति|trans=It (the lump of clay) should be as large as the hole: thus this earth (or clay) becomes his (Agni's) self. And as to its (being) as large as the hole, -- this earth is the womb, and this clay is seed; and whatever part of the seed exceeds the womb, becomes useless; and what is deficient, is '''unsuccessful'''; but that part of the seed which is within the hole is successful. Four-cornered is this hole, for there are four quarters: from all the four quarters he thus digs him out.

sa||ŚBr|8|6|2|18|quote=सोऽस्यैष सुकृत आत्मा । तद्यस्य हैतमेवं सुकृतमात्मानं कुर्वन्त्येतं ह स सुकृतमात्मानमभिसम्भवत्यथ यस्य हैतमतोऽन्यथा कुर्वन्ति '''दुष्कृतं''' ह तस्यात्मानं कुर्वन्ति स ह स '''दुष्कृतम्''' एवात्मानमभिसम्भवति |trans=That body of his (Agni) is well-made; --and, indeed, for whomsoever they thus make that body of his so as to be well-made, he becomes possessed of that body of his as a well-made one; but for whomsoever they make it otherwise than that, for him they make that body of his so as to be '''ill-made''', and he becomes possessed of an '''ill-made''' body.

sa||Suśruta Saṃhitā|46|292|quote=वेणोः '''करीराः''' कफला मधुरा रसपाकतः ।<br/> विदाहिनो वातकराः सकषाया विरूक्षणाः ॥|t=Bamboo '''shoots''' are phlegmatic, sweet both in taste and digestion, causing heartburn and flatulence, astringent and dryness-causing.

sa||Suśruta Saṃhitā|46|292|quote=वेणोः करीराः '''कफला''' मधुरा रसपाकतः ।<br/> विदाहिनो वातकराः सकषाया विरूक्षणाः ॥|t=Bamboo shoots are '''phlegmatic''', sweet both in taste and digestion, causing heartburn and flatulence, astringent and dryness-causing.

sa||TS|IV|5.11|2|quote=नमो रुद्रेभ्यो ये पृथिव्यां ये ऽन्तरिक्षे ये दिवि येषाम् अन्नं वातो वर्षम् इषवस् तेभ्यो दश प्राचीर् दश दक्षिणा दश '''प्रतीचीर्''' दशोदीचीर् दशोर्ध्वास् तेभ्यो नमस् ते नो मृडयन्तु ते यं द्विष्मो यश् च नो द्वेष्टि तं वो जम्भे दधामि ॥|trans=Homage to the Rudras on the earth, in the atmosphere, in the sky, whose arrows are food, wind, and rain, to them ten eastwards, ten to the south, ten to '''the west''', ten to the north, ten upwards; to them homage, be they merciful to us, him whom we hate and him who hateth us, I place him within your jaws.

sa||TS|VII|5.18|quote=आऽस्मिन् राष्ट्रे राजन्य इषव्यः शूरो महारथो जायताम् । दोग्ध्री धेनुः । वोढाऽनड्वान् आशुः सप्तिः पुरंधिर्योषा जिष्णू रथेष्ठाः सभेयो युवा । आऽस्य यजमानस्य वीरो जायताम् । निकामेनिकामे नः पर्जन्यो वर्षतु फलिन्यो न ओषधयः पच्यन्ताम् । '''योगक्षेमो''' नः कल्पताम् ॥|trans=In this kingdom may a prince [who is bent on ruling] be born, an archer [who is able to shoot arrows], a hero [who is bent on excelling in battle], and a great chariot-fighter [who is bent on fighting]; a milk cow who will yield milk; a draught ox [who is bent on plowing]; a swift racer [who is bent on running]; a young woman who is fertile; a victorious warrior [who is bent on winning]; a youth fit for the assembly [who is bent on speaking well]. To this worshipper be a hero born. May Parjanya rain for us whensoever we desire. May our plants ripen with fruit. May '''peace and prosperity''' be ours.|tr=ā́smín rāṣṭré rājanyà iṣavyàḥ śū́ro mahārathó jāyatām. dógdhrī dhenúḥ. vóḍhānaḍvā́n. ā́śuḥ sáptiḥ. púraṃdhiryóṣā. jiṣṇū́ ratheṣṭhā́ḥ. sabhéyo yúvā. ā́syá yájamānasya vīró jāyatām. nikāménikāme naḥ parjányo varṣatu phalínyo na óṣadhayaḥ pacyantām. '''yogakṣemó''' naḥ kalpatām.

sa||VS|11|15|quote=प्रतूर्वन्न् एह्य् अवक्रामन्न् अशस्ती रुद्रस्य '''गाणपत्यम्''' मयोभूर् एहि ।<br/>उर्व् अन्तरिक्षं वीहि ।<br/>स्वस्तिगव्यूतिर् अभयानि कृण्वन् पूष्णा सयुजा सह ॥|t=Come speeding on and trampling imprecations; come gladdening to the '''chieftainship''' of Rudra.<br/>Speed through the wide air, whose paths are pleasant,<br/>Come, providing safety, with Pūṣan as your companion.
